story:
About the work:

My name is Khalif. I'm a theatre artist recently out of grad school, and I am putting up my first play Spilled Milk , in the New York Winterfest Theatre Festival, February 2020. But I need your help! Producing theatre--even for as short a run as this--isn't a cheap task. It takes a lot of people and resources to make the magic happen! Now a little about this work:

  • Spilled Milk is a drama/ choreopoem that tells the story of Bobbie—a young black poet— and his five friends who are dealing with his suicide. The play takes place at the repass of Bobbie’s funeral at his childhood home. While he narrates this day and tries to make it more poetic and easier than it is, we see his friends examine grief and the validity and presence of mental illness in Bobbie’s life, as well as their own; and how they could’ve saved him and their friendship.
  • The piece deals with mental health for people of color (One of the reocurring themes in a lot of my work) and has a cast made up entirely of people of color.
  • I began writing this play in undergrad when I got incredibly depressed and needed some way to express how I was feeling and process what I was going through. Each of the friends in this play represent a different stage of grief each character's voice is used to reflect on and speak to a different aspect of my mental state while depressed. The anger, denial, confusion, etc. The piece then naturally became about mental health and my experience with it as a person of color; and how communities of color don't always acknowledge the existence of mental illness. Ultimately, this play begs the question, how do we get healthy?

What We Need

  • For this campaign, I am looking to raise $7500, which goes towards
    • 6 Actor Salaries
    • Rehearsal Space
    • Director
    • Stage Manager
    • Light Board Operator
    • Lighting Designer
    • Sound Designer/ Composer
    • Costumes
    • Set and props
    • Programs
  • If this goal is not met, the funds would go first to paying the actors, then rehearsal space and we would delegate from there where we could make changes and cut costs down.

The Impact

I've shared this play across tables with friends old and new through different parts of the country and the thing that always rings true is that people can relate very much to the feeling of invisible pain; or being from a family or in an environment where people don't take your pain or struggle seriously if they can't physically see it. That's why I think this piece is important. We need to be seen even when the pain is "invisible".

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount that you donate helps. And if you can't donate at the moment, please help spread the word by sharing this campaign with your friends, families, and peers. Thank you!

story:
The Violet Symphony

My name is Timothy White Eagle,  I am a visual and performance artist.

One important way you can support this work is to share this link, like and comment on my related posts, all that helps keep this ball rolling. 

I am in the process of creating a performance about people whom I loved and who died while in a place of deep addiction. It is a personal story, with the universal themes of release and forgiveness. The show will use a five person cast, tricksters, addicts, drag queens, a small Greek chorus, movement, story telling, sets, costumes, lighting, and music. This is the story of the sacred path of the ones that go too far.

I am partnering with On The Boards in Seattle to bring this show to life.  OTB, has commissioned the work in part, and will be funding many of the expense.  Unfortunately not all of the expense can be covered by OTB, I am responsible for paying my director, performers, designers and various other expenses.  The show premieres at OTB in March 2020 and will tour later that year at La Mama in NYC.  

With your help we can create a kind of healing theater.  Additionally your donation will help establish my career as a touring performer. I promise your donation will be well spent, on art and artists telling an important story.

It’s my hope that this show leaves its audience with greater compassion for those dealing with addiction, while finding peace for our memories of those who passed while addicted.  It is my hope that we can collectively as a community of artists and audiences come together and honor those imperfect loved ones and by honoring them may we relieve some of the tension in the world which drives us all to seek perfection.

I am seeking at least $5,000 in funding. Most of which will go to paying all the artists, designers and performers helping to create this show.

‘Thank you sincerely for anything you can offer from warm wishes to big dollars, all are welcome.

story:
Short Summary

ut patet Theater Company is a Latinx artistic organization that thrives to create equal opportunities for women and Latin American artists in New York City. 

Founded by Brazilian actors and producers Juliana Suaide and Renata Soares, ut patet, which means “to be clear”, is a huge step for us, as immigrants and as women, to create an outlet where we can have our own stories and ideas heard. 

So this is what we ask of you:

 

help us to give this first big step in bringing different stories to New York

 

We’re producing SAVANA GLACIAL, an award-winning play written by one of the most influential contemporary Brazilian playwrights, Jô Bilac. We need your financial support to make that happen. But, “to be clear”, your support really means so much more than that. 

Having your support means that our voices and our work matter, and you’ll help us set the stage for many more productions to come. Because, oh boy, we’re just getting started!

Let's be realistic...

There are many challenges in living as Latinx artists in NYC - which we can tell you all about it over coffee or drinks some time - but nothing will ever make us feel any less proud of who we are or where we come from.

So this is where we stand. 

This will be the first time one of Bilac’s works is produced in the United States and, as Brazilians, it’s extremely important for us to share our artistry and show that our country has much more to offer than soccer, naked women, Carnaval and a terrible President that doesn’t care about burning down the Amazon Forest. 

That it is not the Brazil that represents us.

So let us show you what truly represents us. And like most Bossa Nova’s greatest hits, Savana Glacial knows exactly how to talk about pain and trauma through a poetic and fun text. 

 

Pain and Trauma and Poetic and Fun?!

Yep! Savana Glacial is a dark comedy that dives deep into a love triangle between a writer, his wife who suffers from short-term memory loss and their eccentric neighbor.

In this multi-layered world full of trauma and loss, everything is fiction— except the pain.

And there’s something beautiful about it - trauma and pain. Because there’s so much growth after we experience trauma and so much light after we feel pain. 

The play will be directed by award-winning Brazilian director Marina Montesanti. According to Marina,

The play exposes deep layers of internal attachments, coping mechanisms, and attempts to be free again. (...) It allows us to reconsider our human condition and it’s paradox with the urban behavior and conflicts of the modern existence:  isolation, paranoia and the artificiality in relationships.

About the creators

Juliana and Renata met back in Brazil in 2010 and were roommates when Renata first moved to New York in 2015. They have always shared this hunger and need to create, experiment and jump in with both feet in projects that felt right to them. So when the opportunity came to take on this challenge together, neither of them hesitated to say YES!

 

The idea of having a  theatre company here in NY has always been a great desire. There is so much waiting on the actor’s life so I always felt in need to create my own projects. I do believe great minds think alike, so this connection with Renata to just jump on board and start producing this play was something meant to happen - Projects do not get out of text messages or emails if there’s no connection between the creators. - Juliana

 

One of the biggest challenges that I had to face when establishing myself as an artist in New York was finding my own community. There’s something special when you find an artistic connection that inspires and dares you to dream bigger, and I think Juliana and I do that for each other. Artists can do great things on their own but nothing compares to when you create something together. - Renata 

 

Okay! So let’s create something together.

This is what we really need.


With your support, we’ll be able to produce this play and pay for the:

  • theatre fee
  • scripts
  • costumes
  • set
  • props
  • marketing

 

... and compensate our collaborators. ;)

 

  • 2 producers
  • 1 director
  • 4 actors
  • 1 choreographer
  • 1 composer
  • 1 lighting designer
  • 1 set designer
  • 1 costume designer
  • 1 stage manager
  • 1 script supervisor

 

yup, we have a lot of great people on board! 

 

And since we are all independent artists, we have all agreed to use this crowdfunding to pay for the production's costs, and then we are going to share whatever is left equally between everyone who is sharing their vision, talent and time with us.

 

what do we have to pay 

 

Let's be pretty transparent in here:

 

  • $1350 (+ 20% of box office) - Venue Rental
  • $300 - Props
  • $300 - Costume 
  • $100 - Man with a van

 

other ways you can help

 

Oh yeah, there are other ways you can help. ;)

 

  • Come and watch our performance. PLEASE DO!
  • Follow and share our content on Instagram. - @savanaglacialplay
  • And Indiegogo has asked us to remind you to use their share tools!

 

And that's all, folks!

story:
Making a cake is difficult without a mixing bowl.
Living a life is difficult without mental health care.
Is it too much to ask to want to have your cake and treatment?

George is an actor and Sionnán is a writer. 

We’re both storytellers,  We each have a poignant personal story involving cake,

And neither of us could win the battle to access treatment for our separate mental health conditions in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.

Instead of birthday presents for us this year we are asking for help making a show about this!

 

We recently devised a documentary production for Scene+Heard that explored the biochemical imbalances in our brains, the effect this has on our day-to-day routines, and the obstacles we encounter in trying to bake cakes - oh, I mean live our lives.

But sometimes sharing cake can make everything feel kind of ok.

You know, there really is an incomparable joy in feeling ok.

 

We were both heartened and devastated by the stories our audience members approached us with immediately after our Scene + Heard show. 

We know we need to take this story further.

Mental illness is a lonely experience.

Even more so when the support you need is “not currently available”.

We know that it can feel like a twisted contest and like there is no winning.

But we refuse to lose.

And we need to make a fuss, because no one should feel like they have to struggle alone.

 

For this development phase of CAKE we are going further than exploring just our own experiences. We have a network of friends and collaborators in psychology, in culinary careers, and in therapy. And there is a lot more cross over between these areas than we realised. We’re already in talks (well, Zooms)  and are holding weekly online script-development workshops together. We’re excited about the creative solutions we’re coming up with to facilitate remote devising until it’s safe to see each other again - when we will be looking at developing it further in person!

 

If you’ve any questions, or any advice or guidance for us in relation to developing our project further, do get in touch!

What We Need 

For this project we need help paying for:

  • Rehearsal and development space cost for two weeks; €1000
  • Printing and transport costs for interviews and rehearsals; €300 (trust us, there's a lot of paperwork!)
  • Freedom of Information (FOI) requests; €150
  • Indiegogo fees; approx €50

Why do we need to make this?

We are making this for;

Anyone who has ever struggled to access appropriate mental health supports - and needs to know that they are not alone.

Anyone who is close to the above person - and who wants to understand how to support them.

Anyone who is a frontline mental health worker - and who is frustrated that they don’t have access to the resources they need.

Anyone who is responsible for the funding of mental health services - and needs to see how their decisions affect patients on the ground.

We believe that this an important piece of theatre to make and would appreciate any help you can give! If you aren't in a position to donate please share this on social media/ by email/ send a carefully coded semaphore message to the Minister for Health.

Thank you all,

George and Sionnán

story:
Part drive-in performance, part healing cypher, this Atlanta-based multimedia Immersive Theater production tells the story of a family thrown into chaos after the death of their matriarch. 

Hello! We are the cast and creative team of HEREafter. Our story begins in 2017, when former Sleep No More cast member Kelly Bartnik launched her own Immersive Theater production HERE in NYC.  Seeing an untapped market in Atlanta, Kelly approached Kathleen Wessel, a choreographer and faculty member in the Department of Dance Performance and Choreography at Spelman College, with an idea: to build the first large-scale, long-running (Broadway model) Immersive Theater show in the Southeast. For two years, Kelly and Kathleen amassed a creative team, held workshops, plotted and planned, and eventually secured a home in the historic H.L. Green building in South Downtown Atlanta with the help of Newport Real Estate: a 10,000 square foot space that was a five and dime store in the 1950s.

In October 2019, we held a pop-up performance in H.L. Green, a sort of prequel to the main show and an introduction to the setting, story, and characters. Here is the full teaser:

    We were about to start construction on the set and rehearsals with the cast when the pandemic hit and the show had to be put on hold indefinitely. 

    After much consideration, we decided to craft a different version of the show that would expand on the existing narrative while utilizing a completely new format to allow for social distancing guidelines, yet still allow the audience to become part of the show. 

    Why Us?

    Kelly Bartnik is a leading expert in Immersive Theater, an original cast member of Sleep No More, and cast representative for the both the Boston and NYC productions. She has worked with top immersive companies and productions including Meow Wolf, Amazon Prime, Optika Moderna with La Jolla Playhouse, and Cinereal's The Unbrunch. 

    Co-Director Kathleen Wessel was a founding member of Staibdance in Atlanta and is the current director of Spelman Dance Theater. She was an associate co-director and choreographer for the Georgia Incarceration Performance Project Presents: By Our Hands, a devised work that explored the history of prison and convict labor in Georgia.

    The cast below from left to right: Ivory Lloyd, Aaron Glaize, Patrick Otsuki, Tate Rekhlau, Monique Wimby and Lamia Dingle.

    Together we devise. We do not work with an existing script but instead create character tracks, dialogue, storyline, and choreography in rehearsals as a group.  All members of the team are co-creators including set, lighting, sound, and costume designers, a set decorator, and dramaturge. 

    Why Now?

    #immersivetheatersowhite

    Immersive Theater is a relatively new genre in the United States and was one of the fastest growing facets of the entertainment industry before COVID-19 shook up the planet. But despite its massive rise in popularity, Immersive Theater remains a majority white art form with very few people of color performing in, consulting for, designing or leading productions. So we ask ourselves:

    • How do we continue to support artists and engage audiences in a pandemic?
    • How do we amplify Black voices, stories and storytellers?
    • How do we work to dismantle white supremacy in arts organizations and creative processes?
    • How do we stay true to the intimacy offered in Immersive Theater while keeping people safe?

    The Impact

    #artisessentialwork

    We turn to who we are and what we know for solace and a path forward during these confusing and difficult times. As artists, we know there is great power and possibility in the practice of listening, following our instincts, and letting one moment drive the next, leaning on the work we've done but rerouting or wholly ditching the plan when need be to make way for something better, more spontaneous, or more generous. A skyscraper needs a strong core but also the ability to sway in the wind. When a structure is too rigid, it will break.  Artists know how to change it up, bring people together, and shift perspectives.

    Prior to the pandemic, Immersive Theater was thriving and expanding at exponential rates, pointing to a desire for people to engage in performance work in a more intimate and personal way.  Now that we've all been in the house for 4 months, the desire for connection and experience is even more potent.

    We need to get off Zoom and get out of the house, y'all.  Safely.

    What We Need & What You Get

    Each pop-up performance costs about $5,000 to mount. About half of this amount goes directly to rehearsal and performance pay for the cast of six.  The remainder goes to PR, recurring props, back-of-house staffing and sound/lighting design. The July 25/26th shows are intended to be the first of several through the remainder of the summer and early fall.  Due to social distancing regulations, we have to limit the amount of audience members we can have per show.  Additionally, we want to be sure to keep the ticket prices financially accessible.  For those reasons, the amount of money we make per pop-up through ticket sales is minimal and will primarily go toward administrative costs as well as longer term investment to hopefully mount the full show when pandemic restrictions are lifted.

    Risks & Challenges

      At this point, the show we are crafting and the impact it will have is a mystery.  Our top priority is safety, so the work is being created with those parameters in mind first and foremost. But within those parameters, we are finding unique and interesting ways to allow audience members to engage in performance, follow a narrative, and even change location over the course of the show.  It will be an experiment that we will learn from and continue to tweak as we move forward.

She has worked with top immersive companies and productions including Meow Wolf, Amazon Prime, Optika Moderna with La Jolla Playhouse, and Cinereal's The Unbrunch. 

Co-Director Kathleen Wessel was a founding member of Staibdance in Atlanta and is the current director of Spelman Dance Theater. She was an associate co-director and choreographer for the Georgia Incarceration Performance Project Presents: By Our Hands, a devised work that explored the history of prison and convict labor in Georgia.

The cast below from left to right: Ivory Lloyd, Aaron Glaize, Patrick Otsuki, Tate Rekhlau, Monique Wimby and Lamia Dingle.

Together we devise. We do not work with an existing script but instead create character tracks, dialogue, storyline, and choreography in rehearsals as a group.  All members of the team are co-creators including set, lighting, sound, and costume designers, a set decorator, and dramaturge. 
Why Now?
#immersivetheatersowhite
Immersive Theater is a relatively new genre in the United States and was one of the fastest growing facets of the entertainment industry before COVID-19 shook up the planet. But despite its massive rise in popularity, Immersive Theater remains a majority white art form with very few people of color performing in, consulting for, designing or leading productions. So we ask ourselves:

How do we continue to support artists and engage audiences in a pandemic?
How do we amplify Black voices, stories and storytellers?
How do we work to dismantle white supremacy in arts organizations and creative processes?
How do we stay true to the intimacy offered in Immersive Theater while keeping people safe?

The Impact
#artisessentialwork

We turn to who we are and what we know for solace and a path forward during these confusing and difficult times. As artists, we know there is great power and possibility in the practice of listening, following our instincts, and letting one moment drive the next, leaning on the work we've done but rerouting or wholly ditching the plan when need be to make way for something better, more spontaneous, or more generous. A skyscraper needs a strong core but also the ability to sway in the wind. When a structure is too rigid, it will break.  Artists know how to change it up, bring people together, and shift perspectives.
Prior to the pandemic, Immersive Theater was thriving and expanding at exponential rates, pointing to a desire for people to engage in performance work in a more intimate and personal way.  Now that we've all been in the house for 4 months, the desire for connection and experience is even more potent.
We need to get off Zoom and get out of the house, y'all.  Safely.
What We Need & What You Get
Each pop-up performance costs about $5,000 to mount. About half of this amount goes directly to rehearsal and performance pay for the cast of six.  The remainder goes to PR, recurring props, back-of-house staffing and sound/lighting design. The July 25/26th shows are intended to be the first of several through the remainder of the summer and early fall.  Due to social distancing regulations, we have to limit the amount of audience members we can have per show.  Additionally, we want to be sure to keep the ticket prices financially accessible.  For those reasons, the amount of money we make per pop-up through ticket sales is minimal and will primarily go toward administrative costs as well as longer term investment to hopefully mount the full show when pandemic restrictions are lifted.

Risks & Challenges

At this point, the show we are crafting and the impact it will have is a mystery.  Our top priority is safety, so the work is being created with those parameters in mind first and foremost. But within those parameters, we are finding unique and interesting ways to allow audience members to engage in performance, follow a narrative, and even change location over the course of the show.  It will be an experiment that we will learn from and continue to tweak as we move forward.

story:
Like many organizations, the COVID-19 pandemic has pushed REDi Dance Company to pivot and refine our mission, goals and curriculum.  REDi Dance Company is a community of storytellers. We advocate for interpersonal relationships and use a variety of performance tactics to inspire healing connections. The company presents dance-theater works that fuse House, Latin dance and Modern dance. We are excited to share our vision for 2021. One filled with hope and action. We are prepared to keep our momentum going and it's our mission to keep our programs financially accessible. With your help we will raise $11,000 for our 2021 youth programs. 

During the pandemic we worked together with little to no resources and supported young artists in three major ways:

1) by creating the #DanceBridgeChallenge dance challenge on Instagram: @dancebridgeworkshop (April 2020) 

2) by organizing a 4-week virtual welcome workshop for our new Junior Dance Company recruits (July 2020) Click HERE to watch the process.

3) by starting a Junior Dance Company and rehearsing for 6 weeks at three Bronx parks (September 2020). At the last rehearsal the company performed a work in progress at the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance. The dance piece was live streamed on Instagram. In this rehearsal process each young artist was assigned a mentor. See the entire performance HERE!  

This pandemic affirmed our belief that art making is a necessary tool for survival, self-love and transformation. Going forward your support will continue to provide quality work, healing processes and creative outlets for the Bronx community. 

Youth Programs:

1. Dance Bridge Workshop

March 30-31 & August 16-20 2021

Dance Bridge Workshop was founded in 2017.  This low-cost program ($10 per day) provides a safe space for teen artists to use dance making as a tool for effective storytelling. This 5-day program takes place twice a year during the NYC public school breaks (spring and summer). Our aim is to establish a community of young people who are continuously creating and learning the skills needed to speak their truth. 

We are fundraising for a 2-day virtual iteration of the program during the NYC Department of Education spring break and a live in-person workshop during summer break at Lehman College. Participants will practice daily rituals for self-care. Our dance making exercises are centered around the theme of healing. We will talk about simple systems that can ground and recharge our energy. Participants will also learn practical skills and methods that can equip them to choreograph their own dances. Each workshop day participants take dance classes with guest teaching artists. Past master classes include House, Bachata, Afrobeats, West African, Salsa, Modern Dance, Hip Hop, Vogue, Contemporary and Rumba. 

Click to learn more about the Dance Bridge Program!

2. Junior Company’s New Dance Piece

September 12 - November 14 2021 

What is the Junior Company?  The REDi Dance Junior Company is a pre-professional company of Bronx-residing dance and theater artists, ages 13-19. As a member of the company, artists are given access to free training in Latin dance techniques, House and Modern dance. Artists are given opportunities to co-create and perform original choreography and text. Our work is social justice based. We explore identity, liberation, self-care and healing practices. Our aim is to empower black and brown teens by providing avenues for them to exercise their creativity as artists and as active members of their community.

We are raising funds for a 3-month rehearsal process with the eight teen artists of our Junior Company. The company will produce a completed work (15-30 minutes in length). Youth will be building on a dance they started in September 2020.  Click HERE to see the dance. 

We feel confident in providing a stellar virtual experience for young people. In this time we have successfully created virtual programs for teen artists and have gained insight on how to improve and enhance the experience going forward. If we are unable to gather and create in person due to COVID-19 we are prepared for more remote learning experiences. 

Click for more information on the Junior Company!

What We Need: Our Goal $11,000

(Please see this separate link if you wish to make a tax deductible donation. This link allows you to make a direct donation to Beverly Lopez on The Field's website. We are fiscally sponsored by this nonprofit organization. All other donations through IndieGogo are not tax deductible.)

PROJECT EXPENSES: March - November 2021

Artistic Direction and Management:  $7,225 

Our director and program manager will spearhead the administrative components of both  programs. 

Teaching Artists: $1,275 

Cost for guest Teaching Artists. Past Teaching Artists include Ana Rokafella Garcia, Slim Xtravaganza, Candace Tabbs, Beatrice Capote, Leah Tubbs, Madelyn Sher, Roberto Parris, Dorren Smith, Raymond Falcon, and Marcel March.   

Project Staff: $2,000 

Cost for two Junior Co. rehearsal staff and two Dance Bridge Workshop staff. These individuals help facilitate the workshop or rehearsal experience and are present in the space during all program hours.

Materials/Supplies: $500 

Includes prints, craft/set materials,  and journals for Junior Company.

Other Ways You Can Help:

- BE A PART OF OUR COMMUNITY!

- Like and share our Indiegogo campaign link on social media 

- Like and share our campaign content on social media (see handles below)

- Tell potential donors about us

- Reach out to us and give encouraging words

- Ask to be on our mailing list (dancebridgeworks@gmail.com)

- Ask to volunteer for our upcoming programs

- Connect us to young people who may want to participate in our programs

 

THANK YOU FOR DONATING AND TAKING THE TIME TO LEARN ABOUT US!

STAY CONNECTED:

Email: dancebridgeworks@gmail.com

IG: @redidancecompany & @dancebridgeworkshop

FB: @redidancecompany

story:
WHAT IS SHAKE THE CITY?

 

'Shake The City'  is a play written by Millie Gaston with the Leeds community at heart, to help share the forgotten history of the Women's Liberation Movement and inspire young, northern, women.

 Based on the clothworkers strike in Leeds, 1970. Wendy, Laurie, Heather and Margaret work at Burton’s Menswear Factory. On the cusp of the new decade the four women decide to start their own Women’s Liberation Movement meetings in the fight for equality and equal pay. The 90 minute play focuses on the new wave of feminism of the 1970’s and the struggles women faced and fought. Shake The City puts three dimensional, complex women centre stage using a mixture of comedy and pathos.

2020 has the opportunity for magnificent transformation and we have the power to listen to a wider variety of voices. As well as being a historical dramatisation, the play has a social and economic comment on gender equality and the economic divide between the north and south. The play was written exactly fifty years on from the Leeds Clothworkers strike.

The show was written during the first UK lockdown. It has had two readings via zoom with two amazing groups of actors. The first zoom table read led to re-writes of the script. The second reading was part of FEVA Festival alongside Simon Armitage and Lucy Adlington. The reading was free and drew a massive live audience. This has led to the development of an R&D draft for the workshops with the aim to create a rehearsal draft for an audience in 2021. 

After the uncertainty of lockdown, I have pushed to organise the workshops for 2020. I feel proud and excited to be creating work after such a challenging year. This IndieGoGo Campaign is where it really counts to fund all the freelance artists!

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHY?

 

I am holding a five-day R&D at Leeds Playhouse to develop a script which will be produced in 2021. The workshops have been supported by Leeds Playhouse who are giving me in-kind support. The aim of the R&D is to develop the script, composition, movement, design and film the work to be able to pitch to Theatres and create initial marketing ideas. Additionally, by using a videographer to film the show I will be able to send the video to theatres, producers and there is also the opportunity to share the work on-line. As I will be producing the play in 2021, the workshops are vital in discovering new ways to make the show accessible and audience friendly under new Covid-19 restrictions. The workshops will employ nine freelance creatives to continue their creative practice and develop the show.

The script will be developed by myself and director Rob Ellis through table reads, workshopping scenes, re organisation of the script, feedback from industry professionals and a short presentation. I aim to have a rehearsal draft written from this week’s development.

         One day will be set aside to work with a composer to develop the music of the show. We aim to explore an original score and have one phrase written by the end of the week to accompany the promotional video with pitching the show. During this day, Rob Ellis, who is also a movement director, will explore the movement in the show.

         Designer, Caitlin Mawhinney will develop costume and set design ideas and help bring the world to life. She will also be responsible for creating ideas for a logo and developing ways in which we can make produce the play under new Covid-19 restrictions.

I need your help to be able to fund all the performers and creative team, especially after such a challenging year for theatre! Every donation will help go towards producing the show in 2021. I will make sure that you are taken on the plays journey and as a backer you will see how your donation helped to kick start the show. 

 

MEET THE TEAM

 

Millie Gaston (Writer)

Millie is a writer and producer based in Leeds. She graduated from Manchester School of Theatre in 2018 with a BA (hons) in Acting.  She has had commissions from the Northern Broadsides (Hon3y92) , York Army Museum (The Happy Warrior) and worked with theatres such as Leeds playhouse and Harrogate Theatre. She is currently working with the Northern Broadsides on an upcoming project for 2021 and is writing a show taking place at SlungLow in December 2020 (The Robin and The Holly Tree). She is also the Artistic Director of SHOOK, a regular cabaret evening in London, at the Arts Theatre Leicester Square and Leeds at Belgrave Music Hall, which has sold out every event (7 editions). 

Rob Ellis (Director/Dramaturg)

Rob is a director and dramaturg from North Yorkshire. His most recent work is Time and Tide (Park Theatre). Other theatre includes Cuttings (Theatre503; The Hope Theatre), The Merry Wives Of Windsor (Théâtre de Verdure du Jardin Shakespeare, Paris), The Taming Of The Shrew, The Two Gentlemen of Verona (Albert Square Gardens), Unicorn (Theatre N16), Bluebird (Katzpace), The 39 Steps (Upstairs At The Gatehouse), Six Pack (Leicester Square Theatre), Clybourne Park (Bridewell Theatre). He is the associate director for Wound Up Theatre, on their shows Bismillah! An ISIS Tragicomedy and It’ll Be Alt-Right On The Night (UK Tour; Edinburgh Fringe; Pleasance Theatre, Islington). He has also directed at Southwark Playhouse, Jermyn Street Theatre, Tristan Bates Theatre, and at the Edinburgh Fringe. Rob is the artistic director of Relish Theatre.

Caitlin Mawhinney (Designer)

Since graduating Nottingham Trent University with a First-Class Honours in Theatre Design and a Sustainability in Practice Award, Caitlin has been working as a freelance set and costume designer across the country. She is currently working with Red Ladder Theatre Company on their upcoing production 'My Voice Was Heard But It Was Ignored' at the Leeds Playhouse. During the last year she has created three productions with the Harrogate Theatre, including ‘The Body Snatcher’ by Thunder Road Theatre Company, which embarked on a 15 venue tour of the North. Her other work was with local playwrights: ‘Connection’ by Associate Artist Rachael Halliwell and ‘A Shadow of Doubt’ by Gill McVey. Her design for Leo & Hyde’s new pop-pera ‘The Marriage of Kim K’ also toured nationally following its run at The Lowry Theatre, Salford. Other productions include ‘There’s A Dead Body In My Baby’s Sandpit’ with Liverpool based company Falling Doors Theatre and the new musical ‘The Accidental Time Traveller’ at The Barbican, Plymouth. Alongside this, she has worked as an assistant for Michael Vale at the Kneehigh Asylum in Cornwall.

 

WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?

 

The support in kind is being given from Leeds Playhouse to support the company’s infrastructure and hosting the workshops. The theatre wants to support myself as I am a part of their Furnace artist collective and also because they have an interest in the project.  

The company fees are based upon current ITC rates for 5 days work: 

Composer - £131.00 x 1 day

Designer - £494

Director - £494

Writer - £494

Videographer - £300

Captioner - £28.26 based on 30 minutes of footage

Actors x 3 - £1,482.00​ 

Marketing - £200

Total  ​- £3,623.26

In-Kind support from Leeds Playhouse -  £1750

Contingency and match funding supported by myself £537.33

 

THE IMPACT

 

 I found that writing gave me a voice, and as a young northern female, this has become more and more liberating. I want my writing to reflect the women I know and to celebrate un-heard voices. Shake The City puts Yorkshire women centre stage and shares a forgotten history. 

With the help of your contribution I will be able to bring this local story back to the Leeds community and share to a wider audience about the Women's Liberation Movement. I hope that the play will open conversations between mothers and daughters. 

I have big plans for the play and the workshops are going to be a giant leap for producing in 2021!

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

 

If we do not hit the target then your money will not go to waste. The money will still be used to go towards the workshops however, there will be elements which will be stripped back. For example, the show will not be filmed and there will be cuts on other marketing areas. Whilst this is possible, it would still be amazing to hit our target as all promotional materials will help to pitch to theatres and producers for 2021. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

I understand that not everyone will be able to donate, especially after such a challenging year. It would be amazing if you can share the Crowdfunder and tell your friends and family about the campaign. Every share helps to spread the word and gets this show on the road. 

Don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read all about Shake The City, any donation will go along way and is incredibly exciting for the beginning of Shake The City.

story:
Introduction

Dear reader,

Thank you for visiting our project campaign page on Indie GoGo.

I am a 20-year-old resident of Luxembourg. Since this year I am directing my very own play in English. I have been taking acting classes for 8 years and recently decided to change my point of view of the stage. 

Synopsis of the play:

The plot focusses on the meaning of trust and friendship, furthermore it uses the notion of reason of state and the respect for nature. Norse mythology plays an important part in the story as well, though it will be introduced step by step to avoid overwhelming the audience. 'A Shieldmaiden’s Saga' is not aiming to be historically accurate, but rather educational and entertaining.

The plot is about Rökia, a fisherwoman, who does not fit into her society and tries to find a way to feel accepted again. During her adventure she blunders into a much larger conflict and needs to make a decision that can alter the future for good or worse. In the meantime, a prophecy comes true and causes turmoil in the realm of the gods.

 

Where your money will go:

Dear potential supporter,

Some of the funds we need right now will be used to pay the cinematography team who record our green screen scenes. The rest of the funds will be used to pay the carpenter workshop for creating our custom Viking round shields that every actor needs. The funds need to pay the renting of the costumes and the renting of the music studio in order to record good quality music. As the play will have an intermezzo, we had the idea to offer the spectators traditional Scandinavian food and beverages. Thus the remaining amount of the funds will be used to pay the catering. 

While supporting the project, you will receive some exclusive content and behind the scenes footage or vlogs of our progress.

 

Importance of a supporter:

Dear supporter,

We urge you to consider helping the project to fully flourish. The project is nearly ready for finalisation, however right now we have sacrificed every good will of our close friends, therefore we don't have any other choice than to ask you to financially support us. 

The play has a real potential and once fully completed and having the final video of the whole performance in my grasp, then that will be a remarkable day in everyone's life who participated in this project and believed in my idea.

 

Our Obstacles that we have managed

As already mentioned, I am the stage director, however I am also the author and script writer of the play. In addition, I manage marketing and the advertisement campaign. Of course, I am the head of communication as well. And if this is not enough already, I am also composing the music for the play.

There is a lot that needs constant oversight in order to quickly react and adapt if obstacles occur. At the beginning of this year we had sort of a safe haven in the rehearsal rooms of my former high school. Everything was fine, but then Covid-19 made an appearance and everything was closed down. This was the first big obstacle, which we managed pretty quickly as I created a Discord server on which the rehearsals were held via online format.

Next bad surprise, the association that let us use the rehearsal rooms in the high school, did not want to know how we dealt with the situation as the schools were still closed down. When the government was discussing their deconfinement strategy, I immediately with all the necessary precautions asked different kinds of theatre houses, if some of them would let us in to rehearse. Still there was no curiosity from that first association. After a lot of trial and decline, one theatre house invited us in to rehearse and even play the final performances for free. As soon as I told my friends that the Shieldmaiden's Saga has not yet died, the first association began writing a complaint, that I would not have respected the terms and they decided to not further support the project anymore. Until this day I am still certain, that Covid-19 was the contract breaker and not me.

During the last few weeks, everybody is working as they should and according to the productivity we are on schedule and will be ready to perform in September.

However, it all depends on you, dear supporter.

As the Luxembourgish nation branding goes: Let's make it happen!

Other ways to help:

 

If you can't donate some money, then please make sure to use the link sharing tools of Indie GoGo to spread the word and tell everyone you know about our project.

 

I wish you a pleasant day,

Sincerely,

Daniel Kohnen

story:
INVASION! is Drama-Wallah’s first production which opened at the South Asian International Performing Arts Festival (SAIPAF) on August 5, and enjoyed incredible success sweeping the awards for Best Director -  Hafiz Karmali, Best Actor - Gopal Divan, and Best Ensemble. 


Drama Wallah is a newly-formed group of international artists who seek to break down the social, religious, racial, and ethnic barriers that divide people, and create something truly unique and undeniably human. We chose Jonas Hassen Khemiri’s 2011 Obie award winning play "INVASION!" as our so called map in the quest. Jonas' play gives people an opportunity to momentarily forget their individual identities and share in an experience of what is rooted in humanity. Drama Wallah was founded by actor/playwright Aman Soni and director Hafiz Karmali and is in collaboration for this production of "Invasion!" with cast members Gopal Divan, Jackson Goldberg, Mahima Saigal. 


THE STORY

The play is performed by an ensemble of four actors who each play five or more different characters. The story follows two American teenagers, Yousef (Gopal Divan) and Arvind (Aman Soni), as they navigate racial stereotypes and hip-hop culture in New York. INVASION! uses American politics as fodder for comedy, but the play is much more deeply rooted in philosophy than any particular political ideology. It reveals the subtle ways in which people trick themselves into dehumanizing others, and highlights the very real challenges of living together peacefully in a multicultural society.



WHY IT'S RELEVANT

With the influx of immigrants from all over the world to the US and western Europe at an all-time-high, INVASION! provides a crucial perspective that must be heard. The humor and irreverence that Khemiri uses so well allows the audience to feel included in this great endeavor, and that is why the play is effective and has the potential to change perspectives: it both implicates and includes everyone.



                    THEATER FOR THE NEW CITY


Since its inception, 'TNC' has presented powerful works that have won a total of 43 Obie Awards, as well as the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Sam Shepard’s Buried Child. Theatre for the New City has served as the home for theatre pioneers such as Richard Foreman, Charles Ludlam, Miguel Piñero, Ralph Lee, María Irene Fornés, Harvey Forbes Fierstein, and Heiner Muller. We would like nothing more than to continue this tradition of creating inspiring new work that challenges the traditional parameters of theatre.



THE CAST


Gopal Divan- Gopal was born and brought up in Hong Kong and left home at the age of 17 to train in classical theatre in London with RADA and at the Drama Centre. He is also currently starring in the extended run of the award winning play "Death of the Persian Prince” in New York and recently completed shooting an independent film entitled "Guys Reading Poems”. He was the recipient of the Best Actor Award at the 2015 South Asian International Performing Arts Festival for his performance in “Invasion!”. In addition to his acting work he is about to release his podcast series entitled “Sit-Chat-And”.  Invasion! (Yousef/Other), Death of the Persian Prince (Cas), Post Office (Fakir) NYC. Guys Reading Poems (The Oracle) Feature Film. Around the World in 80 Days (Phileas Fogg) Hong Kong. Casualty (Krishna) BBC UK. Señor Carrar’s Rifles (Pedro), Love’s Labours Lost (Longaville) West End, London.

Jackson Goldberg- Jackson is excited to make his NY Theater debut with DramaWallah. Jackson is a recent graduate of Indiana University Bloomington, where he studied Arabic Language.  He most recently appeared in Gruesome Playground Injuries (Doug) by Rajiv Joseph, for 4615 Theatre Company in Bethesda, MD. Past shows include, but are in no way limited to: Romeo and Juliet (Mercutio), In the Next Room, or The Vibrator Play (Leo Irving), Angels in America: Millennium Approaches: (Rabbi Isador Chemelwitz), Hello Herman (Herman Howards), Bachelorette (Joe), Honey Brown Eyes (Dragan). Jackson is from San Francisco, CA.

Mahima Saigal - Mahima is from New Delhi, India. She is currently studying at the Atlantic Theatre Company's Acting School (Professional Conservatory)She was recently seen as 'Djamila' in Charles Mee's "A Perfect Wedding" produced by the Atlantic Acting School, for which she also choreographed a Bollywood dance number for the entire cast of actors. In New Delhi she originated The role of Kasturba Gandhi in "Gandhi's Gita" produced by the Akshara National Classical Theatre of India,She has choreographed a number of Bollywood pieces for both theatre as well dance companies in India and New York.

Aman Soni- Aman is from New Delhi, India. He is an actor and a playwright who recently graduated from SUNY Purchase College with a degree in Theatre and Playwriting. He has also studied acting at Stella Adler Acting Studio and Atlantic Acting Conservatory. He recently appeared in Harold Pinter’s play ‘Room’ and Mike Bartletts play ‘Bull’ at SUNY Purchase College. Other performances include – The Merchant of Venice, Changeling by Thomas Middleton, The Good Person of Szechwan by Bertolt Brecht, 4.48 Psychosis by Sarah Kane



WHERE YOU CAN HELP

Performing in this festival at this venue will help our small theatre company reach a goal which many young artists dream of achieving. It allows us to tell our story honestly and honourably with dedication and energy as a story-telling force to be reckoned with. 

The reason we were able to produce and perform INVASION! so effectively at SAIPAF was the raw passion and connection each one of us felt towards this play. We want to spread this message of togetherness and empathy to a much wider audience at the DreamUp Festival, but we only have ten days left to raise this money, and we need your support to give it due justice. 

In order to participate in this festival, INVASION! would need a minimum of $3500 (breakdown below).

$500 Festival fees

$750 Play royalties for the festival

$300 Rehearsal space

$1950 Salary for the technicians and stage managers.

We’ve been able to raise such a substantial portion of what we need so quickly because of the excitement and appreciation of the audiences at SAIPAF. 

In order to push ourselves further as artists with this play we need a professional rehearsal space. They cost about $20/hr to rent, and we’re shooting for 15 hours of rehearsal before our first performance on August 30 to ensure that we present a first-rate production that is technically astute, truthful and impassioned.

It is more important that we pay the technicians and stage managers (whose hard work and dedication often goes unnoticed) who are absolutely essential to creating a powerful production. We’ve been so lucky to work with talented crew members and designers, and we need to be able to financially respect their work in order to move forward with this project.

We need $3500 to produce the play at its best but we would love to reach our ultimate goal of $5000 so that we can pay ourselves as artists. We value what we do and we know we have work of substance to share. Any contribution in any capacity will be highly appreciated. 

Becoming a contributer to the arts is one of the most important and generous ways to spend money. In Theater we can share a conversation on an emotional and psychological level that can’t be compared. We have an opportunity to present something unique and bold to society, and we want you to take the leap with us in giving our world a precious gift that would otherwise be lost to the great white void of ambivalence and routine. Please join us in this endeavour to better know ourselves and our nature so that we may improve and explore our human condition.


          Critical Reception for Invasion! 

Winner! 2011 Obie for Playwriting
A New York Times Critic's Pick!
INVASION! is “a meta-theatrical orientalist critique on ethnic stereotypes of people from South Asia and the Middle East. It is a tornado of words, images and ideas, all centered around a magical name: Abulkasem. The play assaults our deepest prejudices about identity, race and language. At once hilarious, disturbing and poignant, this deeply subversive play deconstructs concepts of the "OTHER" and forces us to confront our own cultural identity.”
"CRITIC'S PICK! A slyly entertaining comedy with a sharp political edge... expresses confusion with remarkable clarity." - The New York Times
"If you’ve ever wished somebody would write a razor-sharp play anatomizing lazy paranoia about the Middle East―somebody has." - The Village Voice
"A high-energy, often hectic experience, with theatrical and political ideas bouncing off each other like pinballs." - Backstage
"It's a stimulating, challenging, and rewarding ride." - NY Theatre



Thank you so much for taking the time to read this, it is your interest and connection to the work that keeps us young artists going.

Love,

The cast of INVASION!

story:
How Often Do I Dream...

My name is Katie Dorian. I am a Toronto-based theatre artist.

In December 2011 I spent some time with my Opi (Dad's Dad), and realized for the first time that his mind was not what it used to be. Opi repeated himself, forgot where he kept his shoes, and left Post It notes all around his apartment to remind him who my Dad was and what his phone number was. He had dementia.

I didn't know how to cope with losing him; what I perceived as losing him, and his memories along with my family's history. So, I created a piece of theatre that set out to explore memory and dementia, called "How Often Do I Dream..."

I premiered it at the Atlantic Fringe Festival in Halifax 2014, where the show received and award for Best Solo Show, and I am now taking it across Canada to 5 more Fringes: Montreal, Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton, and Victoria. 

But I need help to get there, and that's where you come in!


What We Need

I need $8000 to make it across the country with my stage manager, Gina.

$4000 goes to travel costs: plane tickets, baggage fees, and cabs to and from the airport.

$3000 goes to Gina and I living while on the road for 3 months: food, transportation to the theatre, and billet fees in Edmonton and Victoria.

$1000 goes to publicity and props: we want the show to be as successful as possible! We'll have to print many posters and hand bills, and we'll need to buy Post Its and Jell-O for each show (curious? you'll have to come see why!)

PERKS!

For each $20 donation: A personal thank you card illustrated by yours truly, Katie!

For each $50 donation: A personally illustrated thank you card, a print of the poster,  a permanent Post It note with your name on it on the set and 2 tickets to the show in the Fringe city of your choice!

For each $100+ donation: A personally illustrated thank you card, a print of the poster,  a permanent Post It note with your name on it on the set, 2 tickets to the show in the Fringe city of your choice, and a surprise piece of new Canadian artwork!

If we don't reach our entire goal, the first thing we need to fund are the travel costs, so no matter how much you fund you are helping us get safely to each city!

What you are doing by helping us across the country is allowing communities from across Canada to engage with stories we all share - in death, ageing and dementia.


Risks & Challenges

Fringe Festivals are hard to perform for - there is no guaranteed audience. We will be among many great shows in each city, and since our work is new, it's considered risky.

BUT!

We're growing little networks in each city on the tour list to help get people out, especially to the first two performances of each Fringe, so we have a good word-of-mouth campaign on the street once we get underway.

We're also reaching out to the Alzheimer's society and local community groups who focus on caring for those with dementia and Alzheimer's - and much of our reach is going to those who provide care. Primary care-givers are often over-looked in the confrontation with dementia, and "How Often Do I Dream..." is story-telling for them.


Other Ways You Can Help

We have a lofty goal, and not everyone can donate money...but you can help spread the word about the show!

If you know anyone in our Fringe Tour cities - 

Tell them about "How Often Do I Dream..."!

You can call your friends, family and acquaintances to tell them this show is happening in their local Fringe Festival. Post about it on Facebook, share our updates as we travel, tweet about it and help us grow an audience!

Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/events/983578598359385/ 

Twitter handle: @idreamoften

Blog page: katiedorian.com

You can use the Indie Go Go share tools, off to your right, and spread word the campaign with the click of a button. If you can't donate, maybe you know someone who can!

If you know anyone in our Fringe Tour cities - 
Tell them about "How Often Do I Dream..."!
You can call your friends, family and acquaintances to tell them this show is happening in their local Fringe Festival. Post about it on Facebook, share our updates as we travel, tweet about it and help us grow an audience!
Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/events/983578598359385/ 
Twitter handle: @idreamoften
Blog page: katiedorian.com
You can use the Indie Go Go share tools, off to your right, and spread word the campaign with the click of a button. If you can't donate, maybe you know someone who can!

story:
Imitation of a Performance of Life is a new play by Tiffany Osedra Miller.  In collaboration with Peggy Gould and Michael Rogers, the evening-length work will be presented in its premier production by NYC’s Dixon Place on Tuesday, March 17, 2015.  With this unique opportunity provided by Dixon Place, Miller and Gould have convened a company of nine players to bring the project to life via a mix of theater, dancing and music.  It is a culmination of many years’ work by Miller as a visionary writer and visual artist, in conversation with Gould and Rogers.

Themes of motherhood, daughterhood, restless spirits, racial identity, choice and chance permeate the carnivalesque and dreamlike world of the play, which arose specifically from decades of critical dialogue between Miller and her collaborators.  The rich imagery that features so strongly in all of Miller’s work, situates this piece squarely in the fluid temporality of a utopian universe steeped in Caribbean sensibility as it collides with the brutalities of life in its many layers.  Burlesque collides with post-modern and tap dancing;  Racialized rhetoric encounters resistance through exaggeration and parody.  Love finds its way in and around obsession.  And the fun is there for the taking.

The show has four acts, with an overture and epilogue, and features dancing, music and text interwoven throughout.  The company is currently in rehearsal with cast featuring Gould, Rogers, Chicava HoneyChild, Lea “BC Love” Bempah, Clarissa Marie Ligon, Genie Adagio, Anneke Hansen, Ashley Handel and Patrick Gallagher.  Lighting designer Kathy Kaufmann, photographer Bryan Fox, videographer Peter Richards and production stage manager Chloe Czinsky round out the production team for this event. 

We are seeking to raise a minimum of $3000, to help cover fees for artistic and technical personnel, rehearsal studio rental, video documentation and modest production costs.  Revenue raised beyond our minimum fundraising goal will be used to cover production expenses ($5800 total).  Revenue raised beyond total production expenses will be shared among all members of the production team, to more fully compensate everyone for the work that is being put in. 

Sincere thanks for considering this request for support.  Hoping to see you at Dixon Place!

story:
Our Project

Please help support Clairobscur Dance Company and the creation of Artistic Director and Choreographer Laurie Sefton’s new work “Memory Lapse.”

Clairobscur Dance Company is an award winning, issued based concert dance company that creates work where issues are viewed through an emotional lens.

Our newest work is “Memory Lapse” which will be performed to an emotional score by composer Bryan Kostors. Memory is a reflection of our past; its loss can mean a loss of identity, our relationships, loves and abilities. The act of recollection is just that, to collect the memory in your mind again. How do we make this happen? By repeating the same process over and over? By “thinking really hard?” Memory is physical, emotional, physiological, practical and necessary. We need our memory for daily life, for practical tasks as well as to keep us functioning and independent. I examine this topic from several points of view: short-term memory loss; trying to remember; Alzheimers; remembering one’s past self. This piece is both a journey and a glimpse of our memory. Memories can be vestiges of our reality, like a lingering impression of a scent or trying to recall the exact color of the sky in October, the mere feeling of trying to remember. Alternatively, it can be a definable concrete absence, a hole in the fabric of ones mind.  Memory Lapse will be premiered at Diavolo Performance Space this April.

What we've raised, what we need

We have already raised $3000, but need an additional $6,000 to complete the creation of this work. Most of the money you donate will go to pay our talented dancers for the rehearsal and performance of this work.  We also need to pay our lighting designer to create an original design for the lighting environment and our costume fabricator for her work as well.

When you make a donation to the creation of Memory Lapse you will receive some unique perks including at the $100 level a video artifact of some early rehearsal footage during the creation period of the work or at the $50 level an original photograph of Memory Lapse in rehearsal.  At the $250 level and above you will be invited to an early access rehearsal of the work in the studio. 

No donation is too small and every donation is important to us.  Please spread the word and help us complete this emotional, thought provoking work about memory.  Thank you.

story:
Applied Theatre Collective's Mission

The Applied Theatre Collective is a group of peacebuilders and artists who use applied theatre techniques to establish creative space for dialogue, understanding, and relationship building at the grassroots and policy levels both at home and abroad. 

What You'd Be Supporting!

Your donations will help to support our operational costs and the artists creating exciting new work!  These 2015 projects emphasize borders, both real & imagined. Here’s a quick overview of the projects that you would be supporting through your Indiegogo contribution:

  • Borders between Nations: ATC will connect local theatre communities in the Rio Grande Valley, Texas with migrant communities. As we connect these sectors, we will create, perform, and publish an original work of theatre on the migrant experience and put faces and stories to the numbers in news reports. By strengthening cooperation among these communities, we can work together to devise and advocate for policies to address their needs.
  • Borders between Races:  ATC will produce a participatory drama influenced by Anton Chekov's "Three Sisters" set during the Tulsa Race Riot. This piece will explore the legacy of unaddressed racial violence in our nation’s past and engage in a dialogue around how we might use our past to push us forward.
  • Borders between Beliefs: In April, ATC will be presenting a workshop at the 7th Annual Mediators Beyond Borders International Congress. Our workshop, Creative Approaches for Support, is designed to engage mediators in a dialogue around the necessity of analyzing personal histories and biases before mediating conflicts particularly in historically divided societies. Our session will emphasize the importance of creating space for reflection and support among their professional community.  
  • Borders between Gender: May 9th marks Man Question’s third New Masculinities Festival.  The festival is a day of performances and dialogue, investigating the question, “how do you stay human in the face of masculinity?” Performers and audience members who wish to stay connected after the festival will work with ATC to create an original piece of applied theatre together in the fall around this theme. 

The Impact

We work across borders to establish community for change, recognizing the interplay between art-and policy-making. This year we will begin the process by:

Establishing greater dialogue between local theatre artists and migrant communities in the Rio Grande Valley around issues of migration/immigration in order to create theatre and enable change.

Increasing awareness of legacies of racial violence in the U.S. for future advocacy to address this history of abuse.

Contributing to the field of peace mediation through practice-based research on building a community of support to those involved in resolving conflicts.

Building a network of people dedicated to exploring issues of gender to promote greater understanding, tolerance, and inclusivity.


A gift from you can help ATC be at the forefront of establishing creative space, supporting strategic thinkers, and cultivating a culture of peace through the arts. 

Can't donate? Help spread the word instead!

Just because you might not be able to contribute doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

story:
GENJI JACQUES

Genji E. Jacques is a writer, director and actor. He is known for his passion for the arts. He has starred in independent films and stage plays such as Wind of Desire, Hard Times, Miami Vice, Mary Jane, Brothers Under The Influence, In The House, Hoztage, Cloud 9, My Girl, Your Never Alone and When Good Men Are Tempted.

Genji is the founder and chief of Godz Sun Productions Inc., and present stage plays and films that not only entertain, but deliver positive, inspirational messages. He also an acting coach and a script supervisor/producer for the LunerVersal Film, Loving Till It Hurts. The motto for his production company is: "Your Life is a Ministry On Stage."

Currently, Genji is developing his acting work shop classes to teach upcoming actors in the Dade and Broward county area about acting and how to perfect their craft.

              GENJI'S ACTING WORKSHOP INTERVIEW WITH SEASONED

                             BROWARD AND DADE COUNTY ACTORS

LIGHTS, CAMERA, ACTION!!!

Most Florida actors are passionate about the entertainment industry, and they

take the opportunity to show their talent whether it's in a video, commercial, 

theater, feature or indie film.They strive toward their goal and educate themselves 

by attending acting seminars or workshops to perfect their craft.

On the other hand, the life of an actor is not easy for those who are pursuing 

to be actors because of the demand of time and challenges it requires the artist

 to give towards a project. For instance, actors sacrifice their time

from daily lives and spend hours on a stage to develop a

 scene or a character role they present in a stage play or film.

Moreover, they spend time to learn their lines in order to build chemistry

 in scenes with other characters they interact with on stage.

 As a result, the life of an actor takes passion, dedication, commitment, 

flexibility and humility to endure these challenges. However, they may 

realize that the acting career is demanding when it comes to 

their daily life schedule but they tend to overcome those demands

 because they have a passion for pursuing it. 

As a Director, Writer, Producer and Actor I understand and experienced those 

challenges, and in those times I learned a lot about the industry. Nevertheless, 

it has its obstacles but it also has its benefits as well. Actors have the opportunity 

to develop their craft and grow in the industry by: 

ACTORS DEVELOPING THEIR CRAFT

-Networking with legit directors and producers.

 -Network with other great actors. 

-Attend entertainment events.

 -Participate in acting activities.

 -Do what they love

 -Be seen on the "Big Screen."

 -Make money

 -Travel around the world 

The knowledge that I have now is priceless and based on my experiences

 my focus is not primarily on presenting fun acting activities. 

I focus on developing people's talent by educating them about the history

and foundation of the entertainment industry and how it affects the world. 

The Genji's Acting Workshop is a project that will develop into a resource for 

actors/actresses to experience an event that is supportive, positive, fun, and 

educational. It was a temporary project that benefit many

actors who came to develop their craft. 

Furthermore, they even met talented artists who testify about the their challenges 

and rewards of being an actor and to never give up on their dreams. 

The Genji's Acting Workshop will continue and develop into an entity that 

will benefit and inspire all actors in the community. The pledge goal for this project is $4000 

and with this funding the necessary materials needed can make the Genji’s Acting 

workshop more affective and provide momentum to continue to assist actors who 

want to develop their craft.  If the amount is not reached it will be

invested to produce inspirational plays or film in the community.

By making a pledge today to supply the proper tools and materials will help make 

Genji's Acting Workshop a qualified, active, event to all actors. 

GENJI'S ACTING WORKSHOP MATERIALS NEEDED:

-Stage venue 

-Stage props 

-Camera and TV equipment 

-Improv acting and character development materials 

-Certificate documents to reward actors who complete the workshop New 

  Enrollment  for Beginner actors. 

-Invites of local Florida artists to share their experiences with other actors about 

 working  in the entertainment industry.

"PASSION" IS THE HEART FOR ACTING

I believe that “passion” is the heart for acting, and my passion to

 present an excellent acting workshop will motivate and ignite the passion in 

others to be a positive vessel in the entertainment industry.

The unique challenges that I may face is searching for the proper venue

and scheduling  a time that does not conflict with other events.

RISK AND CHALLENGES.

I will overcome the challenges simply by being consistent on researching

on areas to present the workshops at the  right venue to

accommodate those who will attend, and scheduling it on a days where

people are available to partake in the event. Other challenges I may face is

possessing the adequate equipment that will not only make the event successful

but affective as well.
