story:
RealSpace Brings hit show Dine Her to Niagara Falls for a limited run

RealSpace Theatre's  mandate is to push the boundaries of traditional theatre by exploring environmental integration and offering the audience an engaging performance. In partnering with local communities via non-traditional venues, RealSpace Theatre offers a customized, one-of-a-kind experience that reinterprets the audience’s relationship to those environments. 
In addition to integrating the venue with the storyline and the show itself with the host community, RealSpace Theatre is renowned for its commitment to mentoring. Dine Her has provided actors as young as eight years old with an opportunity to be directed, choreographed and perform. In its last production, their 16 year old assistant stage manager learned the ropes by working alongside a veteran stage manager.






Why is Dine Her important to us?

This show has been embraced by audiences (and diner owners) in each short run, in each city we've produced it; people love this new theatre experience - one that is unique and fun and where they are part of the action. We think there is an exciting opportunity to bring Dine Her to a broader audience - to engage more people in something interactive..something that changes the way we look at spaces we live, work and play in,  something that ties communities and businesses together - in Niagara Falls in the summer of 2015.

To promote Dine Her as widely as possible - to share the show with as many people as possible - we need your help. 

Contributors will help get the word out to audiences of all ages, all walks of life, who are looking for an entertainment experience that is both loads of fun and thought provoking; more people will engage with art, ideas and others in a singularly special evening out.  

What Dine Her is

Dine Her is love story gone awry. Imagine waiting for your boyfriend for over an hour and a half, only to be dished out a ridiculous story about a zombie invasion. Audiences of Dine Her sit alongside Tim & Liz as they sort out their relationship and the weird and wonderful situations that ensue. Warning: there is a great deal of comedy. You will laugh A LOT.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $8,000 to make sure we can tell audiences - locals, tourists, individuals, businesses - on both sides of the border - that this unique experience is happening. From there we hope the word will spread like a good zombie virus.
 Jory Bice design zombie tee shirt

The Impact

There is a change afoot in how people spend their time and how they engage with art and culture. As a contributor you will be on the cutting edge of something that responds to the current needs of audiences and how they want to engage with performance and with different environments/spaces around them. We've accomplished four successful short runs in two cities. This scale is a larger step up. One we believe in, but one we need some help achieving.

Who we are 

Bruce Hunter (Artistic Director, Writer & Performer): Bruce has been associated with the local improv scene for more than 30 years, most notably as a teacher with The Second City and performer with veteran comedy troupe, Illustrated Men. His movie work includes parts in Goodwill Hunting, Mean Girls and Canadian Bacon. His spectrum of work – as performer and as director – has won numerous awards, including Best of the Fringe in 2010 for his direction of A Freudian Slip of the Jung; two Canadian Comedy Awards for improvisation and a Gemini for his voice work on Atomic Betty. 

Erica Wood/May (Artistic Associate/Co-Producer, & Performer): Erica trained at LAMDA in the U.K. and has performed on stages across Ontario in such shows as The Importance of Being Earnest (Gryphon Theatre); Godspell (The Stage Co.); Beauty and the Beast (Playbill Theatre) and Brighton Beach Memoirs (Variety). She has appeared on radio, television and in independent films. When not performing, Erica teaches drama and facilitates creative workshops.


To order tickets online please click on the link:
http://www.eventbrite.ca/e/dine-her-niagara-falls-tickets-16539185148
story_txt:
RealSpace Brings hit show Dine Her to Niagara Falls for a limited run

RealSpace Theatre's  mandate is to push the boundaries of traditional theatre by exploring environmental integration and offering the audience an engaging performance. In partnering with local communities via non-traditional venues, RealSpace Theatre offers a customized, one-of-a-kind experience that reinterprets the audience’s relationship to those environments. In addition to integrating the   venue with the storyline and the show itself with the host community,   RealSpace Theatre is renowned for its commitment to mentoring. Dine Her   has provided   actors as young as eight years old with an opportunity to be directed,   choreographed and perform. In its last production, their   16 year old assistant stage manager learned   the ropes by   working alongside   a veteran stage   manager.



Why is Dine Her important to us?

This show has been embraced by audiences (and diner owners) in each short run, in each city we've produced it; people love this new theatre experience - one that is unique and fun and where they are part of the action. We think there is an exciting opportunity to bring Dine Her to a broader audience - to engage more people in something interactive..something that changes the way we look at spaces we live, work and play in,  something that ties communities and businesses together - in Niagara Falls in the summer of 2015. 
To promote Dine Her as widely as possible - to share the show with as many people as possible - we need your help. 
Contributors will help get the word out to audiences of all ages, all walks of life, who are looking for an entertainment experience that is both loads of fun and thought provoking; more people will engage with art, ideas and others in a singularly special evening out.  What Dine Her isDine Her is love story gone awry. Imagine waiting for your boyfriend for over an hour and a half, only to be dished out a ridiculous story about a zombie invasion. Audiences of Dine Her sit alongside Tim & Liz as they sort out their relationship and the weird and wonderful situations that ensue. Warning: there is a great deal of comedy. You will laugh A LOT.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $8,000 to make sure we can tell audiences - locals, tourists, individuals, businesses - on both sides of the border - that this unique experience is happening. From there we hope the word will spread like a good zombie virus.
 Jory Bice design zombie tee shirtThe ImpactThere     is a change afoot in how people spend their time and how they engage with     art and culture. As a contributor you will be on the cutting edge of     something that responds to the current needs of audiences and how they     want to engage with performance and with different environments/spaces     around them. We've     accomplished four successful short runs in two cities. This scale is a     larger step up. One we believe in, but one we need some help achieving.Who we are 


Bruce Hunter (Artistic Director, Writer & Performer): Bruce has been associated with the local improv scene for more than 30 years, most notably as a teacher with The Second City and performer with veteran comedy troupe, Illustrated Men. His movie work includes parts in Goodwill Hunting, Mean Girls and Canadian Bacon. His spectrum of work – as performer and as director – has won numerous awards, including Best of the Fringe in 2010 for his direction of A Freudian Slip of the Jung; two Canadian Comedy Awards for improvisation and a Gemini for his voice work on Atomic Betty. 


Erica Wood/May (Artistic Associate/Co-Producer, & Performer): Erica trained at LAMDA in the U.K. and has performed on stages across Ontario in such shows as The Importance of Being Earnest (Gryphon Theatre); Godspell (The Stage Co.); Beauty and the Beast (Playbill Theatre) and Brighton Beach Memoirs (Variety). She has appeared on radio, television and in independent films. When not performing, Erica teaches drama and facilitates creative workshops.





To order tickets online please click on the link:
http://www.eventbrite.ca/e/dine-her-niagara-falls-tickets-16539185148

story:
Bal Malhada is a group of ten dancers aiming to spread the Gospel through dance. We will be travelling to South Korea for four weeks this May and using the platform of dance to provide a message of encouragement, hope and healing to our audience. We will be performing in churches, nursing homes, schools, orphanages, and other venues in Korea to share our message.

What We Need

Through this campaign, we're asking for $20,000 -- half the cost of the trip. We're averaging total expenses for each individual to be $4,200. This is going toward travel (flight, van rentals, gas, and subway tickets), lodging, food, and other items such as costumes, medical supplies, and gifts for hosts and children at orphanages.

The Impact

During this purposeful trip, Bal Malhada will have a variety of occasions to share our gifts and talents as Christian artists. We are confident God will use our offerings to impart His love through our ministry, performances, workshop teachings and discussions with audiences, congregations and fellow dancers. 

Our impact will be to encourage the Korean Christian Church as well as share the gospel through dance in various settings including public and private schools (K-12) and with university students.

During last year’s tour the ensemble performed live in 13 cities, at 33 venues and in front of over three thousand individuals. Two of the large events were televised where thousands of others were touched by work of the ensemble. We anticipate reaching and serving this amount of individuals again this year.

One of the most outstanding events of our trip last year was an opportunity to perform at the Busan International Dance Festival where we were able to share the stage with other professional dance companies from around the world. One of the most humbling  experiences was when we were blessed to perform for terminally ill patients at a hospital, knowing we would be the last dance presentation they would ever see. This event concluded with our group moving out into the audience, dancing over and praying with each precious soul. 

Past and Present Repertoire Performed in Korea




(see the gallery for more)

Current Challenge

A challenge we face at this time is that of finances. We've raised nearly half of the needed funds for our trip and ask that you partner with us for the remainder. As this is our third return trip, Bal Malhada believes our track record shows our impact in South Korea has been successful and we are grateful for this opportunity to again serve those with whom we come in contact.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us in prayer! The choreography is set, rehearsals are under way, bookings are nearly complete for a full schedule, and people eagerly await us. Please pray for the remainder of our preparations as we follow God's call to use our gifts of dance and our love, care, and compassion to engage and inspire.

story:
Hi All!

As the choreographer of the Lyrric Cosby Jackson Dance Project, founded in 2014, I am elated to announce the world premier of a new experimental work entitled Waking Pressure. I invite you to become a part of the process and join in the conversation around human interaction and understanding.

The Lyrric Cosby Jackson Dance Project is committed to the art of dance, anthropological study, and the connection it has to current social issues.  Through interdisciplinary collaborations and research the LCJ Dance Project’s choreography seeks to unveil social issues and champion human rights around the world.

LCJ will be presenting its inaugural dance work at the Atlanta Fringe Festival from June 4-7, 2015 at 7 Stages Theatre, MainStage. The LCJ Dance project submitted an application for consideration to the festival and was accepted among 19 other artists. The project began rehearsals in February and has been pushing towards opening day ever since. 

A percentage of the ticket sales revenue from the show will be donated to City of Joy a project of the Panzi Foundation (DRC) and V-Day.  The funds donated to City of Joy will provide relief to women in conflict and disaster zones in the Democratic Republic of Congo. 

Your support is essential to the success of the performance and I hope the LCJ Dance Project in the fight for social reform through dance.

Thank you for your support and I hope to see you at the show! 

Lyrric Cosby Jackson


Learn about Waking Pressure: http://lcjdanceproject.com

Show Dates and Times:

Thursday, June 4, 2015- 8 p.m.

Friday, June 5, 2015- 9:30 p.m.

Saturday, June 6, 2015-  6:30 p.m.

Sunday, June 7, 2015- 5 p.m.

7 Stages Theatre- Mainstage

1105 Euclid Ave. Atlanta, GA 30307


How will your contribution help?

The budget for “Waking Pressure” is very small but will make a large impact on the overall cause for the performance.

$ 1600- Performer Compensation

$ 400- Production Team

$ 200- Costuming

$ 200- Documenting the Performance


Meet the Team:

Paul Maga- Marketing Assistant/Webmaster

Jordan Robinson- Fundraising Assistant

Keeyen Martin- Music Consultant

Keenan Carver- Photographer/Videographer

Raheem Pounds-Visual Artist


Performers:

Bianca Griffin- Dancer

Jackson Hayes- Dancer

Michaela Johnson- Dancer

story:
On Impulse! . . . it started out as an experiment and then . . . IT GREW!!

When Emmy-Nominated Producer/Director and teacher Pamela Peak was asked, five years ago, to take a room full of every-day business folks, who had always longed to act since they were little kids, and turn them into fabulous actors that Disney's animation department would find "improvisational and free", no one knew  that they were about to bond like a family and become one of the most well thought of acting troupes in Orange County, California known as On Impulse!

Be sure to see the memorable video clips of several On Impulse performances at the bottom of this page.

FIRST, THESE ACTORS ALL GOT THEMSELVES HIGHLY TRAINED!!!

The actors all got themselves trained fully in the brilliant acting technique of the great Sandford Meisner (Teacher to Robert Duval, Sandra Bullock, Steve McQueen and so many more).

Now, the highly skilled On Impulse actors are known to touch their audiences deeply—to make them laugh, cry and sit on the very edge of their seat . . . all in one incredible live theater performance!

They dedicate themselves, in each performance, to taking their audiences on an emotional journey, using real emotions—an exciting journey their audiences will never forget.

A HOMELESS TROUPE?

Being a "Homeless troupe", On Impulse loved their art so much that they've dug deep into their own pockets, year after year, in order get their theater company started.

Not having a theater to perform in, On Impulse has played in just about every venue you can think of—from Historical Parks to funky saloon-like barrooms, spooky old Victorian Houses to gorgeous Orange County beachfront mansions. And they tailor-made their performances for whatever venue they played in.

BUT they have always longed simply to play in an actual theater!

NOW . . . A TEMPORARY HOME!!

Now, On Impulse has been given a short-term "temporary home" at the historic Cabrillo Playhouse in San Clemente, California and . . . they have BIG THINGS PLANNED!

THREE FABULOUS PLAYS in Just
Two Months

On Impulse has been very busy preparing to put on the three major productions described below in just two months of performances.

See this link for dates and ticket information: 2015 On Impluse Season.

SIMPLY SIMON

NEIL SIMON'S BEST COMEDY SCENES!

May 15, 16, 17 & July 10, 11, 12

SWEET BIRD OF YOUTH

BY TENNESSEE WILLIAMS

July 17, 18, 19 and July 24, 25, 26

A FEW GOOD MEN

BY AARON SORKIN

July 31, Aug. 1 & 2 - Aug. 7 & 8 - Aug. 14, 15, 16

And in late 2015 and early 2016, in between The Cabrillo Playhouse's regular seasons, are still two more On Impulse productions:

  • A RAISIN IN THE SUN
  • ON GOLDEN POND

Please Help On Impulse Fund Their 2015/16 Season

Your money will go to things like:

  • Costumes
  • Lighting and sound crew
  • Props
  • Scenery
  • The performance rights to all their plays
  • Rehearsal space, and 
  • An advertising campaign fitting for the quality of work these actors are doing

Their work will be seen by a much wider audience!

  • Without your help, we have no season.
  • With your help, hundreds of people will gain an incredible live theater experience.
  • Please help keep quality LIVE theater alive! Please support On Impulse.

And please know that the actors of On Impulse will be eternally grateful for any help you can give them.

☺THANK YOU! From the bottom of our hearts!☺


What We Need & What You Get

The On Impulse Acting Troupe needs $28,678 to fund their entire 2015/16 season.

Here is how it all breaks down:

The Impact of Your Contribution

A Message From Producer/Director Pamela Peak

My Meisner Acting Teacher once told us:

"If an actor works from the truth of himself, audiences will remember that truthful moment on stage and take that moment to their graves . . . even if they are sitting in the back row of the balcony. It is a profound experience."

The actors of On Impulse dedicate themselves to creating those kind of moments on stage. If they can shine a light on the "human experience" then they know they have done their jobs.

ON IMPULSE truly deserves to be seen by the people of Orange County who appreciate work of this quality. This year we are inviting corporate sponsors to our performances who can help On Impulse grow well into the future.

Your contribution will help fund the season that is our "springboard". THAT is the kind of impact even a small contribution can make.

Help Us Make It Happen

We are a determined group that has reached every goal we have set for ourselves thus far.

Our work is ready . . . our audiences are ready . . . our name is becoming known . . . we have a well-thought-out promotional campaign, that reaches out far and wide.

We simply need your help to make this happen.

Won't you please take a moment to contribute to this cause THEN SPREAD THE WORD?

Other Ways You Can Help

Please link friends and family to our promotional video. Pass the word along. Every action is so appreciated.

If you love great theater and you love great art . . . then JOIN US!


We Have Some Great Special Edition On Impulse Perks (below and to the right)

Spooky Halloween Party!

Would you like to throw the spookiest Halloween party ever? Then invite the On Impulse Actors to "return from the grave" at your Halloween Party to perform their fantastic show: "The Souls of Spoon River Return!" See the details in our Perk sections . . . and brace yourself for one FABULOUS, SPOOKY SHOW your guests will never forget!

Have THE GRINCH Host Your Christmas Party!

Put more Christmas in your Private or Corporate Christmas Party this year! Invite THE GRINCH and his WONDERFUL CAST OF CHARACTERS to join you! (See details in our Perk section to the right.) 

This fun show will bring your Holiday guests more Christmas cheer than they know what to do with!!!

Leif Settergren as "The Grinch"

Actors Tamika Bush-Craig, Nathan Elekes, Leif Settergren and Lynette Johnson in a performance of The Grinch!

Gallery of Some of Our Past Work

From Get Low, Actor Leif Settergren gives his "final dying confession":


Actors Ron Arentz (as George), Erik Leeming (as Carlson) and Greg Doyle (as Candy appear in John Steinbeck's Of Mice and Men:


Actors Sarah Joslin (as Curly's Wife) and Mike Bryant (as Lennie) appear in Of Mice and Men:


Actor's Ron Arentz (as George) and Mike Bryant (as Lennie) appear in the moving final scene of Of Mice and Men:

story:
Want to be a Producer of a West End show?! Keen? Well here is how you can do it!

What are we doing?

Roar Edge Productions are thrilled to announce their ‘potty-mouthed’ musical parody Bedding Belle. Bedding Belle tells the story of six teenagers, with six-teen problems, taking you on journeys of unrequited love, lust, and Disney- not so magic- happily ever after’s. With a trip back down memory lane, where Prince Charming was covered in acne, and lets face it you weren’t so charming, Bedding Belle revisits your awkward school days, that you hoped you could keep forgotten.

Roar Edge Productions are proud to announce Direction by Joel Montague and Musical Direction by Mark Crossland, with a vibrant cast put together by Glenn Gaunt, comprising of Olivier Award winner Leanne Jones (Hairspray, The Voice), Michelle Pentacost (Evita, Wicked), Gemma Knight Jones (The Lion King, Sister Act), and West End heart throbs James Alexander Gibbs, (Mamma Mia, Tommy), Brian Gilligan (The Commitments), and introducing Maisey Bawden and Rhoda Dell.

With book by R. Dell, lyrics by Jacqueline Ozorio.  R.Dell and Benjamin Summer’s concept of Bedding Belle is due to hit the stage, for one night only, on Monday 22nd June 2015, for a closed performance at The London Hippodrome, Leicester Square.

Who are we?

Roar Edge Productions was founded in 2014 by Rhoda Dell and Ben Summers after they graduated from the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. Soon after establishing the Company, Joel Montague and Glenn Gaunt joined the team to create our first musical, Bedding Belle, and here on the team at Roar Edge Productions we believe in collaborating everyone's passions to create truly dynamic theatre.

Why?

Why is Bedding Belle going on at The Hippodrome for one night? Bedding Belle has been developed and workshopped for over 18 months now, and we felt it was time to put it up on it's feet, in front of an audience, to get feedback. This performance will give us the chance to see how to develop the project further.

What we need

We are currently sourcing funding for our rehearsal space, props and costs for the venue.

The Impact

Your generous contributions will enable us to create a strong show for June and proceed into the next phase of our development swiftly after.

Other ways you can help

If you really like the sound of our project and are unable to donate, but are keen to support, we would love it if you could share out campaign via your facebook and twitter accounts, and use the indiegogo share tools. You can stay in the loop of our progress, by subscribing to our newsletter at: http://www.roaredgeproductions.co.uk/contact/ and follow us on facebook: Roar Edge Productions and twitter: @roaredge @bedding_belle

Thank you for your help and we hope to see you in person at the show.

From the Team at Roar Edge.

www.roaredgeproductions.co.uk

Well here is how you can do it!What are we doing?Roar Edge Productions are thrilled to announce their ‘potty-mouthed’ musical parody Bedding Belle. Bedding Belle tells the story of six teenagers, with six-teen problems, taking you on journeys of unrequited love, lust, and Disney- not so magic- happily ever after’s. With a trip back down memory lane, where Prince Charming was covered in acne, and lets face it you weren’t so charming, Bedding Belle revisits your awkward school days, that you hoped you could keep forgotten.Roar Edge Productions are proud to announce Direction by Joel Montague and Musical Direction by Mark Crossland, with a vibrant cast put together by Glenn Gaunt, comprising of Olivier Award winner Leanne Jones (Hairspray, The Voice), Michelle Pentacost (Evita, Wicked), Gemma Knight Jones (The Lion King, Sister Act), and West End heart throbs James Alexander Gibbs, (Mamma Mia, Tommy), Brian Gilligan (The Commitments), and introducing Maisey Bawden and Rhoda Dell.With book by R. Dell, lyrics by Jacqueline Ozorio.  R.Dell and Benjamin Summer’s concept of Bedding Belle is due to hit the stage, for one night only, on Monday 22nd June 2015, for a closed performance at The London Hippodrome, Leicester Square.Who are we?Roar Edge Productions was founded in 2014 by Rhoda Dell and Ben Summers after they graduated from the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. Soon after establishing the Company, Joel Montague and Glenn Gaunt joined the team to create our first musical, Bedding Belle, and here on the team at Roar Edge Productions we believe in collaborating everyone's passions to create truly dynamic theatre.Why?Why is Bedding Belle going on at The Hippodrome for one night? Bedding Belle has been developed and workshopped for over 18 months now, and we felt it was time to put it up on it's feet, in front of an audience, to get feedback. This performance will give us the chance to see how to develop the project further.What we needWe are currently sourcing funding for our rehearsal space, props and costs for the venue.The ImpactYour generous contributions will enable us to create a strong show for June and proceed into the next phase of our development swiftly after.Other ways you can helpIf you really like the sound of our project and are unable to donate, but are keen to support, we would love it if you could share out campaign via your facebook and twitter accounts, and use the indiegogo share tools. You can stay in the loop of our progress, by subscribing to our newsletter at: http://www.roaredgeproductions.co.uk/contact/ and follow us on facebook: Roar Edge Productions and twitter: @roaredge @bedding_belleThank you for your help and we hope to see you in person at the show.From the Team at Roar Edge.www.roaredgeproductions.co.uk

story:
ABOUT THE SHOW

Scheherazade is no longer a Queen staving off execution by her cruel husband but a woman condemned to death by the criminal justice system.

1001 Nights: Love Stories on Death Row (A Rock Ballet) is a feast for all five senses featuring stories from the Middle East, North Africa, India, China and Greece and an original musical score consisting of Hip Hop, Rock and World Music.

We will explore what it means to be the "minority" in terms of ethnicity, religion, sex and sexual orientation within Western and Eastern cultures and take a critical look at the American prison-industrial complex. 

The work has been picked up by renowned, downtown theatres in NYC such as Dixon Place and Theatre for the New City for Spring/Summer 2015. The work has also been honored with a residency at the Jamaica Performing Arts Center. During our residency we will further develop the production and continue to fulfill our collective’s mission statement by offering free (donation optional) dance classes, open rehearsals, outdoor performances and a workshop in community building.

ABOUT THE COLLECTIVE

Formed in March 2011, The Kandake Dance Theatre for Social Change combines social activism and philanthropy with folkloric, modern, theatrical and experimental movement. The collective embraces talented performers of various ethnicities, religious (or non-religious) backgrounds, sexual orientations and gender identities. The Kandake stays active in the community by hosting free and "no one turned away for lack of funds" shows, street art and workshops.

WHY WE NEED YOU!

1. We Need To Pay Our Performers!: While we're honored to have the chance to work in such well-respected venues, sadly each only offers a very modest stipend with which we cannot realistically pay all our performers. First and foremost we want to make sure the performers are compensated well for their time, energy and heart. Helping us reach or exceed our fundraising goal will ensure this (and you'll get cool prizes too!)

2. The Other Stuff: We will have a few new performers and acts in the new incarnations of the show. Therefore tailoring and creating new costuming will be necessary. We also have some beautiful new post cards (which we will be revealing gradually here!) that have to be printed. Last --but definitely not least-- we want to make sure our audiences are well taken care of at our outdoor events, workshops and etc. This means providing yummy and healthy refreshments! Helping us reach or exceed our goal will make it all possible and some!

SO ARE WE REALLY MAKING A BETTER WORLD OR WHAT?

Our ultimate goal as a dance theatre for social change is to bring about a more compassionate, just and healthy society by exposing diverse communities to the healing and inspiring power of arts and culture. A huge part of this is creating spaces for discussion, sharing, learning, creativity, inspiration and fun among many different people.

Systemic injustices, including but not limited to those within the criminal justice system, hit close to home every day. The larger artistic work calls attention to these injustices while the accompanying community engagement projects provide a tangible approach to addressing it.

Awareness can lead to more harmonious communities locally and internationally but it is nothing without action and change from the inside of an individual or community outward. We aim to pay it forward.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Ok, maybe you can't give us piles of dough but please remember every penny counts! However, there are other ways you can help:

1. Spread The Word!: Share our fundraising link with your friends and be sure to make it to a show! Current show dates are online www.TheKandake.com!

2. Volunteer To Be A Stage Crew Member: Help out backstage with wardrobe, make up, assisting at rehearsals or otherwise being useful!

3. Become A Server Genie: We love unique ways to play with our audiences. Let us dress you up and go out and grant wishes!

4. Come To An Event!: We love offering great classes, parties and performances for our friends, family and community. Visit www.TheKandake.com for details!

story:
Hi everyone!

We have a large theatre scene here in brisbane, ranging from dance to plays, we would like to open a themed bar. We will do events on Friday and Saturday nights that change each week and will consist of dance and plays, some of which will be adult entertainment as there is a very large call for that also. We will also have a VIP membership available for those that wish to become members. Members will get cheaper drinks and cheaper cover charges to get in. Also members will be invited to member only nights and access to equipment and other things at a cheaper rate.

We will be requiring a fair few staff for this business which will open job opportunities and being that we will be the only one in brisbane to have a themed bar like ours, it will be a definite success!

Let me tell you about myself,

My name is Luke, I am 28, I was a chef for 2 years when i finished school. I enjoyed the hospitality industry but being 19 I wanted a social life and the split shit 7 days was not ideal.

I moved onto do I.T for 8 years as I am a huge technology fiend. After 4 years I was a little more mature and wanted to get back into hospitality but without redoing my apprenticeship I couldn't get a job as a chef. I thought about how I could get back into the industry and i happen upon a site offering free security courses which would allow me to work in pubs clubs and other areas where hospitality was being done.

I focused on security once I was made redundant at my I.T job. 6 years in security and it has not helped me get back into hospitality so in that time I have been planning for a few years now to have my own business where I can give other like minded people a fair go in hospitality, credentials or not.

I have almost finished a Diploma in Business and currently have a Cert IV in Business Management, I will have completed by the time this project is at the goal the Responsible Management of a Licenced Venue course, I have an Responsible Service of Alcohol and Responsible Service of Gaming certificates, I have experience in Security but i have not worked behind a bar so i am planning to do a bartending short course to learn quickly how to tend a bar and so I am almost ready to start i just need your help to make my dream happen!

story:
Everyone remembers the brutal story of what happened on a bus in Delhi in 2012. A woman’s life was destroyed. I was disturbed for months. I couldn’t understand how one human being could do that to another human being. Where was the respect?


The incident sparked in me a personal desire to effect a social transformation; one that saw people honouring and respecting each other because if you honoured and respected another human being, why would you hurt them? What better way to do this than through dance :) 

Part one of my campaign is to launch 'Dance for Transformation,' a campaign to unite India through dance to end sexual violence. There will be more details on this on a separate page.

Part two, is to raise £5000 for Kolkata Sanved, an innovate Non-Governmental Organisation that uses Dance Movement Therapy (DMT) as an alternative approach to counselling and psychosocial rehabilitation. Their ground-breaking programmes empower survivors of trafficking and violence release trauma, develop confidence and identify their own potentials as human beings rather than as victims. 

I love dance and I love how Kolkata Sanved uses dance to empower women. In the last 10 years, Kolkata Sanved has impacted upon 7000 survivors directly and reached out to 188199 individuals globally. What's special about them is the fact that their core employees, have experienced the healing and empowerment programme first hand as participants. 

Your contribution will help:

  • Promote Dance Movement Therapy in the vulnerable community who are facing violence, abuse and exploitation.
  • Capacity building of Dance Movement Therapy Practitioners

Here's what the £5,000 will contribute to:

1)  Rent of Dance Studio (35% of funds)

2)  Travel Cost for DMT Practitioners (25% of funds)

3)  Dance exchange programme and capacity building of practitioners (5% of funds)

4)  Salary of 2 DMT Practitioners (30%)

5)  Admin and Overhead cost (4%)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love what Kolkata Sanved are up to and want to help in other ways, then please share this campaign with your friends, family and wider community!

For more information on Kolkata Sanved please visit their website www.kolkatasanved.org

story:
Website

http://bottledupnyc.com/

Summary

For our first show in New York, we are producing two original one-act narrative plays that are performed in a completely immersive and interactive theater space at DCTV in Tribeca.
The first act, Jack, is a story about a boy who has locked himself in a box and no-one really knows why. Every family member and friend comes to the box to confess something they know about him or something that they have done that they believe has driven him in the box. Things get more frantic as days turn into nights and Jack is still in the box and lead to a collision of family and friends that leave Jack changed forever.
Act 2 is about a young housewife who, P.S., deals drugs on the side. She is troubled by the potential loss of the PTA and, oh right, she accidentally killed three kids in the neighborhood with a bad batch. With her dreams, which are written by a hollywood production team, fighting to push her to assert herself with the PTA, things head to an explosive, hilarious, and unexpected finish.
The night will be an experience rather than just a performance, where the guests get buzzed on whiskey and wine with the characters as they peruse around a storybook 1950's southern setting which they then follow into a foggy dreamscape. Guests will have 45 minutes to peruse the space, look at the character's personal effects and enjoy cocktails (with the purchase of the Complementary Open Bar) 'Bottled Up' is a show where narrative meets experimental--and with an open bar full of aged liquor. The two shows are short dark comedies and in between the two acts there will be music, drinking, dancing, and a drastic change of scenery.

Our company, PeachPie Productions is our company that started in San Francisco in 2012. We've taken our show on the road and  We want to seek out new plays in  and theatre concepts in New York City to develop innovative, experiential performances. Our work will often involve modern and contemporary dance, improvisation and experimental-meets-narrative material. Our first show tries to do just that and establish our company as a home for innovative and unique storytelling. 

Location:

DCTV TriBeCa, 1st floor
87 Lafayette Street
New York, NY 10013

Dates:

May 29th, 30th, 31st
June 5th, 6th and 7th

Check below for the link to tickets and times!


What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking 7,000 Dollars to help us start our company off and produce our first show! This will offset the 600 dollars for costumes, 1000 for lighting, 150 for sound, 400 for sets, 500 for a dance floor, 500 for rehearsal spaces, 400 for props, 1000 for actor stipends and 4000 for space rental,

Check out the donation levels on the right for some of the fantastic perks that we'd like to give to those who donate to our fund!


The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • We want to show a less staid and less film-influenced side of theater.
  • So much of theater's uniqueness comes from it's ability to reach it's audience directly. Our shows are going to do that, by providing the audience a chance to be immersed in a story and be able to feel, smell and explore another world.
  • PeachPie has done one show in San Francisco and it sold out the entire weekend at the Joe Goode Annex theater in the Mission District. The show raised several thousand 
  • We need help to maintain the quality of this show and future shows. We forsee a lean, forward thinking, new work theater that brings a needed dimension to narrative storytelling in New York City.

Risks & Challenges

We are sure we will face more challenges.  Any live theater is risky, as we have to get people to not only come, but also spread the word friend to friend. If we can't get butts in seats we could be in a lot of trouble. It's also always risky when we can't pay our actors more than a stipend, which means that when they book paying work we have to let them pursue their career.

  • However, we have many people in the show who are all pulling to get friends, family and strangers to come see their amazing work
  • Our actors, designers and friends are all helping to get the word out to make this play a success.
  • We've also had a couple actors leave, but the beauty of New York, is that someone is always looking for a new opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot share financially, we need help with other things as well!

  • We need help building sets, costuming, propping, selling tickets and ushering!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • http://bottledup.brownpapertickets.com to directly buy tickets

story:
(English will follow)

Le Projet Chevelu est une réflexion dansée, inspirée de la relation à la fois profonde et superficielle, intime et politique, que nous entretenons avec nos cheveux.

Nos cheveux parlent. Ils expriment d’où nous venons et trahissent qui nous voulons être. Point de convergence de l’identité personnelle, culturelle, sociale et sexuelle, les cheveux sont, par leur relative facilité de trans­formation, le point de tension entre l’être et le paraître. Au fil de l’histoire, de nombreuses cultures en ont fait la démonstration parfois codifiée et les sociétés africaines se démarquent par l’exubérance et la créativité de leurs créations capillaires, qualités qu’elles ont léguées à leurs descendants d’aujourd’hui, qu’ils soient en Afrique ou en Amérique. De part leur insubordination tant à la gravité qu’aux critères de beauté euro-américains, les cheveux des femmes noires ont souvent pris la forme d’un monstre insoumis dont les racines plongent profondément dans l’inconscient personnel et collectif.

Les cheveux des femmes recèlent parfois un monde caché de dou­leur, de honte et d’envie et le cheminement vers l’acceptation prend alors des allures de quête spirituelle.

Suite à une première phase de création où je me suis dédiée à l’exploration de la gestuelle et du langage chorégraphique, est ressorti une démarche qui, loin de vouloir imposer une certaine lecture ou morale du thème, laisse plutôt apparaître des moments, images et impressions où l’on peut se reconnaître. Forte d’une recherche précise et approfondie, la gestuelle dégage une puissante impression sensorielle et tactile.

Le projet entre maintenant en seconde phase de création et de production où on mettra davantage l’accent sur la dramaturgie, la composition chorégraphique, la trame sonore, les costumes, les accessoires capillaires et l’éclairage en vue de la diffusion. La pièce sera diffusée en grande première du 17 au 19 septembre 2015 au MAI. Votre contribution ira directement aux nombreux artistes de ce projet afin de pouvoir à terme mener ce projet qui me tient à coeur. Merci d’avance!

***

“Le Projet Chevelu” (The Hairy Project) is a danced reflection, inspired by the profound and superficial, intimate and political relationship we experience with our hair.

Our hair speaks. It expresses our origins and betrays who we want to be. Our hair is the merging point of our identity, whether personally, culturally, socially or sexually. Due to how easily one can transform it, our hair symbolizes the tension point between being and appearing. Throughout history, many cultures have developed rituals and traditions over hair that demonstrates its expressive power. African societies especially stand out for the exuberance and creativity of their capillary creations. They have since passed this ingenuity on to their contemporary descendants in Africa and America. Through their noncompliance to both gravity and Euro-American standards of beauty, black women’s hair has often taken on the form of an untamed monster whose roots plunge deeply into the personal and collective unconscious. Women’s hair sometimes conceals a hidden world of pain, shame and envy and the pathway towards acceptance may turn into a spiritual quest.

After a first  phase of creation in which I dedicated myself  to movement exploration and the development of a choreographic language, an approach emerged: allowing moments, images and impressions with which one could identify to arise instead of imposing a specific interpretation of the theme or morality. Based on precise and thorough research, the movements create a powerful sensory and tactile impression.

We are now beginning the second phase of creation and production of the project. We will be working on dramaturgy, choreographic composition, musical score, costumes, hair accessories and lighting. The grand premiere of the show will be from the 17th to the 19th of September 2015 at the MAI, in Montreal. Your contribution will go directly to the many artists involved and will allow us to complete this project which is very close to my heart. Thank you in advance!

***

Chorégraphe : Maria Isabel Rondon

Interprètes : Myriam Farger, Fedora Mathieu et Sophia Gaspard

Conseillère artistique : Sophie Michaud

Artiste capillaire : Anta Niang

Compositeur musique : Javier Asencio

Conceptrice d'éclairages : Audrey-Anne Bouchard

Conception costumes : Maria Isabel Rondon

Photographe : Dioni Pereira

Vidéaste : Philippe Boissier

Graphisme : Atelier Atoca
story_txt:
(English will follow)Le
Projet Chevelu est une réflexion dansée, inspirée de la relation à la fois
profonde et superficielle, intime et politique, que nous entretenons avec nos
cheveux. 

Nos cheveux parlent.
Ils expriment d’où nous venons et trahissent qui nous voulons être. Point de
convergence de l’identité personnelle, culturelle, sociale et sexuelle, les
cheveux sont, par leur relative facilité de trans­formation, le point de
tension entre l’être et le paraître. Au fil de l’histoire, de
nombreuses cultures en ont fait la démonstration parfois codifiée et les
sociétés africaines se démarquent par l’exubérance et la créativité de leurs
créations capillaires, qualités qu’elles ont léguées à leurs descendants
d’aujourd’hui, qu’ils soient en Afrique ou en Amérique. De part leur
insubordination tant à la gravité qu’aux critères de beauté euro-américains,
les cheveux des femmes noires ont souvent pris la forme d’un monstre insoumis
dont les racines plongent profondément dans l’inconscient personnel et
collectif.
Les cheveux des femmes recèlent parfois un
monde caché de dou­leur, de honte et d’envie et le cheminement vers l’acceptation
prend alors des allures de quête spirituelle. 

Suite à une première phase de création où je me suis dédiée à
l’exploration de la gestuelle et du langage chorégraphique, est ressorti une
démarche qui, loin de vouloir imposer une certaine lecture ou morale du thème,
laisse plutôt apparaître des moments, images et impressions où l’on peut se
reconnaître. Forte d’une recherche précise et approfondie, la gestuelle dégage
une puissante impression sensorielle et tactile.

Le projet entre maintenant en seconde phase
de création et de production où on mettra davantage l’accent sur la
dramaturgie, la composition chorégraphique, la trame sonore, les costumes, les accessoires capillaires et l’éclairage en vue de la
diffusion. La pièce sera diffusée en grande première du 17 au 19 septembre 2015
au MAI. Votre contribution ira directement aux nombreux artistes de ce projet
afin de pouvoir à terme mener ce projet qui me tient à coeur. Merci d’avance!
***“Le Projet Chevelu” (The Hairy
Project) is a danced reflection, inspired by the profound and superficial,
intimate and political relationship we experience with our hair.
Our hair speaks. It expresses our
origins and betrays who we want to be. Our hair is the merging point of our
identity, whether personally, culturally, socially or sexually. Due to how
easily one can transform it, our hair symbolizes the tension point between
being and appearing. Throughout history, many cultures have developed rituals
and traditions over hair that demonstrates its expressive power. African
societies especially stand out for the exuberance and creativity of their
capillary creations. They have since passed this ingenuity on to their
contemporary descendants in Africa and America. Through their noncompliance to
both gravity and Euro-American standards of beauty, black women’s hair has
often taken on the form of an untamed monster whose roots plunge deeply into
the personal and collective unconscious. Women’s hair sometimes conceals a
hidden world of pain, shame and envy and the pathway towards acceptance may
turn into a spiritual quest.After a first  phase of creation in which I
dedicated myself  to movement exploration and the development of a
choreographic language, an approach emerged: allowing moments, images and impressions with which one could identify to arise instead of imposing a specific interpretation of the theme or morality. Based on precise and thorough research, the movements create a powerful
sensory and tactile impression.
We are now beginning the second phase of creation and
production of the project. We will be working on dramaturgy, choreographic
composition, musical score, costumes, hair accessories and lighting. The grand premiere of the show will be
from the 17th to the 19th of September 2015 at the MAI, in Montreal. Your contribution will go directly to the many artists
involved and will allow us to complete this project which is very close to my
heart. Thank you in advance!***


Chorégraphe : Maria Isabel Rondon
Interprètes : Myriam Farger, Fedora Mathieu et Sophia Gaspard
Conseillère
artistique : Sophie Michaud
Artiste
capillaire : Anta Niang
Compositeur
musique : Javier Asencio
Conceptrice d'éclairages : Audrey-Anne Bouchard
Conception
costumes : Maria Isabel Rondon
Photographe : Dioni Pereira
Vidéaste : Philippe Boissier
Graphisme : Atelier Atoca

story:
The 4th Annual Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue is excited to announce the launch of our “Pasties Across the Pacific” Fundraising Campaign via Indiegogo! 


What is Burlesque? 

“BURLESQUE (or burlesk):  a humorous and provocative stage show featuring slapstick humor, comic skits, bawdy songs, striptease acts, and a scantily clad chorus.”

-American Dictionary 

In The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue’s case it’s all that and MORE! The HBF is going by the standard definition of American Burlesque here, but words fail to capture all of the naughty fun we’ve got in store for you! Burlesque is artful striptease, with an emphasis on the TEASE! Our performers pour their hearts and souls into their work, telling stories, making statements and turning everyday situations into delightful opportunities to see things a little differently...and a little less dressed! 


What is the Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue?
"The 4th Annual Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue" is a locally produced event that invites 30+ local, national & international performers to share their artistry in Burlesque, Cabaret & Circus Arts in front of more than 500 audience members! The HBF is immensely popular with our local audience consistently selling out shows since it's inception in 2012. Each HBF event, from shows to classes & workshops; provides a fun, entertaining and engaging way for our attendees to experience some of the finest in burlesque from around the globe, right here in Hawaii! 


When is the Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue?

The 4th Annual Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue will take place on August 30th - September 5th, 2015 at the Honolulu Museum of Art's stunning Doris Duke Theater, and culminate in two incredible Burlesque shows on September 5th & 4th, 2015. In addition to the shows, the HBF will offer a selection of workshops taught by Burlesque Legends as well as visiting and local performers, historical talks, film screenings, panel discussions & more within the festival week!


Our Fundraising Goals:

We'd be honored to have your support & generosity!  The HBF operates on a volunteer basis and we LOVE what we do, but costs are rising and thats why we're asking for your hand in helping The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue uphold it's reputation as Honolulu's most sparking, riveting and hilarious 2-night Burlesque spectacle. 

Your contribution will go towards:

  •  Featured Performer Travel
  • Featured Performer Fees
  • Per Diems
  •  HBF 2015 Merchandise 
  • & More!

This is the very first time the Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue has skinny dipped in the crowdfunding pool and we’ve prepared some great incentives for your support! Not only will you walk away with some amazing HBF swag, but you’ll also get that warm fuzzy feeling inside that only comes from supporting the arts & artists that make Hawaii Nei so unique! We've got a wide range of options (listed below) to support this glittering cause, and are immensely grateful for any and all contributions towards making 2015 another stellar year in Hawaii Burlesque History!


Our HBF 2015 Featured Acts & Lineup 

On that exciting note, we’re over the moon to announce our HBF 2015 Featured Performers: “The Embodiment of Burlesque,” “The Queen of the Quake” & “Miss Exotic World 2003” the world-famous KITTEN DEVILLE & “The Good Bad Girl” & Burlesque Legend SHANNON DOAH! These two beautiful Burlesque Superstars will be LIVE ONSTAGE at the Honolulu Art Museum’s Doris Duke Theatre for TWO NIGHTS ONLY! Kitten Deville & Shannon Doah will also be presenting one-of a-kind opportunities to learn from the best names in burlesque in the form of Workshops, held during the festival week. Help us get them here & ONSTAGE to entertain YOU! 

In addition to our Featured Performers, we're tickled pink to announce our delightful HBF 2015 Visiting & Local Performers:

VISITING PERFORMERS

Layne Fawkes

Ron Dez Vous

Sassy Stiletto

Flower Bel

Jolie Stripes

Coco das Vegas

Midnight Joy

Bourbon and Lace Pinup and Cabaret

Mademoiselle Estelle

Candy Bottom

Scarlett Letter

Kitty Littéur

Riff Bender

Sheila Starr Siani

Auralie Wilde

The Satin Dolls

LOCAL PERFORMERS

Cherry Blossom Cabaret

Kit Kat Club Cabaret

Volary Aerial Burlesque

Shakti Dance Movement & Devi Dance Company

Tita Titsling

Violetta Beretta

ChiChi Roniz

Mabsy

& MORE!


Other Ways You Can Help The HBF:

Sometimes finances are tight, but you can still help the HBF in other super awesome ways:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our HBF 2015 "Pasties Across the Pacific" Fundraising Campaign by using the the Indiegogo share tools (or email, carrier pigeons, snail mail..whatever you like!) 
  • Follow the HBF 2015 on Social Media! Like, Comment, Share & Participate in the Hawaii Burlesque madness! Learn about upcoming HBF events, workshops, fundraisers and MORE! 
  • Sign up to be an HBF Volunteer, Crew Member or Stage Kitten via www.hawaiiburlesquefestival.com 
  • Get in touch with us about Sponsorship opportunities for yourself or your business! We offer an exciting array of possibilities to fit all budgets! 

Before You Say Aloha.....

The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue wishes you a fond Aloha for your generosity and support towards reaching our goals! We're know how "lucky we are to live Hawaii"  and look forward to entertaining you this September!

An extra special thanks to our wonderful HBF Supporters, Benefactors, Audiences, Sponsors, Associates, Volunteers & HBF/Doris Duke Staff  for their outstanding altruism throughout the years. Without your extraordinary contributions the HBF would not continue to thrive and grow. Here’s to an outstanding 4th year & SEE YOU AT THE DORIS!


In Case You Were Wondering...A Little Bit More on The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue:

Since it’s inception 3 years ago, “The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue” has endeavored to foster artistic & cultural exchange while offering our local audiences a rare chance to see new and exciting performers of all kinds from around the world; to encourage movement, body positivity and learning through free and paid workshops taught by experts in the field; and to help to preserve & grow Hawaii’s unique place in the annals of American Stage Performance & Burlesque history.

The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue is an annual event committed to sharing the “Art of the Tease” with our Hawaii audience! Now in our 4th sparking year, the HBF has become a serious platform to showcase our outstanding home-grown Burlesque, Cabaret and Vaudeville performers. “The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue” has also historically offered educational opportunities for kama’aina in the form of film screenings, talks, classes, symposiums and more!

“The Hawaii Burlesque Festival & Revue” is honored to have featured over 50 Hawaii, Pacific Rim, US Mainland and International Burlesque & Cabaret Performers on the Doris Duke Theatre Stage. We’re happily committed to fostering a wonderful exchange of knowledge and friendship with performers around the world, while providing our visitors & audiences alike a unique view into what makes Hawaii no ka oi!

If you'd like more information on the Hawaii Burlesque Festival, please visit:  

www.hawaiiburlesquefestival.com

story:
The Year of the Writer

In 2015-2016, The Shelter will debut three new full length plays all written by Shelter writers faithfully engaging in what The Shelter holds most dear: re-imagining an original work, exploring new avenues of collaboration, or workshopping at Shelter Sunday—our free, weekly workshop for theatrical artists. Night of the Living, Trapper, and The Red Room are not only great examples of the values and work we encourage at The Shelter, but are also the best and the brightest New York theatre has to offer this season. At The Shelter this is The Year of the Writer.

What We Need & What You Get

Shelter Sunday, our weekly developmental workshop, has supported over 300 artists since 2009 and costs just under $5000 annually to sustain. The work from Shelter Sunday gets its first breath in front of an audience via our quarterly series, THE SHELTER PEEP SHOW; the series supports between 80-120 artists per season and costs around $1500 annually to produce. And our three main stage presentations this year will cost a combined $40,000 to produce.

Unfortunately, ticket sales from these productions cover less than fifty percent of our total costs. While we have been applauded for our fiscal responsibility and our ability to operate on a shoestring budget we can’t do it without donors like you.


The Impact

  • Like most not-for profit theatre companies more than fifty percent of our funding comes from generous donors like you. Your donation will make our seventh season possible.
  • All three plays scheduled for production in 2015-2016 tackle topics important to our cultural narrative and discussion: the purpose of marriage, the myth of female hysteria, and restorative justice. Without your donation these plays will not have the life they so readily deserve.
  • Having successfully produced seven seasons of independent theatre in New York City, our all-volunteer staff is capable of stretching every dollar much further than many of our peers.  We have minimal overhead and allocate over 95% of our funds towards the production of theatre.
  • Since 2009, The Shelter has been building a collaborative and constructive environment for the development of artists and theatre. Your donation will ensure that programs like Shelter Sunday and The Shelter Peep Show continue to foster artistic talent and theatrical excellence.


About The Artists

Dave Lankford, Playwright NIGHT OF THE LIVING. Dave Lankford is a founding member of The Shelter, where he often contributes as a writer, director and actor. Dave’s plays have been presented throughout New York, including Nuyorican Poets Cafe and the historic Cherry Lane Theatre. His monologue Tree was recently performed as part of Our War at Arena Stage in Washington, DC—which featured comissioned works by David Lindsay-Abaire and Lynn Nottage. Dave is an alumnus of The American University and T. Schreiber Studio, a member of the Dramatists Guild, and serves as Director of Platform Product at MLB Advanced Media.

Meghan E. Jones, Playwright TRAPPER. Playwright, Meghan E. Jones is a founding member and Co-Artistic Director of The Shelter. She began her acting training at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and, upon graduating, continued her studies at the Terry Schreiber Studio under the mentorship of Terry Schreiber himself. Acting credits include Annie in The Real Thing, Julia in Fefu and Her Friends, and Edna Pontellier in Ugly Rhino’s critically acclaimed original adaptation of the Kate Chopin novel, The Awakening. Meghan is a two-time Irene Ryan nominee and a recipient of The American Theatre Wing Scholarship. In addition to the stage, Meghan can be seen in numerous commercials, short films, and the recent full length feature, Only Fear of Death. As a playwright, her work has been featured on stages throughout New York City. She is a head mentor for The Young Storytellers Foundation, teaching screenplay writing to disadvantaged youth.

Morgan McGuire, Playwright THE RED ROOM. Morgan McGuire, originally from the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, is a Brooklyn based actress and playwright. She received her Bachelor of Fine Arts from Marymount Manhattan College and continued her studies with Terry Schreiber at the Terry Scheiber Studio. Recent acting credits include Cul-de-Sac, Coriolanus, The Last Days of Judas Iscariot. Recent writing includes Sextet (National Black Theatre KSA series) and Triptych (The Shelter).  In addition to theatrical endeavors Morgan is an avid activist 

Jenny Reed, Director TRAPPER. Jenny Reed is a Brooklyn-based theater artist. Her work is in constant pursuit of artistic excellence paired with community inclusion in the arts. Most of her work is collaborative and created with the artists and/or communities she is working with. In that respect she makes theater using both traditional and non-traditional spaces and performers. She has directed and choreographed various theater pieces that have been presented at the University of San Francisco, Fools Fury, Climate Theater, Berkley Reparatory Theater, Elsewhere Collaborative, The Brick Theater, Dance New Amsterdam, and Theater for a New City, Abron Arts Center, Movement Research, and Dixon Place. As a community-based director she has worked in prisons, nursing homes, schools and abroad. Currently she is an artist-in-residence at Fishkill Correctional Facility with Rehabilitation Through the Arts.

Jenny Beth Snyder, Director NIGHT OF THE LIVING and THE RED ROOM. Jenny Beth Snyder is a Tennessee born, NYC based theater director and co-founder of theater company Fresh Ground Pepper. Her Collaboration with True False Theatre on an adaptation of Slaughterhouse Five played to sold out houses in the 2013 Fringe Festival and went on to the Encore Series. She directed new play Man and Coconut written by Jessica Hernandez in a residency with IRT. She braved the polar vortex in the outdoor, immersive cab show Take Me Home as Assistant Director to Meghan Finn in the Incubator Arts Other Forces festival. Through a collaboration with Exquisite Corpse Theater Company she directed new play Anon written by Matthew Minnincino in ECC’s WareArt: Subterra Festival at Here Arts Center. Other past directing credits include, Morgan McGuire’s Triptych (The Shelter), Callan Stout’s America, In Camera! (Fresh Ground Pepper), The Michael Show by Amy Virginia Buchannon (Fresh Gruond Pepper) and Ideal by Ayn Rand at 59 E 59th America’s Off-Broadway Festival in it’s world premiere. Jenny Beth holds a BFA from NYU Tisch School of the arts. She is a member of the Lincoln Center Theater Director’s Lab in 2013.

Michael Kingsbaker, Artistic Director, The Shelter. Michael Kingsbaker has been working professionally in film and theatre since the age of 5.  He’s currently serves as the co-artistic director of The Shelter and moderator of The Shelter Sunday weekly workshop. A member of Academy Award winner Bobby Moresco’s Actor Gym in Los Angeles, The Labyrinth Theatre Company’s 2013 Ensemble Intensive as well as a recent graduate of the two year conservatory at The Maggie Flannigan Studio.  As an actor, Michael has recently worked at The Arvada Center, Curious Theatre, Rising Phoenix, Vertigo, LABrats, The Shelter, Looking Glass, and Spleen.  He was nominated by the Colorado Theatre Guild for Best Actor in a Play for his performance in John Kolvenbach's On an Average Day.  Michael directed The Shelter’s immersive project, Soarward Holiday Party, as well as the sold out original full-length collaborative play Cul-de-Sac at Cherry Lane Theatre.


About The Shelter

The Shelter is more than a theatre company. We are a community. The core of our community is our weekly Shelter Sunday workshop— the creative home to some of theatre’s most exciting writers, directors and actors. Shelter Sunday is a vibrant and galvanizing playground for our artists. It breeds collaborations and creative collisions, and it’s also the epicenter for our play development and production process. Since 2009, Shelter Artists, along with our all-volunteer staff, have created and staged over 100 world premieres.

Currently she is an artist-in-residence at Fishkill Correctional Facility with Rehabilitation Through the Arts.Jenny Beth Snyder, Director NIGHT OF THE LIVING and THE RED ROOM. Jenny Beth Snyder is a Tennessee born, NYC based theater director and 
co-founder of theater company Fresh Ground Pepper. Her Collaboration 
with True False Theatre on an adaptation of Slaughterhouse Five played to sold out houses in the 2013 Fringe Festival and went on to the Encore Series. She directed new play Man and Coconut written by Jessica Hernandez in a residency with IRT. She braved the polar vortex in the outdoor, immersive cab show Take Me Home
 as Assistant Director to Meghan Finn in the Incubator Arts Other Forces
 festival. Through a collaboration with Exquisite Corpse Theater Company
 she directed new play Anon written by Matthew Minnincino in 
ECC’s WareArt: Subterra Festival at Here Arts Center. Other past 
directing credits include, Morgan McGuire’s Triptych (The Shelter), Callan Stout’s America, In Camera! (Fresh Ground Pepper), The Michael Show by Amy Virginia Buchannon (Fresh Gruond Pepper) and Ideal
 by Ayn Rand at 59 E 59th America’s Off-Broadway Festival in it’s world 
premiere. Jenny Beth holds a BFA from NYU Tisch School of the arts. She 
is a member of the Lincoln Center Theater Director’s Lab in 2013.Michael Kingsbaker, Artistic Director, The Shelter. Michael Kingsbaker has been working professionally in film and theatre since the age of 5.  He’s currently serves as the co-artistic director of The Shelter and moderator of The Shelter Sunday weekly workshop. A member of Academy Award winner Bobby Moresco’s Actor Gym in Los Angeles, The Labyrinth Theatre Company’s 2013 Ensemble Intensive as well as a recent graduate of the two year conservatory at The Maggie Flannigan Studio.  As an actor, Michael has recently worked at The Arvada Center, Curious Theatre, Rising Phoenix, Vertigo, LABrats, The Shelter, Looking Glass, and Spleen.  He was nominated by the Colorado Theatre Guild for Best Actor in a Play for his performance in John Kolvenbach's On an Average Day.  Michael directed The Shelter’s immersive project, Soarward Holiday Party, as well as the sold out original full-length collaborative play Cul-de-Sac at Cherry Lane Theatre.
About The Shelter 
The Shelter is more than a theatre company. We are a community. The core
 of our community is our weekly Shelter Sunday workshop— the creative 
home to some of theatre’s most exciting writers, directors and 
actors. Shelter Sunday is a vibrant and galvanizing playground for 
our artists. It breeds collaborations and creative collisions, and it’s 
also the epicenter for our play development and production process. 
Since 2009, Shelter Artists, along with our all-volunteer staff, 
have created and staged over 100 world premieres.

story:
A Note from the Producers: 

Elaine insisted on writing this all herself.  While we realize it may be a detriment to the success of the campaign, we rea--
 

-- Oh, SHUT UP! 

Hello, my name is Elaine Stritch and I'm an alcoholic.  I'm also a diabetic and I don't enjoy wearing pants.  About a year ago, I was approached to do this show where I sing songs and tell stories about my life.  The producers still haven't paid me a dime. 

So. What's next?

After workshopping it and putting in festivals over the course of the last year, our little show is now going to the New York Fringe Festival.  So they said, "Here Elaine, ask people for money yourself, but also here are some things we need money for." 

  • Gin
  • Postcards
  • Marketing costs
  • Gin
  • Props (new wig, extra pantyhose, gin.)
  • Insurance 
  • Miscellaneous items (including, but not limited to Gin)
  • Gin. 
Evidently I drink a lot of gin during the show. 

Is this just a drag show making fun of Elaine Stritch?

Unfortunately not.  It's a real show where I sing and dance and also relive some painful memories from my life.  I cry a little and you laugh a lot.  

Why should I pay you any money? 

"This show has been funded as a labor of love thus far because we believe in it.  We now feel the show has finally gotten to a place where it needs to expand beyond it's current audience. We hope with new financial partners who can help spread the word about this great show, Elaine Stritch: Still Here can continue on." 

That's what the producers asked me to say, but I'm not going to say that.  You should pay me because I'm an 87 year old legend and I don't come cheap!

What do I get out of it? 

What do you mean?! It's like anything in life; you get out of it what you put into it. You can read the perks section for more detail, but they've got me hockin a lot of crap to get you to donate.  Happy to do it, but I am going to complain the whole time.

 

When and Where is the show? 

Spectrum NYC
121 Ludlow St #2
New York, NY 10002

SHOW DATES:

  • Saturday, August 15th – 1:00pm 
  • Monday, August 17th – 9:15pm 
  • Friday, August 21st – 10:30pm 
  • Monday, August 24th – 8:00pm 
  • Saturday, August 29th – 2:45pm 

LINKS:

Official Fringe site: http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=E

Find us on: Twitter • Facebook • Instagram

story:
Short Summary

For many years, Terrapin Theatre Troupe provided a loving home for University of Maryland's many musical theatre lovers, but by 2014 it had all but disappeared...

This year a new group of dedicated and enthusiastic students have taken the reigns with plans to revitalize this vital student group. Unfortunately, we have inherited debts and an empty bank account, preventing us from moving forward.

What We Need & What You Get

There are a few key items that we need to pay for before the start of the Fall semester this fall-

  • From the previous administration, we owe Music Theatre International $300*. This is the licensing company that owns most of the contemporary musicals that we may be interested in producing.
  • In order to secure a space for our fall show (still undecided because of the problem described above), we need to make a $250 insurance payment by the beginning of the semester. Again this is money that we just do not have and since we are not in school yet we cannot use any of our grassroots fundraising efforts that would normally be used to pay for this.
  • We also need funds for costumes, sets and props as we are not sponsored by the theatre department and therefore must provide all of our own resources. 

The Impact

A contribution to this campaign will give a diverse array of passionate students opportunities to engage with the arts. We hope to reach students from different majors and backgrounds who share a common love of music and theatre through various interactive activities including...

  • Full-length student produced shows. UMD only puts on mainstage musicals every few years and many non-theatre-majors do not have the time or opportunity to participate in these productions.
  • Cabarets and showcases where students can gain valuable experience performing in front of an audience in a positive, low-stress environment.
  • Workshops, discussions and social events to help build a community and challenge students intellectually and artistically.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Visit and like our facebook page to keep updated on all of our exciting events- https://www.facebook.com/TerrapinTheatreTroupe
  • If you are a UMD student interested in joining, attend our open meetings- every 3rd Sunday of the month at 5pm in CSPAC (see FB page for more details)
  • Attend our shows! We will be hosting a Cabaret on Friday, October 2nd and our fall show (TBD) on November 20th-22nd in CSPAC.

story:
Donate to SFF2016 and #DoTheFringe!

     Seattle Fringe Festival presents 2 weekends of FRESH, Independent,

           and LOCALLY-SOURCED LIVE THEATRE FEB 25-MAR 5 2016

                                                   Tickets will be $10 each

               SFF features scripted, sketch, improv, burlesque, devised, 

                                  generated, clown, puppetry and more! 

Each show is 30-90 minutes long and allows audiences to easily discover many types of live performance. Our low ticket prices and producing fees keep innovative art accessible to everyone who wants to experience the power of intimate theatre!

18 of the shows are chosen through a random lottery with an additional 3 curated artists. 

Check out shows and showtimes HERE:

 http://seattlefringefestival.org/seattle-fringe-festival-shows-and-showtimes/

                                       Performances will be held at:

Capitol Hill's Annex Theatre + Eclectic Theatre as well as in lower Queen Anne in Theatre Puget Sound's Black Box, Conference Room and Center House venues inside of the Seattle Center Armory.

                              "What Will the Donations Be Used For?"

                                  Tickets are affordable at just $10 each

              +all ticket revenue is returned to the producing artists so

                                        WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT.

2016 Fringe Festival Budget

Expenses: (Committee and Organizers are Unpaid Volunteers)

Administrative, Marketing+ Operating costs - $11,222

Space & Equipment Rental - $13,000

Technical & Production Personnel - $4,500

Contingency - $1,000

Total: $30,722

Income -

Artist Fees (lottery & participation) - $11,850

2014 Festival Income - $8,000

Donated

Space Donation - $3,472 (TPS) - Confirmed

4Culture Sustained Support - $1,200 - Confirmed

City of Seattle Office of Arts & Culture - $1,200 - Pending

Total: $25,722

Need: $5,000


               Can't contribute financially but want to help? We need volunteers!

           Go here and fill out a form: http://seattlefringefestival.org/volunteer/

          Or just share this campaign on your Facebook page and get out the word!

To learn about the 2016 Seattle Fringe Festival shows  go to:

             facebook.com/SeattleFringeFestival or https://twitter.com/SeaFringe

Seattle Fringe Festival is a program of

Theatre Puget Sound www.tpsonline.org

(and Upon Donation You Will Receive an email receipt with TPS tax id for your tax purpose)
