But in order to offset the $4,500 which this reading has cost, all of which has come out of my own pocket, at the urging of friends and colleagues, I have undertaken this crowdfunding campaign through Indiegogo.  Any support you can provide - and no amount is too large or too small - would be greatly appreciated.  Your generosity and support will never be forgotten.

Thanks much, and On With The Show!

story:
Divorced, Beheaded, Died,
Divorced, Beheaded, Survived

“Ladies in Waiting: The Judgement of Henry VIII” finds King Henry VIII in a Purgatory-like situation, where one by one he is confronted by each of his six wives. Through dark humour, devastating truths, and powerful revelations, Henry comes face to face with what his legacy has become. 

A group of international students at East 15 Acting School refused to wait for work to come to them and decided to make their own. Our playwright, James, was inspired after seeing Wolf Hall on Broadway and wanted to write a play where all six wives had as much depth as Wolf Hall’s Anne Boleyn. 

In a community where women have less of a voice, we are thrilled to create a female-driven play, especially one that gives voices to six women who are mostly remembered as a list. 


We have been accepted into the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest arts festival in the world! We are excited to represent our school as well as our home countries, but we can’t do it without your help. 

 Our production has been invited to perform for this entire month-long festival at theSpaceUK, a prime location on the festival’s Royal Mile, but accepting this honour involves a sizable financial commitment.

Where the Money Goes

While each cast member is contributing as many personal funds as possible, below is the breakdown of our basic costs for a successful run:

I. Space Rental: £3672 (~$5240)

II. Programme Registration: £295.20 (~$421)

III. Insurance: £150 (~$214)

IV. Housing: £3100 (~$4,423 for 8 people at the month-long festival)

V. Posters

  1. £160 (~$228) for 6- 10 larger posters 
  2. £120 (~$171) for 60 regular posters and a “bagillion” flyers

VI. Photography: £200 (~$285)

Total :£7,697.20 ≈ $10,900 depending on daily exchange rate

The Impact

You're supporting:

New work and young artists

Women's voices and their vital role in theatre, the arts, and history

Peaceful, international collaboration

Our elaborate trick to get Hilary's ears pierced (read the "Perks") :)

And helping the cast meet their future life partners! (Again, read the "Perks"!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Facebook and Twitter!  Spread the word!  Share our story and campaign with people beyond our circle!  Come see our show!

story:
Hi Patrons of the Arts,

Thank you for arriving on this page and welcome. 

My name is Danielle and I am the Creative Producer and CEO for Danielle Lonnon Productions. In association with  our Lead Producer Aria Entertainment, we are Co-Producing our first West End musical, the European premiere of The Toxic Avenger at the Southwark Playhouse London, from April 22nd 2016. We are very excited and hope to see you there.

http://southwarkplayhouse.co.uk/show/the-toxic-avenger/

That's right! The Toxic Avenger based on the 1984 cult movie of the same name produced by Troma Entertainment. #Tromacool

We are looking for Patrons of the Arts to help us fund Danielle Lonnon Production, touring and logistical expenses - and well, perhaps even a new toxic green dress for me on opening night.

Danielle Lonnon Productions is a new start-up based in Sydney. Prior to this start-up, Danielle has had 20 years of experience working with live performing arts companies and festivals around the world, in arts administration and stage management.

A few examples of these wonderful experiences are:

Australia : Opera Australia, Bangara Dance Company, The Sydney Theatre Company, Sydney Festival.

UK: The Royal Shakespeare Company, Cats - David Ian Productions / Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Group, Assembly @ Edinburgh Fringe.

New Zealand: Christchurch Arts Festival.

So, what do you get for your contribution??

Well, if you are in the UK - the chance to see The Toxic Avenger at the Southwark Playhouse.

If you are not -  you are helping to "raise the curtain" (oh dear!) for Danielle Lonnon Productions, so we can bring a show to a theatre near you.

In the near future, Danielle Lonnon Productions wants to be able to, employ, collaborate or commission you to come and work with us - as you have something we don't; your star quality.

Financial Risk and Spend 

The show's first producing tier has been funded - by us Producers. We have paid for the important big things; like the theatre, the actors, the musicians, the staff,  the rights etc. This is where the high financial risk is.

The  show's second producing tier has not been fully funded yet. This tier takes in production incidentals. They might not be considered important in comparison to a performer, however in truth, they are even more essential to the running of the production. Things for example; like travel, first aid kits and tea and coffee;

I have been in many rehearsal rooms where tea and coffee has run out. The production - I kid you not - grinds to a halt until the situation is rectified. 

If you can contribute and help us, for example make sure there is tea and coffee in the rehearsal room - you will be more of a star than our lead performers.

As you can see, contributing to our second tier, means that there are no financial risk to you. In fact, stardom beckons.

If you are a struggling artist

If you are a struggling artist and you want to help - but cash is a little tight (why do you think we're here?), how about liking the show's Twitter and Facebook Pages?

https://twitter.com/ToxicAvengerUK

https://www.facebook.com/ToxicAvengerUK/

Or come and join our touring theatre photo challenge on Instagram and Facebook?

https://www.instagram.com/touringtheatrephotochallenge/

https://www.facebook.com/touringtheatrephotochallenge/

#TouringTheatrePhotoChallenge


Thank you for playing your role as Patron Of The Arts. For being such a star let's cue your curtain call.


Bravo!

Danielle Lonnon Productions

Like theatre, like never before.

story:
What is KNOCK KNOCK about?

A single mother raises her only son in a place where every child is duty bound to hold a gun one day. KNOCK KNOCK is inspired by real events and peels back the curtain of Middle Eastern politics to tell a story about parenthood, friendship, love and sacrifice.

Writer and performer Niv Petel said: "Experiencing the peaceful life in London made me aware of the extent of death I faced on a daily basis in Israel. Not necessarily as in dead bodies on the streets, but more as the potential of death, which is always present and affects every aspect of the life there. And only by stepping out of it for a while, could I become aware of it."

Using his body and voice Niv weaves a vivid and detailed familial relationship, in this physical solo show, exploring the effects of national service on the relationship between a single mother and her only son in Israel.


About National Service.

Conscription or drafting is the compulsory enlistment of people in a national service most often a military service. Conscription dates back to antiquity and continues in some countries to the present day under various names. In most European nations (inspired by the conscription system of the French Revolution in the 1790s) men at a certain age would serve 1-8 years on active duty and then transfer to the reserve force.

Conscription had been legislated in Israeli law since the establishment of the country in 1948, and it applies on all Israeli citizens who have reached the age of 18. The normal length of compulsory service is currently three years for men and two years for women. 

During the last year of high school, every boy and girl gets a letter from the army, stating they must report to a specific place and time for a day-long assessment and interview process. After careful examination of the results, the army enlists those who have passed to begin their basic training.

If a soldier is badly wounded, or has been abducted or died during their service, a special team of officers from the army (including social workers and doctors) will arrive at the family home to inform them. The army will then maintain connection with the bereaved family for many years, helping the family perpetuate the memory of their beloved child, and supporting them in their grief and pain.

How you can help

We believe this project will encourage debate about national service, which can be a divisive subject. It will encourage both sides to listen to each other about the pros and cons of such a system.

We need your help in raising £3000 for our run at the Etcetera Theatre in London. The Money will go towards the following costs:

Artists Fees, Designer Fees, Costume and Props, Theatre rent and Insurance and PR and Marketing.  

We hope that this run at the Etcetera Theatre in London will help us move the production onto the next stage and enable us to produce a longer run in London and/or a touring production.

Written and performed by Niv Petel

Niv Petel is an Israeli actor who originally trained at The Performing Arts Studio of Yoram Leowenstein, Tel-Aviv and Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts in London. Niv has worked both on stage and as a voice over artist and has previously won the award for best actor in theatre for children in Israel 2014.


Produced by Alan Boulter Productions

Alan Boulter Productions was formed in 2015 to produce new writing, new musicals and immersive theatre. Alan Boulter Productions recently produced Never Ending Night at the Waterloo Vaults and the workshop and industry presentation of Guy Fawkes a New Musical at the Prince of Wales Theatre.


Where is the play being performed?

KNOCK KNOCK is being performed at the Etcetera Theatre London from Tuesday 25th October to Sunday 6th November 2016.
Preview Night: Tuesday 25th October.
Press Night: Wednesday 26th October.
Performances start at 7.30pm (Except Sundays 6.30pm)


Where is the Etcetera Theatre?

Etcetera Theatre, 256 Camden High Street, London, NW1 78U
Nearest tube Station: Camden Town (Northern Line)
Bus routes: 24,27,29,31,88,134,168,214,253,274
Website: www.etceteratheatre.com
Tel: 020 7482 4857


How do I get in touch with KNOCK KNOCK?

Please send an email to alan@alanboulterproductions.com or via our website www.alanboulterproductions.com

story:
I am so fortunate to be taking these wonderful performers to Sweden in the Fall to participate in the international Abundance Dance Festival in Karlstad. “Seaclipse” which is a site specific work that was originally commissioned by Santa Monica Cultural Affairs, will take place throughout the grounds of the Varmland Museum in Karlstad.  I am excited for the opportunity to adapt my piece to another beautiful outdoor area halfway across the world.

We have our rooms, meals and full production costs covered, and now we need your help getting there!  As you know, running a dance company can be a bit challenging, so if you have the resources to help, please send along a much appreciated donation. Any amount helps… really.

Thank you for your consideration. This is a  short excerpt from this 40 minute work.


We Need 

  • Six roundtrip airline tickets from LA to Stockholm.
  • Six roundtrip train tickets from Stockholm to Karlstad.
  • Housing for six people for two nights in Stockholm.
  • Travel funds to and from the airport in Stockholm.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kate Caryer. I am a rude, pink-haired, theatre lover and a pain in the arse. Oh, and I have a little thing called athetoid cerebral palsy, which means  I use a wheelchair and a communication aid (think punk haired Stephen Hawking). Even without speech I have a lot to say.

On the serious side I have a Bachelor’s degree in Performing Arts and a Master’s degree in disability studies.

I have always loved theatre, but I very rarely see people like me on the stage. If they do show up, they are usually weak, uninteresting caricatures, written by non-disabled people, and not representative of the interesting diverse group of disabled people that I know. Such roles are also usually given to non-disabled actors!

Wanting to do something about this, I started The Unspoken Project CIC, along with Paul C. Mooney as Artistic Director, to give acting opportunities to disabled and non-disabled actors, and to bring the real stories of disabled people to the stage. Our first production, Speechless, shockingly overwrites everything you know about people without speech, and introduces their own stories to stage and is due to premier later this year.

We are thrilled to be given the opportunity to bring our first show to the 30th anniversary of Communication Matters annual conference in Leeds in September 2016. Communication Matters is the leading charity for non – speech communication.

We hope our dark humour will break through the barriers built up by years of inaccurate representation of disabled people.

What We Need & What You Get

We have calculated for this premier production we would need about £6500. The budget can be broken down as follows:-

Wages

£5000

        5 actors, director, musical director   

     at   Equity rates

Rehearsal space hire

£  500

Accommodation

£  450

       2 nights at hotel

Train fares

£ 334

       London to Leeds return

      5 people

Meals

£ 175

     Dinners at conference

Total

£6459

It is important to us that all of our actors are paid fairly for their time and efforts. In line with Equity's 'No Pay, Low Pay' campaign, we recognise the damaging effects of asking professional actors to work for little or no pay.

We have already raised £4000 and, allowing for contingencies, an extra £3000 would make this show spectacular.

Check out our unique and quirky perks for funders.

This show WILL take place, even if we do not reach our target.  The shortfall will have to come out of my pocket – a poor crippled spastic – can your conscience let you live with this?  (Sometimes inaccurate media representation can be used to my advantage!)  Or we will have to kill off one of our disabled cast members – a popular plot device currently in the news.

The Impact

Speechless shockingly overwrites everything you think you know about people without speech, and introduces their own stories to stage.

It tells the story of 19-year-old Rebecca Walker. Like me, she has no speech due to cerebral palsy. However, like many people in the UK and worldwide, Rebecca has no access to a communication aid or other methods of alternative communication. This means that her story, opinions, and devious teenage thoughts remain unspoken.

When Mr and Mrs Walker leave their so-called ‘baby daughter’ with a personal assistant, they did not know that the cotton wool imprisoning world that they lovingly built for their frail little disabled girl would come tumbling down. Nor did they realise from this, a strong disabled young woman will find her voice, and will use this voice to change her parents view of disability and herself.

A coming-of-age tale of a woman with cerebral palsy that explores assistive communication in a light that hasn’t been seen in the world of theatre before!

Risks & Challenges

Paul and I are both experienced theatre makers and we have built up a dream team of fine actors who have given us incredible support right from the first read through. 

All adventures have risks but we are confident that, with the support and commitment we have received from both the disability and theatre worlds, we are well placed to cope with any challenges that come our way.  We have a guaranteed audience, as some tickets will be given to Conference delegates.



Other Ways You Can Help

Contributions of any size would be welcome, but if you cannot contribute financially, please spread the word in any way you can and use the Indiegogo share tools.  The world needs this play!

story:
Who are we?

RAGE Readings began as a summer reading series dedicated to tapping into the diverse creative community in Queens in order to bring unique live programing to Astoria and the surrounding area. 2015 saw us host five evenings featuring an eclectic mix of poetry, fiction, and non-fiction read by either the writer or an actor who was familiar with the material, plus one scripted piece of theatre, all of which took place at the excellent arts supportive venue Astoria Coffee.

This year we have decided to get back to our roots -- live theatrical performance. We are doing this by producing the world premier of "The King is Dead: A one act play on the trials and tribulations of tindering in the modern world in three parts…in three parts." The King is dead, or TKID for short, is an absurdist piece that draws heavily on inspiration from early existentialist playwrights. Though three story lines taking place in three worlds, it explores the culture of online dating and the idiosyncrasies that seem to go hand in hand with participating in that confusing, often frustrating realm. The cast features four actors, a puppeteer, a musician, and a physical clown. Our performance will be happening as a part of the Secret Theatre's UNFringed Festival in mid August.

Our first production will attempt to turn several conventions of Theatre making on their head. In place of traditional anonymous casting, we have gathered a cast made of actors who have worked together intimately for a number of years. "Rehearsal" is a word that for many brings to mind tedious hours of blocking and frustration. While these will be present in any theatrical environment, we prefer the word "Play" to rehearsal and hope to use our time to give value to the thoughts and opinions of all of our collaborators, allowing everyone involved with "The King is Dead" to enjoy a feeling of ownership over the performance we are creating.


RAGE takes its name from the Dylan Thomas poem "Do not go gentle into that good night." The name pays tribute to Rev. Margo McKenna, painter, photographer, and aunt of RAGE founder Timothy Bell, who took her own life in spring of 2014 after a 53 year battle with depression. Her creativity lives on through the work that we produce.  


Your funding will allow us to build our set, make quality props and costume pieces, and most importantly, we will be able to pay all of our collaborators the stipend that they deserve for their long hours of work.

What about all them greenbacks?

Your money will be used in a variety of ways. Our budget breakdown looks a little something like this:
  • $1800 artists stipends
  • $500 rehearsal space rental
  • $400 Secret Theatre UNFringed performance fee
  • $500 props +set
  • $100 flyers and post cards
  • $200 "Oh no! We forgot ____ " back-up funds

A note from the Director

For anyone who doesn't know, the duty of art, as I was taught it in theatre school, is to hold a mirror up to nature.

You might ask yourself "why would I fund this campaign over something else, or using my money in a way that benefits me more directly?" It would be a fair question. 

My answer would be, if there is something you feel more passionate about, then please do give in that direction. Feed that passion. "It's the spice of life," someone recently reminded me.

Telling stories is something that I am passionate about. The first night of our 2015 reading series, I felt a hard rubber ball of anxiety in the pit of my stomach. Would one of my readers cancel last minute? Would anyone come? Would people walk away feeling like they had wasted an evening? At the end of the evening, we had an audience of forty people packed into a space meant for half that number. We received submissions from creatives all over New York City in response, and put on four more evenings like it. At the end of each evening I was inevitably approached by someone, or many someone's, who expressed that a particular story had touched them in a way they hadn't been ready for, or inspired them to continue their creative journey, or made them laugh for the first time in weeks. 

Live performance is the root of community. From early human fireside storytelling with cave painting illustrations, to the festival of Dionysus in ancient Greece, to the Globe Theatre in Elizabethan England, to the massive network of artists creating all over the world today, performance is what feeds our souls. Art is happening right now as you read this, in hundreds or perhaps thousands of places all over the world. Art will continue to happen. Your donation to "The King is Dead" is a small guarantee that the glue that binds our communities together will continue to hold. You will help us hold a mirror up on a small stage in Long Island City for three evenings in the hope that someone, or several someone's, will see something in our show that makes them ask a question they have never asked, feel something they have never felt, experience something they have never experienced.

What if I'm really, really broke?

We've all been there. If you can't afford to give but you find yourself interested in our message, then please feel free to share our campaign across any social media platform you have, tell your friends, use your home-made intergalactic communication device to beam a message to the Crab Nebula. The more eyes that see our campaign the better, even if those eyes are attached to six foot tall green stalks and belong to a creature who's name you need an extra tongue to pronounce. 

Special thanks to the following artists for their contributions to both our initial efforts and this fundraising campaign:

Caitlin Allen (IG: @catdeedid)

Larry Auerbach (IG: @rustyshapes)

Lia Boner (IG: @makeitlia)

Sharone Halevy (IG: @sharoneile)

Lyssa Mandel (Podcast: The Bitch Seat)

Hila Perry (IG: hilathekilla) 

Jim Poulmas (IG: @jimpoulmas)
story_txt:
Who are we?
RAGE Readings began as a summer reading series dedicated to tapping into the diverse creative community in Queens in order to bring unique live programing to Astoria and the surrounding area. 2015 saw us host five evenings featuring an eclectic mix of poetry, fiction, and non-fiction read by either the writer or an actor who was familiar with the material, plus one scripted piece of theatre, all of which took place at the excellent arts supportive venue Astoria Coffee.

This year we have decided to get back to our roots -- live theatrical performance. We are doing this by producing the world premier of "The King is Dead: A one act play on the trials and tribulations of tindering in the modern world in three parts…in three parts." The King is dead, or TKID for short, is an absurdist piece that draws heavily on inspiration from early existentialist playwrights. Though three story lines taking place in three worlds, it explores the culture of online dating and the idiosyncrasies that seem to go hand in hand with participating in that confusing, often frustrating realm. The cast features four actors, a puppeteer, a musician, and a physical clown. Our performance will be happening as a part of the Secret Theatre's UNFringed Festival in mid August.





Our first production will attempt to turn several conventions of Theatre making on their head. In place of traditional anonymous casting, we have gathered a cast made of actors who have worked together intimately for a number of years. "Rehearsal" is a word that for many brings to mind tedious hours of blocking and frustration. While these will be present in any theatrical environment, we prefer the word "Play" to rehearsal and hope to use our time to give value to the thoughts and opinions of all of our collaborators, allowing everyone involved with "The King is Dead" to enjoy a feeling of ownership over the performance we are creating.

story:
Short Summary

     The HOT BLOODed Theatre Co. was founded in 2014 by actor Daniel Csutkai as a result of his need to explore a different kind of theater with the goals of producing work that would immerse audiences in the piece and allow actors to explore their personal process and craft.

      The HOT BLOODed Theatre Co. is an ensemble-driven collective of artists who work within a number of guidelines to produce theater. We eschew the need for a director, which allows us as actors to explore the vision and aesthetic of the production throughout the rehearsal process, as opposed to rehearsing and developing the show with an unchanging vision in mind. Instead, extensive research and experimentation allow us to develop an ensemble vision of the play. Nothing is blocked beforehand – movement, dance and space are played with, explored, and improvised throughout rehearsal to create a work that flows and is driven by text and an understanding of character; the work evolves naturally as actors make new choices driven from their evolution within the work. 

      We work in unconventional spaces so that both audience and actor may develop a deeper understanding of the work. We use minimal props, set pieces and costumes, allowing our actors to be fully present and vital in their own agency. Our audience is a part of the process – this means that they may be seated, standing, moving in the space, adding the fundamental energy that makes our work necessary. Our theater is immersive, adaptive, dynamic and experimental.

      In 2015, we developed our first work, THE SEAGULL by Anton Chekhov, with the Rocks Pop Up Project in Sydney, Australia. This year, The HOT BLOODed Theatre Co. will develop its first show, DEATHWATCH by Jean Genet, in its new home, New York City. One of the lesser known plays by absurdist master Jean Genet (other works include THE MAIDS and THE BALCONY), this is a play about prisoners in a unknown jail in an unknown place and was largely influenced by Genet’s own imprisonment in France. DEATHWATCH is an exploration of identity, desire, and social conventions in the direst of circumstances.

What We Need

Whether or not we reach our total target, every little bit helps from booking a rehearsal space to being more flexible with our costume or lighting choices. A micro budget is still a budget.

Every cent will go towards creating this show and future shows. 

Breakdown:

Play Permissions: $875

Venue: $1155

Rehearsal Space: $845

Actor Stipend: $200

Marketing/Promotions: $200

Photography/Videography: $225

Costumes: $300

Set/Properties: $500

Lighting: $200

Music/Sound design: $200

Miscellaneous Expenses: $300

Insurance: $200

Total Estimated Budget: $5000

If we reach our target, the money will allow us to create with impunity! If not, whatever we raise will go towards our primary expenses and will attempt to balance our funding in other areas

The Impact

      Theater itself is a dynamic and experimental form. We love feedback from our audience; inviting them into our world allows us to figure out new ways to create new and exciting experiences. When you enter our space, you are leaving the world as you know it and immersing yourself in something new.

       When we had our first foray in Sydney, we activated an old museum foyer, and delved our audience into an intimate and private world. We took classic theater and, without modernising it, made it accessible and immediate.

Risks & Challenges

      Theater making is a challenge even with a budget, there are an enormous number of variables that can halt us, propel us and confound us. Collaborative theater making introduces argument, disagreement, and a micro budget introduces many sacrifices in terms of our potential for set, costume and properties (although we are minimal, we still need the essentials).

     Our major challenge will be our ability to covert the space, which will require a lot of time and energy and is where most of our scenic/costume/properties budget will be spent.

      Additionally, as a member of the company you are expected to be a jack of all trades, which means that anyone involved in a project with the HOT BLOODed Theatre Co. will not only be an actor, but will also be from time to time a costumer, a graphic designer, a carpenter, basically any role involved with making a production come to fruition. Reaching our target will alleviate some of these stresses as we have some budget to work with.

    We will achieve theater whether we reach our target or not, as we work closely with people to collaborate and foster relationships that allow us to overcome our obstacles and achieve our goals. When producing THE SEAGULL, we managed to create a wonderful energy and interest just from fostering our relationships with other theater creators and artists in Sydney and we intend on doing the same here.

Other Ways You Can Help

      There is a saying, “Take of my flesh, not of my wallet" and while we value your financial contribution, if you have any skills you are willing to offer – photography, painting, costume design, etc., we would love to hear from you!

     Please also share our campaign with your friends and family; anyone interested in creating theatre is our friend too.

story:
The 2 Sides of Eddie Ramone started out as a one man show in Santa Monica, California and from there it played for three weeks at the world renowned Edinburgh Festival where it attracted terrific revues as you can see. The first one, by Kate Copstick, was in The Scotsman.

The Play

Since relocating back to London I knew somehow that the play could go further. 
In the piece, Eddie has an out of body experience during his act and continues in 'auto pilot' but gets interrupted by a heckler who brings up an incident from his past.

It is now a full length play - a 'two hander' with Eddie and his daughter. 

This will be the world premiere of the full length play and it opens at: 

The Jermyn Street Theatre, 16b, Jermyn Street, London SW1Y 6ST on Monday July 25th, 2016 and runs till Saturday 30th. 

Here are the venue details:

and a map:


Brian Friel:                       

I was very heavily influenced by the late Brian Friel and, whilst I am not comparing any of my work to his genius, his body of work gave me a lot of ideas for the concept of this full length play.

Now who am I? 

The following will tell you a lot: 

Before you click on to this I have to tell you that it will take you away from this page.

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0838002/?ref_=fn_al_nm_2
 it's the Internet Movie Data Base. 
There you will find credits, photos, ratings, a couple of biographies and even a few comments – mainly about me playing Doctor Who which didn't amount to much at all.
Apart from the movies and TV, I have worked in the theatre in repertory at:

The Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, Royal Theatre, Northampton; The Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham; Birmingham Repertory Theatre, Birmingham; National Tour of the UK in Fur Coat and No Knickers (a comedy, would you believe) A Treat at The Soho Poly Theatre, London (to terrific national reviews) and an award winning play, Lovely, at Santa Monica Playhouse, California which ran for nine months. 

I've also played a one man Irish show called A Bit Of Irish, intermittently, from the year 2001 to 2010.

Funding:

The amount of funding needed on this project is a further £6000.

I say further because I have raised £4000 already – so someone has faith in me! Because I've managed to raise that, the theatre rental is taken care of.

Advertising:

Most of the £6000 will be needed for advertising as there is very little point in doing the play at all if we are playing to empty houses.

I plan to take a quarter of a page in Timeout and maybe an eighth of a page the following week if funds allow.

The local newspaper, The London Evening Standard, will be used for listing the times and dates of the play.

I was asked how much this would cost and it would be about  £2,834 for Timeout and the Standard about £900.

Then there is the printing of the programmes £100, the A5 flyers, £150 and the posters will be about £75.

An extra large poster and maybe post cards.

Rehearsals.

We will be rehearsing the play full time for one week before the opening night and part time for the preceding three weeks. This will involve three week's salary to the person playing my daughter and one week's salary to a stage manager for the final week of rehearsal.

I have managed to find a place to rehearse for the final week and I am talking to people about the other rehearsal days and a meeting place for prospective Kates; Kates? I hear you say - yes the name of the other character is Kate.

Kate's minimum pay will be £900 - that is for one week in the play, one week's rehearsal plus 6 days @ £50. This I will be able to manage it with this budget. 

I will not be taking a salary at all but will wait to see how the play fares at the box office before taking any funds. I'm not expecting to make a profit but if we do or I have money surplus to our requirements it will be paid to the Equity members who will be on minimum pay; including me.

The production will be monitored by Equity (The British version) and the Equity Fringe Agreement for Performers and Stage Management will be adhered to.

I am a member of Equity as well as being the producer.

The Final Financial Figure.

If I do not reach the figure required, compromises will have to be made with advertising; for example less advertising in Time Out, two lines instead of three in The Standard but there will be no compromise with regards to any salaries.

Currencies:

Incidentally this campaign, because I am in the UK, is in British pounds; sterling in other words, i.e. £. 

There is no key on the American key board for £ but you can get it by typing the following - hold down alt type 0163 then release.

Today if you contribute £1 and your currency is in American dollars, for example, your contribution will cost you $1.39.

A rough ball park conversion rate is as follows - but only for today and only for American dollars.

£50 = $69.20.  £100 = $138.50.  £150 = $207.87.  £200 = $277.16.

These rates change by the minute so check the converter against your own currency. Here is one to be going on with or you may have an 'app' on your phone:

Before you click on to this I have to tell you that it will take you away from this page.

http://www.xe.com/currencyconverter/

Perks:

There are perks available but you can send any amount of money if you wish to participate from £1 to whatever you like. 

If you want to claim a perk do so when you contribute. I haven't done this before so I am presuming that's the procedure - if not I'll say so in the updates which, I believe, come to you automatically.

 - here are examples of the perks:

'The Saint' crew jacket and the Dodgers Baseball Jersey.

STIG 'TOP GEAR' TEE SHIRT. - FRONT AND BACK.
Casting:
At the time of preparing this campaign I have yet to cast someone to play my daughter, Kate. The main reason is that it's too early. The play is due to open in July – and then only for a week – and it would be unfair to ask anybody to keep themselves available for such a distance in the future.  

However I will come to that and I'll be looking for someone who is talented, brilliant and experienced.

Risks and Challenges:

There will be risks and challenges on the way, I am sure, and one of my jobs will be to anticipate what they might be.

Number one is getting this to you, not to bother you too much and making sure targets are met; I will be in touch again if the campaign drops off and if it does drop off permanently I will research new avenues of finance. 

Before rehearsals even start I have to cast Kate, put final touches to A5 fliers, posters - first of all six for the theatre and then a batch more to circulate

Targets have to be met artistically so we have to allow plenty of time and concentrated effort for rehearsals. It's no good telling the audience you had a cold in rehearsals when your performance is no good - they don't want to know so we will have to work very hard to make The 2 Sides of Eddie Ramone a first class professional production -  because we are professionals.

Experience as a producer:

I have run my own shows since 2002 which involved booking theatres on the other side of the world – I lived in Los Angeles when I booked theatres in the UK: the Edinburgh Festival, a UK tour to Edinburgh (before I did the festival), Bridgnorth and (as it happens) the Jermyn Street Theatre in London.

I also took the Irish show to colleges in Los Angeles and the Irish Fare at Santa Anita Race Track in California.

Arranging a tour and booking theatres means, when you get to each theatre, lighting needs to be arranged, sound cues, lighting cues and the general upkeep of the show; so I know what to expect, but it's fun, I love it and I look forward to doing it again with this play.

The easy thing about this venue is that the theatre supply someone to 'run the show' so once it's all plotted I will just have to concentrate on attracting an audience.

I have also produced and directed a couple of films, two music videos, some sketches (one of them on the Laugh or Die web site) and written 2 novels which are for sale as paperback, kindle and talking books on Amazon. 

Other Ways you can help.

I realise that some people just can't contribute – but you may be able to spread the word; sometimes that's even better – you may be passing it on to our biggest contributor yet; who knows?

Maybe enter my information on the timeline of your facebook page, or tell all your friends and people in your email address book.

As I mentioned The 2 Sides of Eddie Ramone means a lot to me – I hope you can help in whatever way you can - become part of the family of this exciting new venture and turn it into an adventure that YOU can be proud of too.

This I will be able to manage it with this budget. I
will not be taking a salary at all but will wait to see how the play
fares at the box office before taking any funds. I'm not expecting to make a profit but if we do or I have money surplus to our requirements it will be paid to the Equity members who will be on minimum pay; including me.

The
production will be monitored by Equity (The British version) and the
Equity Fringe Agreement for Performers and Stage Management will
be adhered to.

I
am a member of Equity as well as being the producer.

The
Final Financial Figure.

If
I do not reach the figure required, compromises will have to be made
with advertising; for example less advertising in Time Out, two lines
instead of three in The Standard but there will be no compromise with
regards to any salaries.Currencies:Incidentally this campaign, because I am in the UK, is in British pounds; sterling in other words, i.e. £. There is no key on the American key board for £ but you can get it by typing the following - hold down alt type 0163 then release.Today if you contribute £1 and your currency is in American dollars, for example, your contribution will cost you $1.39.A rough ball park conversion rate is as follows - but only for today and only for American dollars.£50 = $69.20.  £100 = $138.50.  £150 = $207.87.  £200 = $277.16.These rates change by the minute so check the converter against your own currency. Here is one to be going on with or you may have an 'app' on your phone:Before you click on to this I have to tell you that it will take you away from this page.http://www.xe.com/currencyconverter/Perks:There are perks available but you can send any amount of money if you wish to participate from £1 to whatever you like. If you want to claim a perk do so when you contribute. I haven't done this before so I am presuming that's the procedure - if not I'll say so in the updates which, I believe, come to you automatically. - here are examples of the perks:'The Saint' crew jacket and the Dodgers Baseball Jersey.
STIG 'TOP GEAR' TEE SHIRT. - FRONT AND BACK.Casting:
At
the time of preparing this campaign I have yet to cast someone to
play my daughter, Kate. The main reason is that it's too early. The play is
due to open in July – and then only for a week – and it would be
unfair to ask anybody to keep themselves available for such a
distance in the future.  

However
I will come to that and I'll be looking for someone who is talented, brilliant and experienced.
Risks and Challenges:

There
will be risks and challenges on the way, I am sure, and one of my jobs will be to anticipate what they might be.
Number one is getting this to you, not to bother you too much and making sure targets are met; I will be in touch again if the campaign drops off and if it does drop off permanently I will research new avenues of finance. 
Before rehearsals even start I have to cast Kate, put final touches to A5 fliers, posters - first of all six for the theatre and then a batch more to circulate

Targets have to be met artistically so we have to allow plenty of time and concentrated effort for rehearsals. It's no good telling the audience you had a cold in rehearsals when your performance is no good - they don't want to know so we will have to work very hard
to make The 2 Sides of Eddie Ramone a first class professional production -  because we are
professionals.
Experience as a producer:

I
have run my own shows since 2002 which involved booking theatres on
the other side of the world – I lived in Los Angeles when I booked
theatres in the UK: the Edinburgh Festival, a UK tour to Edinburgh
(before I did the festival), Bridgnorth and (as it happens) the
Jermyn Street Theatre in London.
I also took the Irish show to colleges in Los Angeles and the Irish Fare at Santa Anita Race Track in California.

Arranging
a tour and booking theatres means, when you get to each theatre,
lighting needs to be arranged, sound cues, lighting cues and the
general upkeep of the show; so I know what to expect, but it's fun, I love it and I look forward to doing it again with this play.
The easy thing about this venue is that the theatre supply someone to 'run the show' so once it's all plotted I will just have to concentrate on attracting an audience.
I have also produced and directed a couple of films, two music videos, some sketches (one of them on the Laugh or Die web site) and written 2 novels which are for sale as paperback, kindle and talking books on Amazon. 
Other Ways you can help.

I
realise that some people just can't contribute – but you may be
able to spread the word; sometimes that's even better – you may be
passing it on to our biggest contributor yet; who knows?


Maybe enter my information on the timeline of your facebook page, or tell all your friends and people in your email
address book.

As
I mentioned The 2 Sides of Eddie Ramone means a lot to me – I hope
you can help in whatever way you can - become part of the family of this exciting new venture and turn it into an adventure that YOU can be proud of too.

story:
The Dancer's Cooperative's premiere evening-length performance works to demolish existing structures for supporting and funding contemporary dance, and exposes the process of developing a cooperative model. Scratch encourages direct action, drawing on experiences from public protest performances that highlighted Governor Bruce Rauner's budget cuts. It is a physical outlining of a year-long process of experimenting, organizing, and supporting.  

Under the direction of MaryAnn McGovern, Scratch weaves together a charged movement vocabulary, story-telling, and documentation of street performances.

The Dancer’s Cooperative is a process-driven contemporary dance theater project led by emerging Chicago artists MaryAnn McGovern, Gretchen Soechting, Deborah Byczkowski, Kellyn Jackson, and Jasmine Mendoza. Acting as co-directors and ensemble, we aim to address the challenges of the traditional single-artist, not-for-profit model in a post-recession world. We posit that a small group of equal directing partners can achieve more in collaboration than in competition with one another.

With the overarching goals of sustainability and longevity, the cooperative employs a democratic structure of leadership and support. 

The Dancer’s Cooperative is a recipient of the 2015 Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events Individual Artist Grant.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to cover the costs of our premiere evening-length performance at Beauty and Brawn Gallery and Think Space on April 9-11, 2016.

Costs include:

Performance space rental: $2,000

March & April Rehearsal Space rental: $400

Liability insurance: $75

Marketing Materials & Graphic Design: $300

Equipment Rental: $225

Artist fees: $2000

The Impact

This project is an experiment in dance cooperativism.  It is an attempt at improving the working lives of dance artists, and serves as one avenue to solving issues surrounding the crises of under funding in the arts.  It encourages direct action through dance as a viable instrument to promote social justice.

Contributing to this project means that you, too, are helping to address a huge problem: undervaluing the arts.  It means that you are a part of the conversation.  It means that you believe that artists are important members of society who contribute much and deserve to be paid for their time and talent.

Co-Director MaryAnn McGovern has successfully crowdfunded two ambitious projects in the past as MaryAnn McGovern and Dancers.  

Risks & Challenges

Scratch is nearly ready to be performed.  We need your help in funding the final leg of this process.  If this campaign is not fully funded, the co-op will have to dig deep into their pockets to make it happen, and we will not be paid for a year of intense planning and rehearsing.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give, we understand!  Other ways you can help include sharing this campaign with your friends, and making a decision to go see a modern dance concert soon (we suggest Scratch, at Beauty and Brawn Gallery and Think Space on April 9, 10, and 11)!

story:
Short Summary

In 2010, King's Town Players was founded with a goal to create fun, fresh and professional-quality community theatre in Kingston, Ontario. Since its inception the theatre company has presented 31 full-length productions, of which 15 have been Kingston premieres.

What We Need & What You Get

Now entering its 7th season, the King's Town Players is seeking to expand what it means to do community theatre in Kingston. We've enjoyed six years of successful shows but are ready to take our company to the next level. Our team has grown significantly, both in size and talent, and want to continue to produce high quality productions and expand our audience.

Here's what your contribution will go towards:
  • Maintaining our rehearsal and build space
  • Innovative set design and construction
  • High quality costumes and props
  • Rental of performance spaces throughout Kingston
  • Expanding our publicity and marketing to new mediums
Here are some examples of how money is spent that we raise, through our ticket sales and advertising, as well as through memberships, donations and other fund-raising:
$25 = Build a new flat for a set
$50 = A custom costume piece
$75 = One run of show publicity posters
$100 = Licensing rights for a single performance of a show
$125 = Cost of transportation to move a production in to and out of a performance venue
$150 = Average rental cost for a single evening's performance
$250 = Set construction supplies
$350 = The run of house programs for a show

The Impact

The Players have had six years of well-attended and well-received productions and we are thankful to our patrons for helping us achieve that. We would like to continue to stand out as a quality theatre company in Kingston, Ontario. Being able to provide the items above will help us continue our high quality production AND give us more flexibility to focus on expanding what we do both in terms of theatrical programming and how we can market our shows.

We've reached the point in our evolution that we need a little help from our friends. We'll continue to stage great theatre if you can lend us a helping hand (especially one with a few dollars in it).

We would like to be fully funded by August 27, 2016 - only 30 days from now!

Risks & Challenges

As with any arts organization, we face our share of challenges. It's a risky business! We rely on ticket sales, individual and corporate supporters, and advertising to fund our productions. and to help us maintain a viable production space for rehearsals, set builds and storage.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that we are not all wealthy people, and that's why we've started this campaign in the first place, but a contribution of $5.00 or even just sharing this campaign with your network could go a long way. You’d be surprised at how far word of mouth advertising could get us. Whether it’s sharing our IndieGoGo campaign posts on social media or even just talking us up to your friends and family - we could use all the help we can get! Whatever you can give is immensely appreciated.

Like us on Facebook and follow us on Instagram and make sure to share our campaign with #ktp3in30.

Thank you for your interest and support!

story:
The Play

Stuck on an island with 8 million people, Caroline and Denny are lonely and over-medicated. Separated by Central Park and almost two decades in age, this dysfunctional pair is brought together online by lust and their inability to cope. Across the Park, a new play by Kate Tucker Fahlsing, follows Denny and Caroline’s non-traditional relationship for ten years and about ten thousand text messages. This dark comedy takes a candid look at mental illness, the search for human connection, and what happens when the only person who truly understands you is as damaged as you are.

The Team

Playwright/Producer: Kate Tucker Fahlsing

Kate Tucker Fahlsing recently graduated from Northwestern University with her MFA in Writing for the Screen and Stage. Her plays have been featured as readings at Chicago Dramatists, Teatro Vista at Victory Gardens Theater, Greenhouse Theater, and Stage 773 in Chicago. Her plays include, ACROSS THE PARK, HERPES, DUCKS UNLIMITED, SLEEP NUMBER, and PLAN B. She’s also written and performed Off-Off Broadway at La MaMa, Dixon Place, and Judson Church. Kate apprenticed with Oscar-nominated screenwriter, Hawk Ostby, where she wrote and developed projects for both TV and film. She’s a top ten finalist for the Playwrights’ Center Core Apprentice Program 2016-17.

Producer: Kathryn Coughlin Maggiotto

Kathryn writes, develops and produces new plays. She served as the literary manager and associate producer of CulturalDC’s Source Festival for four years where she helped bring over 90 new works to the stage. Dramaturgy credits include Taffety Punk Theatre Company, The DC Queer Theatre Festival and Young Playwrights’ Theater. Kathryn’s plays have been developed and produced by Field Trip Theater, Rorschach Theatre, Inkwell Theatre, 1MPF, DC-Page-to-Stage, St. Bonaventure University, The Disreputables, and Meat and Bone Theatre Company. Studio 28 will be producing her latest play BIGGER THAN YOU, BIGGER THAN ME this spring. She recently relocated her life to New York City.

Director: Maureen Monterubio

Maureen Monterubio is a Brooklyn based director. She mainly focuses on new plays. Her work has been produced by Tiny Rhino, 14th Street Y, Wide Eyed Productions, Peculiar Works Project, Field Trip Theatre, Source Festival, Rorschach Theatre, and Manhattan Theatre Club. In September she will be directing PREGNANT PAUSE at the United Solo Festival. Maureen interned at New York Theatre Workshop. She is a proud Tennessee Volunteer.


What We Need

We have already raised more than 30% of our funding through a grant from Northwestern University and the Araca Project. Our budget expenses are outlined below. Any amount we receive over $10,000 will go to creating a fuller and more realized production through improved sets, costumes and props.

  • Salaries are 40% of our budget. Theatre is inherently collaborative and we believe in paying all of our artists. From our director to actors, designers and stage manager, it truly takes a village to fully produce a play.
  • Production Costs are 35% of our budget. Not only do we need to pay our talented artists to create, we need to give them the space and the materials to do it! Our designers need a lighting and sound package, set materials, costumes and props, and our actors and director need a space to rehearse!
  • Marketing Costs are 15% of our budget. This is a play that needs to be seen by NYC theatre audiences. We need to print programs, create post cards and posters and try to ensure that as many people as possible can come see this incredible play and the talented artists involved.
  • Miscellaneous Costs are 10% of our budget. In addition to all the fun stuff that goes into creating theatre, we also have some less exciting line items. Costs like our monthly fiscal sponsorship dues so that gifts are tax deductible, accident insurance, and a truck to move our large set pieces. We won't bore you with all the details, but know that we've accounted for these things, and that they're necessary.

The Impact

  • Our project will employ over 15 hard working artists working in theatre in New York City and Chicago
  • We have a female led creative team! The Across the Park team isn't waiting around for gender parity  to fix itself. We're taking matters into our own hands.
  • You will have a vital role in bringing a new play to the New York stage.
  • This play puts the story of two characters living with mental illness center stage. Across the Park gives voice to those who suffer and survive in a way that is candid and poignant.

Challenges

Producing is not an easy task. We are building an infrastructure from the ground up by using our experience as producers and artists to solve problems creatively. We are surrounding ourselves with a smart, talented, experienced and hardworking team in order to ensure Across the Park receives the production it so deserves.

How Can You Help?

  • Donate at any level to contribute to the next steps of this journey.
  • Spread the word! Share our project with friends and family in person or on social media.
  • Be in our audience! When we open in October, make sure you're there to see this play's very first production.
  • Be creative! We know the importance of surrounding ourselves with awesome people. Let us know if you have your own idea of how you'd like to get involved.

ACROSS THE PARK  is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of ACROSS THE PARK must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Support Theatre and Local Businesses

Is everyone who lives in the mountains like the characters in Deliverance? Do people from the flatlands not understand a thing? I Ain't Made That Way tackles these questions and examines the true meaning of family.  The audience is part of the cast and we are partnering with local restaurants to sell the show as a dinner theatre. 

The show is being produced without the financial help of an existing theatre company, which is why we need your help to make it happen. Here's what you can help with:

  • Production staff stipends
  • Production materials
  • Artist stipends
  • Marketing materials
  • Script printing
  • Music fees

You Can Make A Huge Difference

Because this play is produced on a shoestring budget, every contribution will be important to bringing this unique story and play to life.

  • We need $5,000 to complete the funding for this play. Already the City of Fairfax is donating rehearsal and performance space, along with promotions through all the city media channels -- all huge in-kind contributions  that  show incredible support for this project.
  • We anticipate ticket sales will cover another portion of the costs.

The Impact

You Can Make a Difference

By helping us out, you become an essential part of the I Ain' Made That Way  team. The cast and creative team is comprised entirely of volunteers who cannot wait to share the story and experience. Your contributions allow us to  bring it all to life.

Every Bit Counts

Can't contribute? We understand, and there are ways you can still help. 

  • Buy tickets
  • Volunteer. Do you have talents in carpentry, music, administration? Moving sets? We love volunteers and have a limited number of slots.  
    • Email townsendart@gmail.com
  • Share this page. The more people find out about us, the better.
  • Like and share our Facebook page, 
    • https://www.facebook.com/iaintmadethatway/

story:
Short Summary

I am a playwright whose work has been performed in many New York City venues. My musical, In the Schoolyard, for which I wrote the book and lyrics, was part of the 2010 New York Fringe Festival. When I Get to Heaven is especially important for me because this time, I have also written the music. What's more the musical is about a deeply spiritual subject - the nature of salvation. It's also pretty funny.

What We Need & What You Get

I am launching this Indiegogo campaign to raise $10,000 for a staged reading and a cast album. In addition to the great feeling you will get knowing you have helped develop a new musical, I am offering several exciting and unique thank-you gifts
story_txt:
Short Summary
I am a playwright whose work has been performed in many New York City venues. My musical, In the Schoolyard, for which I wrote the book and lyrics, was part of the 2010 New York Fringe Festival. When I Get to Heaven is especially important for me because this time, I have also written the music. What's more the musical is about a deeply spiritual subject - the nature of salvation. It's also pretty funny.

What We Need & What You Get
I am launching this Indiegogo campaign to raise $10,000 for a staged reading and a cast album. In addition to the great feeling you will get knowing you have helped develop a new musical, I am offering several exciting and unique thank-you gifts

story:
Hi everyone! My name is Peter Schueller and I have started a soon-to-be non-profit theater company called esō theatricals in Budapest, Hungary. With our last indiegogo drive, we were able to raise enough money to register as a non-profit and put some money aside to use for our next show. However, we'd like to continue to be a presence in Budapest for many years to come, and so would like to humbly ask for your continued support and contributions.

We have now put up three shows! Please check out our website at www.esotheatricals.com or www.facebook.com/esotheatricals for pictures and more information about us as an organization. We've also already had a fantastic review in the Budapest Times: http://budapesttimes.hu/2016/05/06/broadway-com...

esō theatricals’ conceptual framework is unique among the current musical theater industry in Budapest. Currently, there is no formal venue dedicated to English-language musical theater, especially one that also addresses fundamental styles of performance on a professional level.

Through this, we plan to keep connecting members of the local and international communities and expose them to high quality, culturally relevant productions. These have been and will continue to be made accessible by always including Hungarian super-titles. As shown with its premiere productions, esō theatricals has engaged and brought together a melting pot of different peoples and cultures. With the proper funding, we will deliver professional caliber productions that will expose audiences to exceptional performers and present renown musicals from the past and present.

Our casts are diverse, always including at least 5 different nationalities, and welcome to individuals of all gender, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation and identity. We believe this is crucial in helping to create a cultural dialogue and mutual understanding through art and performance. This combination of artists and musical material has so far created an inclusive atmosphere that has been a satisfying and complete theater going experience, delighting new viewers and providing nostalgia for veterans.

Summary of overall objectives:

1.  Successfully provide audiences with desirable and enjoyable entertainment.

2.  Expose the community to iconic musical theater as well as providing exceptional training and services.

3.  Educate the community in various aspects of English-language musical theater methodology, perspective, and history by creating an environment of active cultural relevance and discourse. This will eventually include school and low-income outreach.

4.  Create understanding and compassion towards cultural differences and cultivate mutual good will.

The Budget we are asking for this time around is to help pay for set, costumes, musicians, actors and production expenses. We will always strive for the best we can manage with the funds we receive.

Thank you very much in advance for your support! With your help, we can continue to create something truly unique and special in Budapest!

-Peter Schueller

 

Peter Schueller was born in California and trained in classical vocal performance at the University of Southern California while at the same time branching out into Musical Theater, Theater and Film. Before relocating to Budapest, Peter was seen in numerous professional productions throughout Southern California. Some of his favorite roles have included Tony in West Side Story, Frederic in the Pirates of Penzance and Bobby Child in Crazy for You (awarded Best Actor in a Musical by stagescenela.com). Since being in Budapest, he has acted in, directed, music directed, and choreographed numerous showcases and performances. Some tv and film credits include featured roles in Ridley Scott’s The Martian, Ron Howard’s Inferno, X Company, and NBC’s upcoming Emerald City.

 Classically, Mr. Schueller has been heard as the Tenor soloist in Mozart’s Requiem, Poet/Narrator in Schumann’s Dichterliebe, Tamino in The Magic Flute, Alidoro in Orontea, and as an understudy in SF Opera’s Dead Man Walking, among many other roles. He is a member of the American Guild of Musical Artists and the Mu Phi Epsilon Musical Fraternity.

Additional comments:

esō, means “within”, while in Hungarian means “rain”.  To cleanse, nurture and grow the potential within.

story:
Okay, our video has persuaded you to scroll down. So who are we?

Let us introduce ourselves. We are Sofa Productions, an independent theatre company consisting of over 20 actors & directors who have a passion for producing well crafted theatre. Our aim has always been to provide opportunities for talented young creatives to showcase their work and gain invaluable experience in the world of theatre. Our technique revolves around detailed design of characters, costumes & sets and a love for creating unique theatre experiences.

And did someone say three shows in one night?

Why yes! This year our aim is to bring three amazing shows to the Camden Fringe Festival, which will all be performed every night from 24th-28th August. And we have something to cater for all tastes: 

Like Comedy? At 6pm we start with 'From Russia with Laugh', a collection of three side splitting short stories from one of Mother Russia's greatest writers, Anton Chekhov. This one hour show brings to life a set of rambunctious characters set to some fantastic Russian music & dancing. 

How about something tense and gripping? Extremities at 7:30pm is a thriller of a play by William Mastrosimone. It tells the tale of what happens when a man with unspeakably sinnisiter intentions breaks into three females apartment, before the tables are eventually turned on him.

Or what about something really, really scary? Fright Nights at 9:30pm promises to be the scariest show in Camden Fringe this year. Four gruesome tales of horror, blood and gore will send shivers down your spine like never before!

The venue, Theatro Technis, is a classic theatre space in Camden, with a bar to keep you fully 'hydrated' inbetween shows. Our ticket prices are a bargain at £5 a show. That's £15 for three shows in central London. Now you ask, why so cheap? Well, we believe that great theatre should be accessible to everyone.

So what do you need and what do i get?

Well in total we need  to raise £3000. This is to cover theatre hire, props and costumes. All of our actors, directors and producers work for free and really are doing it simply for the love of their craft.

In return for your supreme kindness and generosity, you will not only receive one of the perks listed but also a huge slice of good karma, our eternal gratitude and the knowledge that you have made us able to realise our dream with this project.

Other ways you can help:

Please feel free to share information about us and our show on social media. Even better, come along to watch the performances and bring your friends! Make a night of it during the last week of August or give yourself a treat during the bank holiday weekend.

story:
From October we are curating a season of American theatre in our UK independent space, The Canal Cafe Theatre. The season will house three American plays (a classic, a modern and an original), plus numerous industry workshops. One of these plays and indeed a major outcome of The American Season, will be a brand new play rooted in Americana. The driving force behind the whole season is to provide a 12 month UK based cultural platform for American theatre in London, thus enriching the UK/USA theatre industry dialogue and understanding.

This arts programming will be pioneering for the UK and indeed the theatre industries on both sides of the Atlantic. It is imagined that the cultural exchange between the UK and US will be enriched and a new dialogue created, thus furthering artistic opportunities for everyone involved and building profiles. This will also be a unique experience in that a British theatre will be commissioning a play focused on Americana.

This is the first of its kind in London Theatreland and we are exploring the possibilities in making this an annual event.

story:
Intro

You can help great actors make a great show! Julie Gaarskjær and Kamilla Reinholdt are a couple of talented actors who built this play and toured it in Denmark before coming to New York to further their craft completing conservatory at Stella Adler Studio. They've joined forces with three more great actors, Ashley Kryzinsky, Christian Lopez-Lamelas, and Lorenzo Luchetti to devise a few more scenes and ratchet up the play for US audiences. Led by director Tania Kass and produced by Kenneth Shook the actors are ready to premier the piece in New York!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to cover several expenses including talent. That's where we really need your help to raise $4,000. When you support this team of talent you'll not only feel good about helping a creative lot, you're supporting important stories about women! As a result, we want to recognize you for helping us. From hand written thank yous to songs written for you and tickets to the show.

The Impact

Fourth Rib from the Right is an entertaining exposé into the daily lives of three women. The play focuses on the themes of identity and taboos as they relate to one’s body. Rounding out the ensemble are two male characters who reveal contrasts and some similarities between men and women. Once on tour in Denmark, the current production has been re-devised and is now ready to entertain audiences in the US. This play can relate to both men and women and is hugely important today especially in NYC where women are often harassed.

Budget

We want you to know where funds are going. It's a very small budget our largest expense is the space. Ticket sales will cover a portion of the costs. Here's what you will help to cover:

Expenses
Talent: $3,500
Space: $2,500
Production (Props, Insurance, etc.): $1,700

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

  • Share our social media posts
  • Share this campaign with others
  • Volunteer (Email Kenneth to volunteer, k@kennethshook.com)
    • Flyering and promotions
    • Helping to run the house

Thank you very much for helping out the Fourth Rib from the Right campaign!!!

 

BUY YOUR TICKETS: http://bit.ly/tix4thribplay

story:
Three Columbia College Chicago students have written a two act musical comedy with a full score and seventeen original songs! "Abduction" takes place in the small town of Pluto, Indiana, where mysterious extraterrestrial abductions have been occurring. It's "The Twilight Zone" meets Mel Brooks, with a cast of larger than life characters, snappy dialogue, and tunes that will get stuck in your head! The main character, Pippa, is a twelve year old girl who is gifted in science and loves to study and invent. Along with catchy tunes, the show promotes a strong female lead and the importance/study of all sciences. We had a reading over the summer in Pittsburgh that allowed us to see what worked and what didn't. In Chicago, we've assembled a cast of theater students from DePaul, Columbia, and Roosevelt, with a few veteran Chicago actors to fill the adult roles. The creative team and designers are all theater students as well, fully committed to this massive passion project.  "Abduction" is set to premiere May 2017 at Stage 773 in Chicago, Illinois. Our core mission is to continue to enrich the Chicago theater community while giving newcomers a chance to take part in developing this new work.

While we fundraised enough to put a down payment on the theater space, there is still much work to do between now and opening night. Costumes, set pieces, props, wigs/makeup, and advertising are all crucial in the making of a successful show. Our budget also includes paying members of a five piece band and printing advertising and playbill materials. We are very proud of and delighted with the content of our material, and would like the show to run as smoothly as possible while looking professional.

TJ Pieffer, the writer/creator of "Abduction" is  junior at Columbia College Chicago, majoring in theater. TJ moved to Chicago three years ago from Pittsburgh where he grew up and fell in love with the city and it's amazing culture. Since he moved, he had been attending and performing in shows around the city, while chipping away at his own original work during any down time. TJ is beyond thrilled at the opportunity to get this show up on it's feet, and there is no place he would rather do it than Chicago!

We are hiring all Chicago based actors, creative crew, and designers to work on this project. While stimulating the theater community, we look forward to giving young artists on stage and off a chance to bring our script to life. Our creative team is almost exclusively made up of students and young designers lending their talent purely for experience and for the love of their craft. While "Abduction" is going up in May, we hope to have the show continue, in many different iterations as it grows and changes, all across the Chicagoland area and perhaps beyond...

story:
Summary

  • We are a new theatre company reinterpreting and re-imagining Shakespeare's The Tempest

  • Key elements of the production are in place and the show will go on!

  • We are seeking your investment in our set, costumes and lighting

  • We will show our appreciation publicly, write poetry in your honour and even come to the place of your choosing and perform scenes from the play just for you and your guests.

  • We believe our audiences will be touched by the moments of transformation they experience and that this will help them to find understanding, connection and hope.  

About Company C  

Company C is a theatre troupe founded by its Director, Lawrence O´Connor, comprising actors, creatives and technicians. The company follows the precedents of the New York Group theatre and Moscow Arts theatre, as a family of practitioners working together on successive productions with geographical ´homes´ from which it finds, engages with, and strengthens its local communities and to which it is of service.  Company C´s key principle is to show up and tell the truth in all that it does.

There is more information about us at http://Companyc.co.uk

About our Tempest Production

Lawrence chose The Tempest as Company C's first production as he believes it captures and articulates its universal human truths in a form that crosses cultural boundaries and barriers. The play sheds light on and raises questions of relationship e.g. between parent-child, lover-loved, carer-caree and oppressor-oppressed roles, loss, personal transformation, fear, resolution, what it is to be free/not free and what it is for a person to find themselves - not of their choosing - in a strange land and what this means to identity and the difference between ´ĺiving´ and ´surviving´.  All extremely relevant and topical themes for life today.

Please visit our Facebook page http://Www.facebook.com/companyctheatretroupe for updates on our current insights and developments about the piece as we explore them through our rehearsal process.

What we have in place

We have a wonderful group of actors and creatives who are contracted to work for a share of the profits.  (The profits will be shared equally after the show)

The Rag Factory and Chelsea Theatre have contributed space for rehearsals and the company is involved in work with the local community in and around the World's End Estate to foster relationships and encourage participation in the arts.  You can read more about Lawrence's connections to this area at companyc.co.uk/lawrence-oconnor/blog/

Our performance space is booked.  Our first 3 performances will be at the Chelsea Theatre 26-29 November and then we move to the Ectetera Theatre, Camden Town 8-27 November

Tickets are on sale! (Click on the theatre names above for ticket details)

What we need

To support our actors, we would love to create a magical environment with our set, lighting and costumes.  We have some talented young people working on the design and would like to provide them with the resources to bring their artistic ideas to fruition.

Specifically we need.... 

  • £600 for materials for the set
  • As our set will need to be taken down after each performance,  storage for our set in central London - £450
  • £60 per actor for costumes - £720
  • Lighting & effects hire: projector, follow spot, hand-held lights, a strobe and dry ice machine with ice - £1400
  • Allowance for Indiegogo fees £185.00

  • Total £3,355

Whatever funds we have, the show will go on and we will still give priority to recycling and value for money.  Your money will make all the difference to the quality of experience our audiences have,  And that in turn will impact ticket sales, overall profits and individual income.  The whole company will be boosted by your support and recognition.

We believe this story of transformation has the potential to reach out and connect deeply with all who come to see us and are seeking your help to reach as many people as fully as we can.

What you get in return

We have a range of ways of showing our appreciation for your contribution.  Fancy VIP treatment when you come to see the show?  We will reserve the seats of your choice, meet you or your group at the door and make sure we take the best care of you.  For smaller contributions we will give our public thanks and recognition and for bigger ones, our Prospero, David K Whiting will write a poem in your honour.  

For substantial sums we will visit a venue of your choice and perform a scene from the play.  A unique and memorable experience for you and your friends.  If you are further afield we can stream your performance live, distance is no barrier!

Risks & Challenges

Although we are a new company, we bring together considerable previous professional experience in theatre, business and promotion. Having said that there is always much to learn, for example, with hindsight, we would have started this site much earlier in the process!

We will be fully expressing our uniqueness in this production which means we will not please everyone. There is a chance that some people will react badly to what we do, but equally they may love us!

We are aware we will not actually have the funds in our account before we need to spend the money on the items we have specified. We will however be able to see what you have contributed and budget accordingly. Where we need to borrow money, this will be possible as we will be able to give a firm commitment to the payback date, thanks to your pledge.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course we’d love you to come and see the show.  Click on the links below for ticket details....

Chelsea Theatre 26-29 November

Ectetera Theatre, Camden Town 8-27 November

Whatever you can do to spread the word would be much appreciated.  You can join our mailing list at forms.aweber.com/form/16/800527516.htm

Please follow us on Facebook and Twitter and don’t forget the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks for reading our pitch, we’d love to hear what you think and hope to connect with you soon
