Our performance space is booked.  Our first 3 performances will be at the Chelsea Theatre 26-29 November and then we move to the Ectetera Theatre, Camden Town 8-27 November
Tickets are on sale! (Click on the theatre names above for ticket details)
What we need
To support our actors, we would love to create a magical environment with our set, lighting and costumes.  We have some talented young people working on the design and would like to provide them with the resources to bring their artistic ideas to fruition.
Specifically we need.... 

£600 for materials for the set
As our set will need to be taken down after each performance,  storage for our set in central London - £450
£60 per actor for costumes - £720
Lighting & effects hire: projector, follow spot, hand-held lights, a strobe and dry ice machine with ice - £1400
Allowance for Indiegogo fees £185.00
Total £3,355

Whatever funds we have, the show will go on and we will still give priority to recycling and value for money.  Your money will make all the difference to the quality of experience our audiences have,  And that in turn will impact ticket sales, overall profits and individual income.  The whole company will be boosted by your support and recognition.
We believe this story of transformation has the potential to reach out and connect deeply with all who come to see us and are seeking your help to reach as many people as fully as we can.
What you get in return
We have a range of ways of showing our appreciation for your contribution.  Fancy VIP treatment when you come to see the show?  We will reserve the seats of your choice, meet you or your group at the door and make sure we take the best care of you.  For smaller contributions we will give our public thanks and recognition and for bigger ones, our Prospero, David K Whiting will write a poem in your honour.  
For substantial sums we will visit a venue of your choice and perform a scene from the play.  A unique and memorable experience for you and your friends.  If you are further afield we can stream your performance live, distance is no barrier!

Risks & Challenges
Although we are a new company, we bring together considerable previous professional experience in theatre, business and promotion. Having said that there is always much to learn, for example, with hindsight, we would have started this site much earlier in the process!
We will be fully expressing our uniqueness in this production which means we will not please everyone. There is a chance that some people will react badly to what we do, but equally they may love us!
We are aware we will not actually have the funds in our account before we need to spend the money on the items we have specified. We will however be able to see what you have contributed and budget accordingly. Where we need to borrow money, this will be possible as we will be able to give a firm commitment to the payback date, thanks to your pledge.

Other Ways You Can Help
Of course we’d love you to come and see the show.  Click on the links below for ticket details....
Chelsea Theatre 26-29 November
Ectetera Theatre, Camden Town 8-27 November
Whatever you can do to spread the word would be much appreciated.  You can join our mailing list at forms.aweber.com/form/16/800527516.htm
Please follow us on Facebook and Twitter and don’t forget the Indiegogo share tools!
Thanks for reading our pitch, we’d love to hear what you think and hope to connect with you soon

story:
BRINGING CHINA TO THE U.S.!

As China's economy develops, the rest of the world still hasn't seen the breadth of creative voices and innovative artists who are emerging! This tour is a first-time opportunity for American audiences on the West Coast to see one of China's most exciting new dance companies.

Gu Jiani is a powerhouse choreographer from China's spicy Sichuan Province. She trained in Chinese classical dance and ballet, but rejected those forms and now creates her own unique works guerrilla style in spaces across Beijing. 

Her duet Right & Left explores the meaning of human relationships, looking at why we fall in love, and how we keep those relationships from destroying who we are.

THE TOUR:

Right & Left is invited to perform in:

June 1, 3, 4:   San Francisco International Arts Festival
June 9, 10: Seattle International Dance Festival
June 16, 17: Los Angeles Huntington Gardens & Library
June 22 (special appearance): JACK Theatre, New York City

Plus workshops, master classes and discussions in each city.

We need your help to make this tour happen!

Video: Alison M. Friedman, Founder of Ping Pong Productions, introduces Gu Jiani 
*Film by Isobel Chang
*Alison Friedman filmed by Ford Fischer
 

About Ping Pong Productions: Bringing Rising Stars to the World Stage

Many of us in the US know China through news and popular media but have limited opportunities to engage directly with contemporary Chinese society, culture and people.

At Ping Pong Productions, we work with contemporary performing artists to bring their works to more than 50 countries on 5 continents for performances and education outreach exchanges. 

Headquartered in Beijing, China, and Washington D.C., Ping Pong Productions' mission is to Bring China and the World Together through Performing Arts. Since founding in 2010, we have produced more than 600 events reaching hundreds of thousands live audience members and exponentially more online. We use the power of the arts to bring people together from different cultures, building mutual understanding and cross-cultural cooperation.

Support "Right & Left" US Tour!

We launch this $25,000 USD campaign to support Gu Jiani's debut US tour of her duet Right & Left this summer, bringing the best of Chinese contemporary dance to the US.

Right & Left, 7-Minute Excerpt
 

With Your Support, Gu Jiani will be able to cover expenses including rehearsal space rental in Beijing, stage props and costumes, flights and visas, local transportation and meals while on tour in the US, and more. Your Support will allow us to include community and school outreach activities for Gu Jiani while on tour, so that she can offer workshops at local schools and meet artists in US communities, further deepening people-to-people engagement between our two countries. 

With Your Support we open the gateway for US audiences to meet this innovative artist and her team from China, sharing her creativity with audiences in America who've never seen anything like her!

We are so grateful for Your Support of Gu Jiani's US Tour. Through the power of these people-to-people connections, together we can help build a more peaceful world!

For Press and other inquiries, CONTACT: Alison@pingpongarts.org 

In addition to the amazing perks offered here, we can offer Title Sponsor and Corporate Underwriting Sponsor opportunities! Name your tour -- [Your Company/Name] Presents: The [City] Premiere of Gu Jiani   Please email Alison@pingpongarts.org for more details!

Photo Gallery 

Gu Jiani in Right & Left  
Photo credit: Hua Dong

 

Right & Left
Photo Credit: Fan Xi

 

Right & Left
Photo credit: Hua Dong

 

Right & Left
Photo credit: Fan Xi

story:
We want to bring this brand new satire to the rest of the UK! In this time of political unease comes Bullingdon revisited, A play on the first meeting of Boris and Dave. We want to raise money for tour purposes. We want to give our actors decent digs, pay for marketing materials as well as be able to get into some great performance spaces in the UK. we want to go big with this and really bowl the theatre world over with this cracking show.


Money we raise will go to promotion and paying the actors. If we do not meet our goal then we will use whatever we have to give to our actors and see about smaller more intimate performance spaces, but our actors come first.


Perks:

We have AMAZING perks just see! VIP tickets, SM shout outs, personalised videos thanking you from the cast.

THE SHOW:

Grand Dame Theatre proudly present a bold new political comedy, specially commissioned from the BBC award-winning playwright Tess Humphrey

It's 1986, among the dreaming spires of Oxford university, one glorious summer's evening.

Dave, a bookish 19-year-old boy who desperately wants to be cool, is trying out his new look as a punk, and going out on the town hoping to impress the famous Bullingdon Club with his racy antics.

Things are looking glum until he meets ultra-popular third year student, and president of the Union, Boris. Boris's eccentric charisma and old English charm makes awestruck Dave desperate to be his friend.

Soon the boys set off on a wild night of raucous attempts to prove that Dave has what it takes to make it in the Bullindon Club. There is a police chase, an incident with a pig, and maybe, if they are very lucky, they will catch a glimpse of their goddess, the sexy and powerful Margaret Thatcher.

Help us take this show on the road and Bing this funny, relevant play to everyone. We are debuting the show in September.

Directed by Sam Hart 
Written by Tess Humphrey

3 Minute Theatre, Oldham Street, Manchester
15-17th September, 7.30pm
To book, go to Grand-Dame-Theatre.co.uk.

story:
Short Summary

Gwyn Emberton Dance is a new dance/theatre company, set up in October 2015 by award-winning choreographer Gwyn Emberton and Producer Kate Perridge.  The first first show by the company is Shadow Of A Quiet Society which toured Wales in early 2016.

After a few funding set backs and dancers who have been injured or ill during the making of SQS, we need support to get back into the studio to rework the piece before the final stages of the tour.  We have a few more performances in Wales and one in Bristol, which we are using as a launch event to introduce the company to theatres and arts centres in England:

Bristol - Circomedia - 14th October

Caernarfon - Galeri - 10th November

Cardiff - Dance House (Wales Millennium Centre) - 12th November

We have had generous support so far from both Arts Council England and Arts Council Wales, but due to other grants being withdrawn we need all the help we can get. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise £3,000.  This will pay for two dancers for the rehearsal period and performances in Bristol, Cardiff and Caernarfon.  This will match the grant that we have received from Arts Council Wales for the performances and will support the England Company Launch in Bristol.

We are offering perks to suit all budgets - from a unique behind-the-scenes invite to a dress rehearsal to the chance to become a patron of the company and have tickets to all our opening nights (forever!)

The Impact

Funding for the arts is hard.  That's the honest truth. We have always been able to make miracles happen on very little money.  But sometimes we need a bit of help and support to make those miracles happen.

We have put a lot of our own funds into the company so far, plus a lot of elbow grease, sweat and a few tears.  We've had ups and downs, but the 'ups' are definitely the way our audiences react to the work that we make.  We want to be able to make more work, to reach more people and offer a new voice to the arts.

So far we have ...

  • Produced My People at Edinburgh Festival Fringe as part of Wales in Edinburgh Showcase in 2015
  • Got some great reviews and received critical acclaim for Shadow Of A Quiet Society on tour in 2016
  • Won awards! Gwyn won Best Choreographer at the Wales Theatre Awards 2015
  • Were invited to perform at British Dance Edition 2016 [international showcase of the best contemporary dance from the UK]
Help us continue this great work through 2016 and into 2017!

Other Ways You Can Help

We realise that times are hard and you might not be able to contribute financially to this campaign, but you can help us in other ways:

  • Come and see a show in Bristol, Caernarfon or Cardiff
  • Tell your friends - please help us spread the word if you have contacts who might be interested in contributing

story:
WHO WE ARE

Ghost Light Players of MetroWest is a non-profit theater group operating out of Marlborough, Massachusetts and serving the MetroWest MA area.  Now in our fifth season, Ghost Light Players hearkens back to the days of old, when traveling troupes entertained their patrons with little more than a few props, masterful skill and an avid love of theater. Our sets are small, our costumes are minimal, but our talents and passions are great.  Our Board of Governors includes members with a more than 20 years of experience producing and directing theater, and we feel incredibly lucky to feature some of the most talented actors in New England. 

THE CHALLENGE

Creating art is not an easy task, and this project brings many challenges.  Not only are we producing a unique Shakespeare experience, but we are also taking that work across the ocean to an international festival.  It is a huge undertaking, but we have the infrastructure and experience as producers and artists to succeed.  Our cast and crew is a talented group of dedicated volunteers who are passionate about bringing locally created theater to the international stage.  Our educational coordinators are developing an experiential learning curriculum so that we can share our work with students in local schools. 

We will…

  • Create and rehearse a 90-minute version of Shakespeare’s Hamlet
  • Mount FREE local productions before we depart
  • Travel to Edinburgh, Scotland
  • Participate in the 2017 International Fringe Festival - the largest theater festival in the world!
  • Return home and engage local youth through an educational theater experience in neighboring schools.  

We have the experience, passion, talent and the courage to make this dream a reality.  So, what do we need now?  You!

 

WE NEED YOUR HELP

Our overall production and travel costs are over $30K, but we're only asking you to help raise half of that (the rest will be raised through grants and participant contributions). Here's where the funds will go (please note that all members of this project are unpaid volunteers):

  • Fringe Festival venue costs
  • Fringe Festival registration fees
  • Production Expenses such as publicity, sets, properties & costumes (including transport)
  • Travel expenses
  • Accommodations for cast and crew 

 

THE IMPACT

  • You will have a vital role in bringing locally created theater from Massachusetts to the international stage.
  • You will help push us to a new level of excellence in theater.
  • You will support the cast and crew of Hamlet in their creative endeavors by allowing us to focus on the hard work ahead of us.  Our goal will be to make you, our supporters, proud of the work we do both locally and overseas.
  • You will help us continue to provide local performances FREE to the public.  Free local productions of Shakespeare encourage those who would normally not see the Bard’s work to explore and enjoy all his works have to offer.
  • You will contribute to the creative and analytical development of local youth. Shakespeare is often taught in our schools by reading his works in an English class, but the best way to experience Shakespeare is to see it performed, or perform it yourself.  Your contribution will help us offer an experiential learning curriculum to local students through our educational program, post Fringe.

 

We can't take the Fringe without your help, but we can help you too! We are a 501c3 non-profit organization, so your donation to Ghost Light Players’ Fringe project is tax-deductible! We're also offering some fun perks that we hope you'll take advantage of (check them out - many were suggested by our early supporters!).  

IF YOU CAN'T DONATE TODAY, THERE ARE STILL PLENTY OF WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Can't contribute monetarily? That's okay! Please consider doing the following:

  • Spread the word! Share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter & Instagram. Talk about the project. Every little effort helps.
  • Visit our website: http://www.ghostlightplayers.com/fringe
  • Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/glplayers
  • Follow us on Twitter & Instagram: @GLPlayers

And last but not least, come out and see us in our local productions in July 2017! We are so excited to share this production with you, and let you see our show before we take it to the Fringe.

With Sincerest Thanks,

Ghost Light Players

 

PS:  All photos from our 2016 production of Hamlet are courtesy of Natalie Hebert

story:
Hi, 

I'm Kyra, I'm a professional dancer. I recently graduated from Simon Fraser University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Contemporary Dance and Sociology. I currently dance with a local company called La Caravan Dance Theatre. I am a dance instructor at Diversity Dance and Performing Arts, where I teach Ballet, Jazz, and Kinder Kids. I also assist adults with mental disabilities on a part time basis. 

I was inspired to make the dance film PEAKS after taking time to walk around Calgary and explore the public art pieces. While I was walking around looking at the pieces I found myself creating dance movement within them, on them, around them, and in front of them. After returning to the same art pieces again and again I was driven to develop the movement into choreography. Initially, I wanted to show what I had created at each location. Then I had the idea to create a dance film, that would capture all the art pieces and interesting movement possibilities and phrases. It was still art that inspired dance art, which lead to my vision for PEAKS. My vision has now evolved from an exploration to a personal objective to show people the local art work that is being produced in Calgary, as well as outside work that artist's have brought into the community. I also want to showcase local contemporary dancers who are committed to enriching the dance community and expanding it. The four minute film will be entered into 12 film festivals throughout North America and Europe. I will write applications for each and submit the film once it has been finalized. Upon acceptance, a larger audience will have the opportunity to view this film. 

Calgary is a younger city and many people don't know what is available here.  I want to bring awareness to its flourishing creativity and vibrant development through this film. 

We need your support to help bring awareness to Calgary's public art, music, and contemporary dance. Your contributions are essential to support each of the artists who are committed to this vision. In total I will need to raise $4500 to pay each artist for their professional contribution and hard work and to cover insurance costs as requested by the Bow Building downtown. 

Please have a look at the funding break down as follows:

Videographer $1400 (10 hours of filming and 4 minutes of video editing @$100/hour).

Dancers $1400 (For the total of five dancers - 3 dancers will attend 5 hours of rehearsal and 10 hours of filming, 1 will attend 3 hours of rehearsal and 3 hours of filming, and 1 dancer will attend 3 hours of rehearsal and 2 hours of filming all @$25/hour).

Composer $600 (30 hours of creating and recording music @$20/hour).

Choreography by Kyra Newton, $400 (4 minutes of dance choreography @$100/per minute produced)

PAL Insurance $350 (as requested by the Bow Building the insurance covers liability coverage up to $5 million, in order to film at the Wonderland Sculpture for 2 hours). 

Submission fees to film festivals $350 (each film festival has a submission cost ranging from $20-$50)

GRAND TOTAL $4500

Meet The Team!

2CreativeCo. is a digital marketing company specializing in identifying you from them. We provide video production services in various genres of film projects. We also provide creative and event photography services, as well as graphic design and aesthetic branding."

 

Eric Smith is a professional musician who also goes by the name Rak, he is an Experimental/Psychedelic/Electronic/Rock Multi-Instrumentalist, Composer, Singer and Performer.

Lindsay Oehlerking graduated from the University of Calgary with a Bachelor or Arts in Dance. She regularly performs in local choreographed work and instructs at Prestige Dance Academy. 

Laura Barcelo is a freelance dance performer, choreographer, and instructor in Calgary. She choreographs and instructs at Crossings Dance and The School of Alberta Ballet. In 2013 she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in psychology from Hope College, with a minor in dance, neuroscience, and ministry. She loves to create beautiful things for others to dwell upon.

Kara Nolte is a freelance dance artist who recently moved to Calgary from Vancouver, where she graduated from the prestigious Arts Umbrella Professional Dance Program and is an alumnus of their world renowned Senior Dance Company. Her award-winning choreography has been shown in collaboration with Project Oswald in Calgary, at the Ignite Festival for Emerging Artists, DanceFest at NextFest in Edmonton, among many other festivals and showcases.

Ruth Naomi Levin holds an MFA in Dance from York University and is a graduate of the School of Toronto Dance Theatre.  She is a company member with Calgary’s own La Caravan Dance Theatre and a member of The Margie Gillis Dance Foundation’s Legacy Project. She has studied, performed and presented her own work across the country, and is the founder and lead coach of Embodied in Motion – a company that offers body-based solutions for better living.

Meghann Michalsky is an independent dance artist and choreographer. She graduated from the University of Calgary with a Bachelor of Arts in Dance and concentration in Choreography and Performance. She has spent time expanding her contemporary dance knowledge in London, Amsterdam, Vienna, Berlin, and recently presented her new collaborative work [Sinking/Floating] abroad in Helsinki, Finland. Michalsky was part of the Lab Emerging Artist Program (LEAP) with Dancers’ Studio West where she performed with Dance Action Company in their 2016 show, Fear. In 2017, Michalsky looks forward to expanding her former choreographic work (Mis)Communication into an evening length show.

Our film will represent Calgary in a new light, it will not only show case local talent but the artists who have helped contribute to the cities public spaces.   

I am committed to creating the film and sharing it no matter what obstacles I face. Throughout my dance career I have overcome stressful situations in company work, attended workshops and auditions that have quite frankly terrified me, and shared my ideas with audience members I don’t know. Creating art is a vulnerable process and my idea for PEAKS is something I trust will impact its audience and the contributing artists in a positive way.

If you’re at a point in your life where you can’t contribute, but you feel passionate about our vision, you can still help us out. Send someone who may be interested in contributing the link to our campaign. Or share the Youtube video describing the project on your Facebook.

Thank you for your interest,

Happy dancing through life.

*All the dance artist rates are calculated based on CADA/WEST guidelines. Please see the link for more information*

http://cadawest.org/wp-content/uploads/CADAWest...
story_txt: Hi, I'm Kyra, I'm a professional dancer. I recently graduated from Simon Fraser University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Contemporary Dance and Sociology. I currently dance with a local company called La Caravan Dance Theatre. I am a dance instructor at Diversity Dance and Performing Arts, where I teach Ballet, Jazz, and Kinder Kids. I also assist adults with mental disabilities on a part time basis. I was inspired to make the dance film PEAKS after taking time to walk around Calgary and explore the public art pieces. While I was walking around looking at the pieces I found myself creating dance movement within them, on them, around them, and in front of them. After returning to the same art pieces again and again I was driven to develop the movement into choreography. Initially, I wanted to show what I had created at each location. Then I had the idea to create a dance film, that would capture all the art pieces and interesting movement possibilities and phrases. It was still art that inspired dance art, which lead to my vision for PEAKS. My vision has now evolved from an exploration to a personal objective to show people the local art work that is being produced in Calgary, as well as outside work that artist's have brought into the community. I also want to showcase local contemporary dancers who are committed to enriching the dance community and expanding it. The four minute film will be entered into 12 film festivals throughout North America and Europe. I will write applications for each and submit the film once it has been finalized. Upon acceptance, a larger audience will have the opportunity to view this film. Calgary is a younger city and many people don't know what is available here.  I want to bring awareness to its flourishing creativity and vibrant development through this film. We need your support to help bring awareness to Calgary's public art, music, and contemporary dance. Your contributions are essential to support each of the artists who are committed to this vision. In total I will need to raise $4500 to pay each artist for their professional contribution and hard work and to cover insurance costs as requested by the Bow Building downtown. Please have a look at the funding break down as follows:Videographer $1400 (10 hours of filming and 4 minutes of video editing @$100/hour).Dancers $1400 (For the total of five dancers - 3 dancers will attend 5 hours of rehearsal and 10 hours of filming, 1 will attend 3 hours of rehearsal and 3 hours of filming, and 1 dancer will attend 3 hours of rehearsal and 2 hours of filming all @$25/hour).Composer $600 (30 hours of creating and recording music @$20/hour).Choreography by Kyra Newton, $400 (4 minutes of dance choreography @$100/per minute produced)PAL Insurance $350 (as requested by the Bow Building the insurance covers liability coverage up to $5 million, in order to film at the Wonderland Sculpture for 2 hours). Submission fees to film festivals $350 (each film festival has a submission cost ranging from $20-$50)GRAND TOTAL $4500Meet The Team!2CreativeCo. is a digital marketing company specializing in identifying you from them. We provide video production services in various genres of film projects. We also provide creative and event photography services, as well as graphic design and aesthetic branding." Eric Smith is a professional musician who also goes by the name Rak, he is an Experimental/Psychedelic/Electronic/Rock Multi-Instrumentalist, Composer, Singer and Performer.Lindsay Oehlerking graduated from the University of Calgary with a Bachelor or Arts in Dance. She regularly performs in local choreographed work and instructs at Prestige Dance Academy. Laura Barcelo is a freelance dance performer, choreographer, and instructor in Calgary. She choreographs and instructs at Crossings Dance and The School of Alberta Ballet. In 2013 she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in psychology from Hope College, with a minor in dance, neuroscience, and ministry. She loves to create beautiful things for others to dwell upon.Kara Nolte is a freelance dance artist who recently moved to Calgary from Vancouver, where she graduated from the prestigious Arts Umbrella Professional Dance Program and is an alumnus of their world renowned Senior Dance Company. Her award-winning choreography has been shown in collaboration with Project Oswald in Calgary, at the Ignite Festival for Emerging Artists, DanceFest at NextFest in Edmonton, among many other festivals and showcases.Ruth Naomi Levin holds an MFA in Dance from York University and is a graduate of the School of Toronto Dance Theatre.  She is a company member with Calgary’s own La Caravan Dance Theatre and a member of The Margie Gillis Dance Foundation’s Legacy Project. She graduated from the University of Calgary with a Bachelor of Arts in Dance and concentration in Choreography and Performance. She has spent time expanding her contemporary dance knowledge in London, Amsterdam, Vienna, Berlin, and recently presented her new collaborative work [Sinking/Floating] abroad in Helsinki, Finland. Michalsky was part of the Lab Emerging Artist Program (LEAP) with Dancers’ Studio West where she performed with Dance Action Company in their 2016 show, Fear. In 2017, Michalsky looks forward to expanding her former choreographic work (Mis)Communication into an evening length show.Our film will represent Calgary in a new light, it will not only show case local talent but the artists who have helped contribute to the cities public spaces.   I am committed to creating the film and sharing it no matter what obstacles I face. story:
Short Summary

It’s 2015 and the United States is rife with violent arrests of young black men. Peaceful protests against the violent arrest and death of Freddy Gray, an unarmed black man turn into an all out riot overnight. The Baltimore Riots of 2015 were a breaking point for police brutality in the U.S. Man Down by Hannah Trujillo is an original play that examines racial violence through the lens of a romantic relationship.

 

Eva Ramirez and Michael Sterling’s unyielding love holds them together as a surge in police brutality against young black men ripples through the United States. Eva’s devotion to Michael is challenged when her estranged brother Eddie reappears asking to reconnect. Seemingly thuggish Freddie also reveals himself and complicates things for Michael.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Every dollar donated goes to our scenic, costume, and shipping needs. 

We need $1,600 for our scenic design. Which includes our set and props, as well as shipping costs. Because we're traveling from Los Angeles, some of our set needs to travel with us. These shipping costs if unfunded, can deter us from having the set we need to perform with.

We need $400 for our custom costume designs. Each character has two-three custom designed costumes. 

We need $200 to fully produce the original music for the show and share that on a streaming service.

 

If you contribute, we can send you personalized videos thanking you for your contribution, a copy of our original compositions, a producer credit, or you can also be invited to preview the show in LA before we travel to Edinburgh. 

BUT MOST OF ALL, 

YOU GET THE SATISFACTION OF KNOWING YOU SUPPORTED YOUNG ARTISTS ! 

 

The Impact

If we reach this financial goal, we can produce the show the way it is intended to be seen. 

Your donation also helps students, and graduates learn how to produce a theatrical performance or event. You also are creating a sense of community through your patronage, and supporting the work of young artists.

Your contribution helps give this team a life-changing experience making relevant and creative stories come to life in one of the biggest international theatre festivals.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please "Like" us on Facebook. https://www.facebook.com/mandowntheplay/

Please follow us on Twitter. https://twitter.com/mandowntheplay

Please follow us on Instagram. https://www.instagram.com/mandowntheplay/

And continue sharing our project with your friends and family and colleagues. We only survive with your word of mouth.

story:
********************************************

Tap here for all the logistics info

********************************************

Who We Are

Established in 2014 by Vattana Thach, Strive For Change is a socially conscious lifestyle brand that consists of influencers, artists, and organizers.

 

What We Do

We use art & influencers to drive attention to social problems. We then connect our audience to resources and organizations that work towards solving those problems.

We are practitioners of:

  • Truth
  • Passion
  • Empathy
  • Patience
  • Vulnerability
  • Love
  • Community

Our Convention - Purpose

Every year we come together to organize this event for the community. Our objective is to provide a space where education, expression, culture, business, vulnerability, and empathy can be explored and experienced. We understand that this sort of environment stimulates growth, friendship, and opportunity.

 

What makes us different?

We are adamant about the type of environment we aim to cultivate. We set the tone for our brand, our team, and the professionals we hire to come to share their energy from beginning to end.

This isn't a competitive space like most conventions that exist. Where it becomes less about the art, and more about what's cool and the accolades. From our knowledge, we are about 4-6 times more affordable than our peers in this space.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This year we are asking our community to help us reach our goal of $5000. Your generous contributions will go towards covering:

  • Venue
  • Insurance
  • Dance Instructors
  • Advertising
  • Photographer
  • Videographers
  • Sound System
  • Staff

Regardless of whether or not we reach our goal, we will still hold the convention. Our team is passionate about this event and its' purpose.

 

As A...

We have some perks in exchange for anyone who decides to donate to our event. There is no limit to the amount you can donate, and you can also donate without receiving perks. Check out the perks! :D (They may be updated even after the campaign is launched.)

The Impact

Our Analysis
The dance community as a whole is a very bright place. However, as dancers ourselves, we have noticed that as the community becomes more industrialized it's also grown a bit more shallow. As a result, many individuals have lost touch with the core reason why they ever started dancing.

Over the past few years, while dance has gotten much bigger, it's also become more intimidating for anyone who might have even the slightest interest to try and take a class.

On the other hand, even if they do take a class, they are usually met with extremely overwhelming combinations and sometimes may not get any sort of feedback from the instructor. It is usually then that some people decide that dance just isn't for them.

 



Addressing Our Analysis
We believe dance should always first and foremost be fun. We also believe it can be used as a tool to overcome personal hurdles as well as a way to communicate with others. At this convention, all of the instructors value your growth.

We care about delivering the best of what we have to offer at a pace that's reasonable to the level of the class.

 

Industry Panel - Educational Workshops

We found that the industry panel from previous years was very engaging and helpful to everyone there. Professionals who are active members in their communities (as well as the dance industry) shared personal stories and provided tips on what happens in their field of work and how they're trying to make an impact in their circles.

This year we are expanding the panel by providing 4 in-depth panels about things that are very crucial for dancers and aspiring entrepreneurs to know.

 

Community Conversation

The community conversation in previous years has served as a bridge between our attendees and the established programs and organizations. Although we have seen success with this portion of the convention. We have decided to end this endeavor.

 

 

Empowerment Workshop

We instead have decided to create an empowerment workshop. This would open up the convention and set the tone for the rest of the weekend. We are very excited to execute this new idea.

 

Community Features

We are still adamant about involving community organizations and leaders so we will be featuring them during our showcase.

 

Risks & Challenges

Coming up short financially is the biggest risk and challenge every year. As organizers, we are very capable of making sure all the pieces are in place so that everyone who attends the event has a phenomenal experience.

Our goal is to be able to pay everyone who contributes to this event as well as make a profit so we can put it aside for other major events we want to put together in the future.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

 

 

Share this campaign with everyone, every day, forever. :D :D :D

Thanks for your time. We will continue to work hard to create exceptional experiences for people! <3

story:
I am embarking on a campaign to produce a live theatrical multimedia play which incorporates film, and theater.  This production will take an introspective look into the mind of a writer who appears to have it all together, but the pressure to be successful,  a tumultuous home life and unresolved issues blur the line between art and torment.

My name is James Gillard   I am an accomplished filmmaker, playwright, and author.   My films, plays and books have been showcased throughout venues in the United States.   These stories focus on telling the stories of the African Diaspora that are true to the integrity of the global Black experience (struggles, identity, moral conflicts and social conditions).

SYNOPSIS

Darcy Sinclair is the new hot shot writer on the scene his essays and short stories on black life have garnered him fame.  He now embarks on his first book.  Funny thing is he's come down with a severe case of writers block.  It is here he meets a mysterious woman who encourages, seduces and torments him.  Darcy witnesses firsthand the whirlwind effects of substance abuse.  Unbeknownst to Darcy Sinclair he is about to write his greatest work -- his life.

WHY?

Growing up in the village of Harlem I witnessed the  damaging effects that alcohol/heroine and the crack could have on families.   Some of my immediate family members struggled with addictions -- which often made me wonder why would someone subject themselves to this inner torment.   In talking to a number of people battling addiction about 60% felt their abuse was a coping mechanism which provided a means of escape.  Which meant that their true issue was never addressed (identity, well-being or status) 

It was my goal to give a face to this issue.  Not just by showing stereotypical images but addressing those trigger points that can cause addiction.   In creating this story I soon found out that we all have the gene for addictive behavior and it can be displayed in some form or fashion.  

PRODUCTION

I would like to showcase this  play on four Sundays during the month of September (2nd, 9th, 16th and 23rd.).  matinee performance at 3:30 pm showtimes and dinner served.  We would like to create an atmosphere that allows patrons to really experience firsthand the provocative subject matter.  The production will incorporate  film and live actors.  

Your contribution would help to pay for actors fees, set design, wardrobe, and to secure all 4 dates in September.   Live theater events in Harlem are few and far between.   Due to huge rental fees it is extremely challenging for independent producers to secure theaters and if so they might only be able to have a 2 to 3 show run.  Which means a good production may never have a chance to have a following. 

I'm hoping hat the contribution you make will afford this production to  have staying power and serve as a catalyst for innovative producers to present theater in non theatrical environments.

Promo for the new theatrical production PENDEMONIJM"

 

THE IMPACT

Your contribution will further allow for further productions and fill a void in the theatrical landscape of one of the most important villages in the world (HARLEM).

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

Check out our wonderful perks which include producer credits and moe

And if you can't support financially feel free to share this post on your social networking platforms.  Every little bit helps.

 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  •

story:
What is Magic Butterfly?

Magic Butterfly is a brand-new ballet, set in Africa, that tells the story of a child who has been rewarded with an adventurous magical journey through Africa because she decided not to collect (kill) butterflies anymore. The dance is accompanied by LIVE classical music, telling stories and vignettes from Africa.

The music was expanded from two 15-minute tone poems, African Vignettes to an approximately 80-minute work for mixed chamber ensemble. 

Magic Butterfly is a world premiere of a work written, prepared and performed by local community talent.

Who?

Ballet performed by: The Highlands Ballet Company (HBC), directed and Choreographed by Deirdre Cole

Music performance: The Paramount Chamber Players (TPCP), directed by Dr. Craig Combs.

Music composed by: Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke

Magic Butterfly dancers will include members of The Highlands Ballet Company, students chosen from The Highlands Center for Ballet Arts, and professional danseurs*.

The production is a collaboration between HBC, TPCP, and the composer.  

When and Where?

Morning Performance for Schools, K-12:  March 15, 2019, McGlothlin Center for the Arts, Emory & Henry College, VA.

Evening Public Performance: March 15, 2019, McGlothlin Center for the Arts, Emory & Henry College, VA.

Evening Public Performance: March 16, 2019, The Paramount Center for the Arts, Bristol, TN

The performance will also include streaming for offsite audience members.

For More Information 

 

The Highlands Ballet Company 

  https://www.highlandsballet.org/

Studio:

 276-623-0822

Fax:

 423-878-3960

18174 Lee Highway

Abingdon, VA 24210

 

deirdre423@icloud.com

deecoler@icloud.com

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Simply put, the project needs $30,000 to be fully funded.  Through the Indiegogo campaign, we are seeking $10,000 to jump-start the project.

Even though we have been awarded a small grant from Virginia Commission for the Arts, this grant requires matching funds and doesn’t come close to covering the costs. Also, if we don’t raise the $$$, the grant goes back.

How Much & Where?

           The estimated costs for the project are as follows:

People’s Services: $17,300

Recording, Streaming, Danseurs (*paid male dancers), Creative work – Choreographer and Composer.

Places: - $3,700

Venue Rental and Tech Fees

Things: $8,400

Costumes (Purchased & Materials) for 50+ dancers; Props and Sets, including materials; Backdrop Rental; Programs.

TOTAL - $29,400

Perks

For a limited time, the Streaming Access perk will be included with ALL donation levels.

        ORCHESTRA 

        Our ORCHESTRA sponsorship package is a $100-$249 investment and includes the following:

        • 1/8 page black & white ad space in all HBC 2018-19 production programs
        • Logo on Highlands Ballet signature fundraiser t-shirt
        • 2 Ticket vouchers
        • Link for streaming 
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones     

        CORPS de BALLET

        Our CORPS DE BALLET sponsorship package is a $250 investment & includes the following:

        • 1/4 page black & white ad space in all HBC 2018-19 production programs
        • 2 ticket vouchers
        • Logo on Highlands Ballet signature t-shirt
        • Social media mentions throughout the 2018-19 season
        • 2 guests invited to attend a private patrons’ reception
        • Link for streaming
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones

        SOLOIST

        Our SOLOIST sponsorship package is a $500 investment & includes the following:

        • 1/ 4 page black & white ad space in all HBC 2018-19 production programs
        • 4 ticket vouchers 
        • Logo on Highlands Ballet signature fundraiser t-shirt
        • Social media mentions throughout the 2018-19 season
        • 4 guests invited to attend a private patrons’ reception 
        • Link for streaming
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones

        PRINCIPAL

        Our PRINCIPAL sponsorship package is a $1,000 investment & includes the following:

        • 1/2 page black & white ad space in all HBC 2018-19 production programs
        • 4 ticket vouchers 
        • Logo on Highlands Ballet signature t-shirt
        • Social Media Mentions throughout the 2018-19 season
        • 4 guests invited to attend a private patrons’ reception
        • Link for streaming
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones

        CHOREOGRAPHER

        Our CHOREOGRAPHER sponsorship packages is a $5,000 investment & includes the following:

        • Full page black & white ad space in all HBC 2018-19 production programs
        • 6 ticket vouchers 
        • Logo on Highlands Ballet signature t-shirt
        • Social Media Mentions throughout the 2018-19 season
        • 6 guests invited to attend a private patrons’ reception
        • Link for streaming
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones

        DIRECTOR

        Our DIRECTOR sponsorship package is a $10,000 investment and includes the following:

        • Full color back cover of Magic Butterfly program + full-page ad in all HBC productions during the 2018-19 performance season
        • 8 ticket vouchers                                                                            
        • Premium logo placement on Highlands Ballet signature t-shirt 
        • Social Media Mentions throughout 2018-19 season 
        • 8 guests invited to attend a private patrons’ reception
        • Recognition as official sponsor of Highlands Ballet's Magic Butterfly on all marketing collateral & program
        • Link for streaming
        • Ringtone for iPhone and Android phones

        **New perks for Magic Butterfly

        Free Commission for Custom Original Music by Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke

        $100+

        Baby/Pre-schooler Name Song* (Child learns to spell their name the way we learned the alphabet – singing it.)

        The spelling of your child’s name set to music.  Score only. *Composer retains copyright.

        $250+

        Baby/Pre-schooler Name Song* + Recording (Child learns to spell their name the way we learned the alphabet – singing it.)

        The spelling of your child’s name performed and recorded by composer. . *Composer retains copyright.

        $500+

        Short poem set to music*  

        Short public domain poem of your choice, for voice or guitar or piano, (~2:00 minutes), score only. (Composer reserves right of final choice of lyric. *Composer retains music copyright.)

        $1,000+

        Poem set to music* + Recording.

        Short public domain poem of your choice, for voice and guitar or piano, (2-4 minutes) performed and recorded by composer. (Composer reserves right of final choice of lyric. *Composer retains music copyright.)

        $5,000+

        Poem set to music* + Recording

        Public domain Poem of your choice for voice and piano, (4-6 minutes) performed and recorded by composer. (*Composer reserves right of final choice of lyric. *Composer retains music copyright.)

        $10,000

        Poem(s) set to music* + Recording

        Up to 3 public domain poems of your choice for voice and guitar or piano,

        (6-12 minutes) performed and recorded by composer. (*Composer reserves right of final choice of lyric. Composer retains music copyright.)

         

        Original lyrics, other accompaniment instruments or all-instrumental works are available.

         

         

        What if we don't reach our goal?  

        If the entire goal of $15,000 is not met, any funds raised will go to the project and a reduced budget will be implemented.  Several reduced budget scenarios have been planned out in the case of fundraising goals not being met.  It is the sincere hope of all collaborators that the goal will be met and that the success of this fundraising campaign will garner more enthusiastic support in other fundraising efforts for the project.  A grant in the amount of $4,200 has been secured from the Virginia Commission for the Arts as of the launch of this campaign. 

        About the Collaborators

        Highlands Ballet Company

        The Highlands Ballet Company (HBC) is a 501(C)(3) non-profit organization dedicated to the fine art of classical ballet and dance. The mission of HBC is to provide entertainment, educational and cultural opportunities in dance for Southwest Virginia and Northeast Tennessee and to promote the understanding, appreciation and enjoyment of dance. HBC offers young dancers training in theater arts and gives them opportunities to perform in live theater. HBC thrives on new choreography for classical and contemporary works.

        The Highlands Ballet Company and its primary feeder school, the Highlands Center for Ballet Arts, work together to help educate, provide support, and to prepare aspiring young dancers for whatever future they may desire! The school provides the foundation during the childhood years; while the Highlands Ballet Company offers advanced students the opportunity for further study and to share the special training and performing opportunities of a civic dance company.

        Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke, Composer

        Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke (MM in composition, University of TN, and over four decades of experience) is a Tanzania-born, active freelance composer and master musical story-teller who lives in northeast Tennessee. Her extensive and varied oeuvre has been heard from coast to coast in the US, and in Europe. She has repeatedly been commissioned to write for The Paramount Chamber Players.

        From the composer, Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke:  "The music I write always tells stories. The most wonderful thing about this project is that I get to tell my favorite tales from my childhood in Africa – some true, others make-believe. Every new musical work I write comes with homework: I study forms, instruments, and performers. This time, I researched ballet, and had a marvelous time attending Highlands Ballet Company’s productions. I’ve watched stories — told in dance — that are old, but somehow have become brand new. I’ve sat, mouth open, watching a cat-person that you’d swear was a real cat." 

        The Paramount Chamber Players

        The Paramount Chamber Players (TPCP), a 501(c)(3) organization, celebrates its 14th season in 2018 - 2019. TPCP is the premiere chamber ensemble in southwestern Virginia and northeast Tennessee, and presents twelve concerts each season (three each in Bristol, Kingsport, and Johnson City, TN and Abingdon, VA.)

        TPCP has commissioned and premiered 11 new works from local composers. Dr. Combs began commissioning new works with the call for composition in which Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke was a winner. The ensemble brought her unusual and delightful African Vignettes to the concert stage. When Dr. Combs and others suggested that that a ballet was the logical next step, Pursley-Kopitzke identified Deirdre Cole and the HBC as the visionary ballet company in the region capable of this project.

        TPCP will provide the live music accompaniment for Magic Butterfly at no cost to HBC as part of TPCP’s concert season.

        The Impact

        Magic Butterfly, the ballet, will have a multi-faceted positive impact on its southwestern Virginia, northeastern Tennessee, and online audiences, its ballet dancers, and the musicians. It will even affect non-audience members through the extensive media campaign that is planned.

        Community Benefit: Magic Butterfly brings to the region a cultural collage that is innovative and unprecedented. It will include new classical music with newly choreographed dancing, performed to live music, in collaboration with the composer. It tells a story set in an exotic locale from a child’s point of view, while retaining the engagement of adult audience members. The story, which includes love and loss, danger and rescue, beauty and sorrow, demonstrates the African experience and yet retains the universal human condition.

        Students and Teachers: Students and teachers from surrounding schools will be invited to the morning performance at a very low cost. For many, this may be their ONLY experience with a classical chamber ensemble or ballet. We are thrilled to present to them this unparalleled performance – especially if it’s their only exposure.

        Dancers: The Highlands Ballet Company dancers will be inspired by the Paramount Chamber Players’ rich, soul-feeding musical interpretations in real time. Since the classical music they have previously danced to has solely been recorded, the “magic” that only live music provides will be new territory for the dancers. They will FEEL the difference and that difference will translate into an artistic experience of the highest order. That feeling will also produce new levels of “magic” in their portrayals onstage, which will in turn be transmitted to the audience.

        Musicians: The Paramount Chamber Players (TPCP) are also exploring new territory. They, as an ensemble, have never before played for a ballet, or played from the orchestra pit. They will also be performing in a new-to-them venue, the McGlothlin Center, VA. In addition, performing for school children is new to TPCP. Performances for school children have not been part of their usual season. Even for an ensemble that regularly commissions and premieres new music, this collaborative production is new and exciting. They will be performing seven all-new movements and the preexisting 30 minutes will be rewritten longer.

        Beyond SWVA & NETN:  We are excited to present the world premiere of Magic Butterfly to the region and plan to tour the production, especially to under-served VA regions, in the future.  After HBC and The Paramount Chamber Players (TPCP) have premiered Magic Butterfly, almost all the elements will be in place for future performances, with or without live music.

        Magic Butterfly will also be available for licensing by other ballet companies. Since the music only requires six musicians it would be more financially affordable for them to have live music--without hiring an entire orchestra (100+ musicians). The recordings will also be available for production licensing.

        Magic Butterfly adds a distinctly viable option to ballet repertoire as a whole, and does so in a way that is innovative and culturally significant.

        Risks & Challenges

        As with any "new" project, especially within the genre of the performing arts, there are inherent risks in the production of such a work.  Due to the nature of this production - live music with original ballet choreography - this region has rarely been exposed to the performing arts in this form.  The uniqueness of the project offers great benefits to the region, as well as presenting risks for all involved in the project.  All collaborators on the project recognize the risks and negotiated budget constraints, venue prices and ticketing fees to lower costs and risks associated with the project.

        Because the Southwest Virginia population is low density, made up of small communities widely scattered across the mountains and valleys of "coal country," performances of this scale, especially with live music, are rare.  People who frequent Barter Theatre or Music Department performances at Emory & Henry College will be expected to attend, as well as people who have never been to a major stage performance of chamber music or ballet. 

        Audience at the Paramount Center performance will expand the faithful Paramount Chamber Players' audience, including many from Bristol, VA, and Abingdon, VA. Because Highlands Ballet Company will be guest performers with The Paramount Chamber Players, Highlands Ballet Company will not control ticket prices. The Paramount Chamber Players' ticket prices are usually $15 for adults, and often, free for students. The Paramount Chamber Players is able to keep prices low to attract a wider demographic through the generosity of their many patrons.  The overall low-cost and value in the ticket prices reduces the risk of venues being left "half-sold."

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Even if you can't contribute monetarily, that doesn't mean you can't help:

        • Share, share, share the campaign on every social media tool you use.  The more people who know about the campaign and Magic Butterfly, the more likely it is to succeed.
        • Share the YouTube link https://youtu.be/DCU0IbNjBvE to the promotional videos so that others can learn about this unique and exciting ballet coming to the region.  The more people who see the video, the increased number of ticket sales the production will have. 
        • Use the Indiegogo share tools right from the campaign page -- it's that simple!
story_txt:
What is Magic Butterfly?
Magic Butterfly is a brand-new ballet, set in Africa, that tells the story of a child who has been rewarded with an adventurous magical journey through Africa because she decided not to collect (kill) butterflies anymore. The dance is accompanied by LIVE classical music, telling stories and vignettes from Africa.
The music was expanded from two 15-minute tone poems, African Vignettes to an approximately 80-minute work for mixed chamber ensemble. 
Magic Butterfly is a world premiere of a work written, prepared and performed by local community talent.
Who?
Ballet performed by: The Highlands Ballet Company (HBC), directed and Choreographed by Deirdre Cole
Music performance: The Paramount Chamber Players (TPCP), directed by Dr. Craig Combs.
Music composed by: Evelyn Pursley-Kopitzke
Magic Butterfly dancers will include members of The Highlands Ballet Company, students chosen from The Highlands Center for Ballet Arts, and professional danseurs*.
The production is a collaboration between HBC, TPCP, and the composer.  
When and Where?
Morning Performance for Schools, K-12:  March 15, 2019, McGlothlin Center for the Arts, Emory & Henry College, VA.
Evening Public Performance: March 15, 2019, McGlothlin Center for the Arts, Emory & Henry College, VA.
Evening Public Performance: March 16, 2019, The Paramount Center for the Arts, Bristol, TN
The performance will also include streaming for offsite audience members.
For More Information 
 


The Highlands Ballet Company 
  https://www.highlandsballet.org/



Studio:
 276-623-0822
Fax:
 423-878-3960


18174 Lee Highway
Abingdon, VA 24210


 
deirdre423@icloud.com
deecoler@icloud.com
 



 
What We Need & What You Get
Simply put, the project needs $30,000 to be fully funded.  Through the Indiegogo campaign, we are seeking $10,000 to jump-start the project.
Even though we have been awarded a small grant from Virginia Commission for the Arts, this grant requires matching funds and doesn’t come close to covering the costs. Also, if we don’t raise the $$$, the grant goes back.
How Much & Where?
           The estimated costs for the project are as follows:
People’s Services: $17,300 
Recording, Streaming, Danseurs (*paid male dancers), Creative work – Choreographer and Composer.
Places: - $3,700
Venue Rental and Tech Fees
Things: $8,400 
Costumes (Purchased & Materials) for 50+ dancers; Props and Sets, including materials; Backdrop Rental; Programs.
TOTAL - $29,400

story:
Folk Dance Remixed believes in diversity, creativity and spreading joy. Our shows and workshops show off the best that can be achieved when people work together, sharing their cultures, their music, their dance moves - their positivity! Our inspiring workshops get families up and dancing together and strangers holding hands and laughing within minutes, our work truly touches all that come into contact with it!

Our current show, Step Hop House, depicts the coming together of diverse travellers to a new land and how they work and play together – mixing together folk, hip-hop, live music, Bollywood, capoeira, African, contemporary, beatbox and maypole traditions into a funky folkyness!

What We Need & What You Get

We need £2000 from our crowdfunding appeal to help keep us devise new shows and participatory workshops for children, young people, families and adults.

Your donation will help us do more education and training work with young people, dance learners and workshop leaders. It also helps support us devising new work and linking with musicians, script writers and other choreographers.

Your money will secure the creativity and research needed to bring new ideas and formats to rehearsal, and enable the company to spend valuable time developing our innovative brand of funked up folkyness to delight audiences across the country. It will contribute to studio time for the artistic directors to experiment and devise; rehearsal costs for the company; costume development; technical experimentation and equipment (those maypole ribbons need to be shiny and perfect each time you see them!).

Every £1 donation helps make our grants and support go further and helps secure our hard work and innovation. Our crowdfunding donations will be combined with our current Arts Council England grant, and our in-kind support from partners East London Dance and the English Folk Dance and Song Society.
Please donate what you can to keep this joyous and eclectic company pushing forwards into the ground breaking territory. Every £1 helps keeps us creating! THANK YOU!

The Impact

Our work brings people together – it creates connections, makes people laugh and enjoy a dynamic and colourful spectacle. Don’t take our word for it – here’s some comments from people that have worked with us and seen our work themselves:

 “It was wonderful to see so many young people from across the North West performing at the beginning of U Dance 2016.  The blend of traditional folk dance and contemporary hip hop clearly enabled all the young people to express their individuality.  The piece seemed to bring folk dance to life for a new generation and the energy and obvious enthusiasm of the performers was infectious!  It was great to see traditional folk dance embraced as a vibrant part of young people’s dance in the UK.” 

Ginny Brown, Head of Education & Training, Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing

 

We received some wonderful comments about your performances and workshops and how they were engaging and inclusive as well as visually stunning!

Rachel Wood, Arts Development Officer, Oldham Council

 

The dancers were wonderful, as were the musicians, and I was thrilled to see the fantastic ceilidh take-up at the end, bought a lump to my throat as these things always do when done so well.

Michael Hambridge, Arts and Cultural Development Officer, Hastings Borough Council

 

Street Dance the Maypole was a brilliant visual focal point, filling the space with colours and energy. The teachers were quick to adapt the level of the workshop to the ability of the participants ... everyone really enjoyed themselves!

Lina Johansson, Joint Artistic Director of Mimbre

 

Thank you again for making the show energetic and dynamic – everyone enjoyed your performance!  

Rozina Ahmed, Senior Events Officer, Events for London, Mayor’s Office

 ‘I just wanted to say how much I enjoyed the show last night – a great mix of dance styles blended into a cohesive performance full of energy, skill and a real sense of joy!  Lovely costumes and colourful props created a terrific environment in which to perform.  All the elements worked well (I loved the “mumming” reference!) and I can see the potential (as you surely can) for this to grow into a bigger show with educational aspects and huge workshop potential.’  

Barry Goodman, President of The Morris Federation

Opportunity to see cutting-edge real/ genuine “folk dance” of today. The sensational performance – when it finished I wanted to see it again, immediately. Loved the mix, meld and marriage of styles that is creating a new tradition.

Jacqueline Beattie, audience member 

Fabulous creative performance. The workshops are fun.

Dodie Lambminder, audience member

Risks & Challenges

We are always ducking and diving – being efficient and nifty with all our expenditure, reusing and revising our resources, our costumes, our admin and management, our sets and equipment… and ideas! We believe this is fundamental to our creativity and keeps us on our toes – but we also need additional support to have valuable time to think, plan, devise and develop into the future. This is where we need your support!  If we get the planning and devising right then we’re confident we can produce some stunning new ideas and performances – we’ve got so many great ideas, and just need some support to make those a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that money is tight. If you can’t contribute the hard cash you can still really help and support us by putting the word out to local event and festival promoters, schools, dance groups and dance agencies and tell them about our work. And you can pass on the news about this campaign and encourage people to join us!  THANK YOU!
story_txt:
Folk Dance Remixed believes in diversity, creativity and spreading joy. Our shows and workshops show off the best that can be achieved when people work together, sharing their cultures, their music, their dance moves - their positivity! Our inspiring workshops get families up and dancing together and strangers holding hands and laughing within minutes, our work truly touches all that come into contact with it!Our current show, Step Hop House, depicts the coming together of diverse travellers to a new land and how they work and play together – mixing together folk, hip-hop, live music, Bollywood, capoeira, African, contemporary, beatbox and maypole traditions into a funky folkyness!
What We Need & What You Get
We need £2000 from our crowdfunding appeal to help keep us devise new shows and participatory workshops for children, young people, families and adults.
Your donation will help us do more education and training work with young people, dance learners and workshop leaders. It also helps support us devising new work and linking with musicians, script writers and other choreographers.
Your money will secure the creativity and research needed to bring new ideas and formats to rehearsal, and enable the company to spend valuable time developing our innovative brand of funked up folkyness to delight audiences across the country. It will contribute to studio time for the artistic directors to experiment and devise; rehearsal costs for the company; costume development; technical experimentation and equipment (those maypole ribbons need to be shiny and perfect each time you see them!).
Every £1 donation helps make our grants and support go further and helps secure our hard work and innovation. Our crowdfunding donations will be combined with our current Arts Council England grant, and our in-kind support from partners East London Dance and the English Folk Dance and Song Society.Please donate what you can to keep this joyous and eclectic company pushing forwards into the ground breaking territory. Every £1 helps keeps us creating! THANK YOU!
The Impact
Our work brings people together – it creates connections, makes people laugh and enjoy a dynamic and colourful spectacle. Don’t take our word for it – here’s some comments from people that have worked with us and seen our work themselves:
 “It was wonderful to see so many young people from across the North West performing at the beginning of U Dance 2016.  The blend of traditional folk dance and contemporary hip hop clearly enabled all the young people to express their individuality.  The piece seemed to bring folk dance to life for a new generation and the energy and obvious enthusiasm of the performers was infectious!  It was great to see traditional folk dance embraced as a vibrant part of young people’s dance in the UK.” 
Ginny Brown, Head of Education & Training, Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing
 
We received some wonderful comments about your performances and workshops and how they were engaging and inclusive as well as visually stunning!
Rachel Wood, Arts Development Officer, Oldham Council
 
The dancers were wonderful, as were the musicians, and I was thrilled to see the fantastic ceilidh take-up at the end, bought a lump to my throat as these things always do when done so well.
Michael Hambridge, Arts and Cultural Development Officer, Hastings Borough Council
 
Street Dance the Maypole was a brilliant visual focal point, filling the space with colours and energy. The teachers were quick to adapt the level of the workshop to the ability of the participants ... everyone really enjoyed themselves!
Lina Johansson, Joint Artistic Director of Mimbre
 
Thank you again for making the show energetic and dynamic – everyone enjoyed your performance!  
Rozina Ahmed, Senior Events Officer, Events for London, Mayor’s Office
 ‘I just wanted to say how much I enjoyed the show last night – a great mix of dance styles blended into a cohesive performance full of energy, skill and a real sense of joy!  Lovely costumes and colourful props created a terrific environment in which to perform.  All the elements worked well (I loved the “mumming” reference!) and I can see the potential (as you surely can) for this to grow into a bigger show with educational aspects and huge workshop potential.’  
Barry Goodman, President of The Morris Federation
Opportunity to see cutting-edge real/ genuine “folk dance” of today. The sensational performance – when it finished I wanted to see it again, immediately. Loved the mix, meld and marriage of styles that is creating a new tradition.
Jacqueline Beattie, audience member 
Fabulous creative performance. The workshops are fun.
Dodie Lambminder, audience member
Risks & Challenges
We are always ducking and diving – being efficient and nifty with all our expenditure, reusing and revising our resources, our costumes, our admin and management, our sets and equipment… and ideas! We believe this is fundamental to our creativity and keeps us on our toes – but we also need additional support to have valuable time to think, plan, devise and develop into the future. This is where we need your support!  If we get the planning and devising right then we’re confident we can produce some stunning new ideas and performances – we’ve got so many great ideas, and just need some support to make those a reality.
Other Ways You Can Help
We know that money is tight. If you can’t contribute the hard cash you can still really help and support us by putting the word out to local event and festival promoters, schools, dance groups and dance agencies and tell them about our work. And you can pass on the news about this campaign and encourage people to join us!  THANK YOU!

story:
A play about identity and appearance that explores not only how others see us, but how we see ourselves. Reasons to Be Pretty examines two couples at crossroads in their relationships, as they grapple with societal expectations of beauty, their notions of self-worth, and the ramifications of toxic masculinity.  Reasons to be Pretty is a an important exploration about feminism, and the subliminal expectation society pushes on young men. When Greg makes a seemingly harmless comment about his girlfriend Steph’s face, the information gets back to Steph and sends their relationship over the deep end.

As a theatre creators we are committed to producing work that allows marginalized or underrepresented voices to be heard and this play is no exception. We are incredibly proud to be working with a 80% female team of emerging artists to bring this important piece to life using a collaborative creative process. 

We first discovered the play in 2017, during a scene study class at Sheridan College. We fell in love with the fast pace of the text combined with the raw intensity of the characters, an actor’s dream to play. But the more we discussed this play, the more relevant it became. LaBute has expertly taken larger social issues and examined how they actually manifest in everyday life. These characters are just trying to figure out who they are, in a world that often makes this kind of vulnerable self discovery impossible, something that many people in our generation can relate to. 

 

Your donation would support this exciting team of emerging young artists and enrich this important exploration and discussion of feminism and toxic masculinity in our community! Funds would be allocated to rehearsal space/venue rental, production rights, and artistic profit share.

Funds would be allocated to rehearsal space/venue rental, production rights, and artistic profit share.

story:
Who We Are:

Theatre Evolve is a new company based in Chicago that is focused not on the type of theatre we create, but the way we create it. Our goal is to be a foothold for emerging artists in the city to develop their skills, resumes, and expand their network. We are doing that by employing a minimum of 50% new artists, whether that be actors, designers, playwrights, or directors with every single production we do.

As we embark on our mission to develop upcoming artists in the Chicago community, we recognize and value the importance of inclusion in our work. We are committed to reflecting the diversity of our nation’s culture at all levels: on our stage, in our audience, and on our staff.

Where We Are Going:

We are thrilled to fulfill our mission of artistic and professional development by producing a brand new play, by a brand new playwright! Human Resources by Sara Means is the sometimes-too-familiar story of corporate America and the extremes of clawing one's way to the top. It is fast, sharp, satirical, and over-caffeinated and we are thrilled to give it it's world premiere. Theatre Evolve is one of the first companies to rent the new blackbox space at the Edge Theater in Edgewater, Chicago for this production. We think it's going to be a wonderful facility for the team to work and play in, and look forward to welcoming our audiences to a shiny new space! Just as Sara Means and the artists we work with evolve, so will our company in our second season.

As a new non-profit organization, we will be selecting a board of directors to help shape and guide our work in Chicago.

Additionally, we look forward to offering classes between our season's productions. We are working on curricula that develop theatre makers artistically, as well as classes to help with the business side of being a working creative in the city. Resume and audition polishing? Quite possibly! Financial and tax workshops? Hello, I need that.

In listening for what our theatre community here in Chicago is needing developmentally, Theatre Evolve is also tuned in to the events of the world as a whole. As we move forward in shaping our season and selecting future shows, we intend to reflect what we hear and learn. We hope you will join us for those conversations and stories in our second season.

Where We’ve Been:

It was a long journey with a lot of T’s to cross and I’s to dot but we finally became an official 501©3, which means your donation is now tax deductible! 

In our 2018 Season, we produced an incredible production of Twelfth Night filled with some of Chicago most amazing artists. Our three-week run had multiple sold out nights and rave reviews from our audience!

Additionally, we produced our first REvolve reading series! After a month of reading through the 260 play submissions we received from all over the country, we narrowed it down to seven 10-min plays and two full length pieces. With packed houses we were honored to produce REvolve with over 30 actors, playwrights, and directors.

So Now The Real Question:
         

We are asking for $8000 to fully fund our next production, cover insurance for the full year, and make sure everyone gets paid for the hard work they are doing.

Budget Breakdown:
Theatre Rental: $3,200
Rehearsal Space Rental: $800
Actors Stipends: $600
Designers Stipends: $1000
Play Royalties: $500
Props/Set/Costumes: $1000
Insurance: $800
____________________________
Total: $7,900

Other Ways You Can Help:

We completely understand if you can’t make a financial donation. But there are other ways to help get Theatre Evolve’s production of Human Resources up and running.

1. Please let all your friends and family know about this Indiegogo campaign. Even your crazy Aunt Clara. Tweet about it. Facebook about it. Instagram, Snap, Message, Text, Email away. Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us spread the word. This is the most important thing you can do!

2. If you’re a Chicago business owner and you’d like to get involved in some way – whether it be taking an ad in the program or donating goodies for the opening night party, get in touch with us at theatreevolve@gmail.com

3. Please come see the show! We run from June 10 through July 6 and we’d love to share the piece with you. Tickets go on sale in May of 2019!

FOR MORE INFO, VISIT www.theatreevolve.com
