story:
Hi,

I’m Phelim McAleer. You might know me from the Gosnell book and movie or the FERGUSON Play. I’ve always wanted to tell stories that the establishment and the mainstream media want to ignore, so I want to tell you about my latest play and how you can help.

My new play exposes how environmentalists carried out the world’s biggest fraud, how the media helped promote the fraud, and how they almost got away with it. 

The play, called The $18-Billion Prize, will open at the Phoenix Theater in San Francisco on May 19th and run until June 3rd. 

I co-wrote it with Jonathan Leaf and it tells the story of a lawsuit, led by New York lawyer Steven Donziger, against the Chevron oil company. The lawsuit alleged Chevron destroyed the rainforest in Ecuador and poisoned the natives. It was successful, and an Ecuadorian court awarded the plaintiffs a staggering $18 billion. Yes, BILLION. This was the biggest ever award in a civil court, but it was ALSO the biggest fraud in history.

Haven’t heard about it?? Funny. The same media that reported endlessly on the so-called “pollution” went pretty quiet when the case turned out to be a fraud. And a load of Hollywood celebrities who helped promote the fraud have also gone very quiet recently. Yes I'm talking about you Sting, Mia Farrow and Danny Glover.

The play shows how the plaintiffs, led by Donziger, bribed the judge and ghost wrote the judgment that awarded them this massive amount. And they were helped on their fraud by a cheerleading media that reported the allegations as fact but have been silent as the truth was revealed.

The scope of the fraud was enormous and at times farcical. Along with bribing judges, they used ludicrous code words to describe the top secret payments. It was all revealed when a New York court, realizing that something was amiss, ordered Donziger to hand over his files. In those files and diaries, Donziger admitted illegal bribes to judges and court officials as he wondered if he had “done a deal with the devil.”

The play reveals all the incredible details, and we have an amazing cast with Richard Kuhlman directing. He loves the play and has already made some stunning changes and suggestions. It is hilarious in places, revealing the madness and hypocrisy of the celebrities who went to Ecuador to “support the natives.” It turns some of them were secretly paid an absolute fortune, and you will laugh and cry when you see how they behaved when they thought the cameras were switched off. They also didn't know it was all recorded in his files by Steven Donziger.

The $18-Billion Prize reveals the dark side of the environmental movement, where campaigners such as Donziger go to remote locations and use locals as props in their ideological war against American corporations. In one of the most outrageous examples, Donziger secretly fought and stopped the Ecuadorian government from cleaning up their pollution because it wouldn’t look good for his case. Donziger was also going to become very rich in the process. He stood to pocket $1.2 billion before the fraud was uncovered.

I’d love for you to come and see the play. You can buy a ticket through Indiegogo by going to ChevronPlay.com. But I need your help to ensure this play gets on stage and the truth gets out there. The theater establishment and the mainstream media don’t want this play to succeed. They want to cover up the story, and they certainly won’t fund it or support it. That’s why I’m crowdfunding. 

Many of you have been supportive of my projects in the past. We broke world records with the Gosnell movie, and the FERGUSON Play made it on stage despite the best attempts of those who wanted it to disappear--nine members of the cast walking out during rehearsals. They do not want the truth out. That’s why crowdfunding is so important. 

I need $75,000 to ensure the play gets on stage and continues its run. Once the play is up and running, the mainstream media will be forced to review it, and the truth about this massive fraud will be revealed. 

So please go to ChevronPlay.com and give what you can. We have lots of great rewards. My favorite one is the Donziger Diary seized by the courts, which reveals the mechanics of the massive bribery scheme and just how celebs behave when they are let loose in the jungle. Let’s just say Sting and his wife Trudie Styler won’t be too happy when it is published...or when the play goes on stage.

So please give what you can to ensure that The $18-Billion Prize goes on stage and the truth is revealed.

Thanks for your help,

Phelim

-------------------------------------------------------

PERFORMANCES

Phoenix Theatre 

414 Mason Street | San Francisco | 94102

Preview: Friday, May 18th @ 8pm

Opening: Saturday, May 19th @ 8pm

Sunday, May 20th @ 3pm

Thursday, May 24th @ 8pm

Friday, May 25th @ 8pm

Saturday, May 26th @ 8pm

Sunday, May 27th @ 3pm

Thursday, May 31st @ 8pm

Friday, June 1st @ 8pm

Saturday, June 2nd @ 8pm

Closing: Sunday June 3rd @ 3pm

story:
Hello!

We're Playwright Charlene Donaghy and Producer/Director William Brown. We’ve had success with plays in New York City and around the country, and Charlene's collection of plays, Bones of Home and Other Plays, published by Hansen Publishing Group, will transport you to New Orleans.

Our current, exciting project is Charlene's full-length stage play The Quadroon and the Dove, set in 1841 New Orleans where secrets fuel betrayals and threaten the delicate balance of a world poised on the precipice of change. The Quadroon and the Dove is a stunning historical portrait of power, gender and race where the price to pay for love is absolute. This unforgettable story is wrapped in pain, beauty, mystery, lust and true love. It reveals a little known time in American history that continues to reverberate in our modern culture today.

What people are saying about The Quadroon and the Dove: 

“With plays that are intoxicating and mysterious, Donaghy has a gift for finding the truth that lurks below our eccentricities.” - Doug Wright, Tony Award winning playwright

The Quadroon and the Dove gives audiences “…a close up look at not only the lengths people will go to attain their heart’s desire, but the obsessions that drive them there.”  - Melissa Wrap, of The Memphis Daily Helmsman

"Charlene writes stories that give voice beyond the boundaries of race, sex, or privilege, painting pictures of human conditions, taking her audiences on journeys through the gift and magic of her words." - Jackie Davis, Artistic Director New Urban Theatre Laboratory

"Charlene is not afraid to take her readers and audience to the dark places—whether that's during a contentious time in history, a city's complex past or a character's uncontrollable desire.  For it is through her exploration of the dark, that Charlene ultimately shows us the light in all of humanity." - Jami Brandli, author, Technicolor Life, BLISS 

What we need and what you get...

We're raising $8,000 to continue the ongoing development of the play, including January readings at The Players Club in New York City for Broadway insiders, theatre supporters, friends and colleagues.   

Madison Square Productions has brought on-board the newest members of our team, Binder Casting, to secure unforgettable Broadway talent to bring this world, and these characters, to life.   

And we're turning to our friends, fans, colleagues to help us reach our goal. For your support, we're offering great perks...from endless gratitude to insider updates and photos and even the ability to see the development of this amazing project up close and first-hand!

Your contribution will help us continue the work of bringing this historic and entertaining play, which resonates with present-day struggles, to the stage and to audiences everywhere. 

Help us tell this story of power, gender, and race…of home…of love…of what it means to be human. 

We hope you can contribute with a donation and, either way, we hope you’ll share this campaign with friends, family, and on social media. 

Thanks so much!

story:
We are 7 female theater-makers/interdisciplinary artists hailing from New York City, Boston, and the Dominican Republic, with an astounding talented team of designers and visionaries behind us! Some of the many credits of our team include: international theater tours, Off-Broadway, TV, published artists, and numerous awards in film and design.

 

Artistic Director, Executive Producer, Actor

Elena Kritter

Associate Producer, Actor

Alida Rose Delaney

Co-Creators, Actors

Madeline Barr

Elizabeth Chahin

Josephine Cooper

Alexis Ingram

Maggie Ronck

Director

Kathleen Anne Hefferon

 

Dramaturg

Max Sklar

 

Production Consultant

Mariel O'Connell

 

Set Engineer

Captain, Gene Kritter

 

Original Score

Joey Giallombardo 

 

Sound Design

*To read more about our ensemble members, visit our website.

 

We’ve Achieved Phase 1!

We developed Night Witches during a month-long residency on Ground Rush Farm in Culpeper, Virginia. An all female team of theatre artists worked tirelessly for 3 weeks to create this hour and a half play from scratch, utilizing conventional realism, physical theatre, music, dance, acro-yoga, and shadow puppetry. We were then fortunate enough to share our play with audiences at Lynchburg College and Culpeper residents in an airplane hangar on the farm. In New York, we held an invitation-only workshop performance at the famous William Esper Studio. As a company, we strive to share this story with a diverse group of people– from New York theatre-goers to small town farmers who have never been to the theatre before. The story of these women’s bravery is compelling for everyone!

Phase I Checklist:

  • Met with members of the 99’s - the International Organization of Female Pilots 
  • Interviewed with the National Agricultural Aviation Association about our use of aviation in research for the show. You can read the article here.
  • Shared the story of the Night Witches with the Warrenton Chapter of the Virginia Aeronautical Historical Society 
  • Attended “Women Can Fly” event, which empowers women in aviation through free flying lessons

 

HYLTON TICKETS | THE MUSE TICKETS | DIXON PLACE TICKETS

  • Costumes - for repairs

  • Set - for repairs

5) Amenities & Other Administrative Fees - 

  • Food
  • Labor - extra set of hands to help unload/reload our set on performance dates
  • Copyright Fee - official Copyright of the script by the U.S. Government
  • Wiggle - towards any extra costs or added fees 

 

We've got some awesome gifts lined up as a THANK YOU for your generosity! Stuff that you'll actually want! With products from start-up's founded by women, to feminist companies, to small Etsy shops. We've got you covered :)

 

 

Night Witches is the story of the brave female members of the Soviet air force and their dramatic efforts against the Nazis during World War II. Inspired by Anne Noggle’s A Dance with Death, a compilation of the women’s direct accounts of their own vivid memories. The play introduces glimpses of pre-war life, the unrelenting rigors of war, and the lasting power of sisterhood. These women, the first ever to fly in combat, proved that they could be among the best of warriors and equal to their male counterparts. From inexperienced girls - many of them teenagers - to hardened pilots. To each other, they were sisters. To many of their male comrades, they were a waste of army resources. To the Germans, however, they remained the Night Witches.

A sneak peek at our Costume Design mood board - farmer meets aviation 

 

(Ground Rush Productions LLC)

With some research under our belts and a whole lot of determination, we packed our bags and traveled to Culpeper, VA. For one month we lived, cooked, laughed, cried, and created together. It was an intense experience and challenging on our hearts, souls, and bodies - working well over 9 hours a day. The Night Witches and their friendships is the basis to our own personal bonds that will last a life-time. So much of Night Witches was inspired by the farms' landscape, post-dinner conversations, and everyday farm life.

 

The 588th Night Bomber Aviation Regiment was one of three female Soviet units during World War II. Formed by Marina Raskova - a Russian Amelia Earhart - it was the only unit to remain exclusively female throughout the war. In the dead of night, they flew repurposed crop dusting biplanes to bomb Nazi forces on the front lines. These girls worked as pilots, navigators, mechanics, armorers, and operated continuously without break, rest, or leave for three years of the war. Flying against the Luftwaffe in open-cockpit biplanes with no radios, parachutes, or armor, they saw many of their friends - as well as their foes - fall to Earth in flames. Performing over 24,000 missions, the regiment was awarded Elite Guards Status and 24 of them were awarded the highest distinction in the country, the Hero of the Soviet Union medal.

Stories of the Night Witches and their deeds were largely suppressed and forgotten after the war. “Do not talk about the services you rendered, let others do it for you," were the words uttered by then President Kalinin to the women who served and suffered for their country. Soviet records are scarce but according to histories compiled by the women pilots after the war, 112 of them flew to the front. Over thirty of them were killed in action.

Women’s Air Force Service Pilot (WASP) Anne Noggle interviewed dozens of Night Witches in the early 90s and compiled their stories into her book: A Dance With Death. In her conclusion, she remarks, “They had gathered as a remembrance, a celebration. They are sisters, they will tell you - closer to one another than to their own relatives. Ultimately their memento mori is one of survival, haunted by ghosts of those not so fortunate.”

 

  • Volunteer to help set up our stage for our New York performances on October 21st, 22nd, and 26th and attend the performance(s) for F-R-E-E. Email us for more: nightwitchesplay@gmail.com
  • Attend our performances in Virginia (see show poster with information above)
  • Attend our performances in New York (see show poster with information above)
  • Share the hashtag #NightWitches
  • Spread the word about the campaign - those who love the arts and stories about war heroes and badass women!
  • Follow us on our Facebook and Instagram

 

  • "Night Witches Gets NYC Workshops," Broadway World
  • “Take Wing with the Night Witches,”  The Daily Progress
  • “Dominican Actress Elizabeth Chahin excels abroad” América Tejeda Magazine
  • “Way Off Broadway” Agricultural Aviation Magazine

 

Phase II is just the first of many steps in developing Night Witches. As our team continues to grow, we intend to apply for a 501(c)3, as well as submit to several theater festivals including the annual Edinburgh Fringe Festival and The Public Theater's, Under the Radar Festival– "a premier launching pad for new and cutting-edge performance from the U.S. and abroad."  We hope to continue making theatre more accessible– touring Night Witches in airplane hangars across the country.

story:
WHO WE ARE

Ananya Dance Theatre is a professional dance company of primarily women artists of color who create “People Powered Dances of Transformation.” We are cultural activists, working through dance and artistic processes to engage audiences, build community, and move toward social justice and beauty.

 

OUR PROJECT

"Shyamali" explores how dissent fuels life force and growth, recognizes the courage of women who speak up and talk back to sustain communities against injustice, and celebrates women who refuse to be broken. 

Inspired by the courage of women around the world, “Shyamali” means “dark green” in Bengali, and invokes the resilience of grass, which springs up when trod upon.

Ananya Chatterjea's choreography combines the metaphor and poetry of Contemporary Indian Dance in a movement practice anchored in social justice as it invokes the spirit of Dakini, traditionally embodied by destruction, chaos, and transformation. 

Dakini lives in the possibilities of audiences' and performers' discomfort and insists that the role of women's rage and their spiritual ecstasy be seen in the arc towards equity. This tumult resolves through choreography that weaves ritualistic performance and dances of the gentle warrior.

Chatterjea's production team includes the dancers of Ananya Dance Theatre, collaborating director Marcus Young, composer Greg Schutte, scenic designer Joel Sass, media designer Darren Johnson, costume designer Annie Cady, lighting designer Kevin A. Jones, production manager Emma Marlar, and stage manager Toan Doan.

"Shyamali" will be presented at The O'Shaughnessy at St. Catherine University, Friday-Saturday, September 15-16, 2017.

 

MAGNITUDE OF CONTRIBUTIONS

We are committed to honoring the creative labor of all the artists and collaborators in our process. This includes providing the materials and resources needed to bring their designs and efforts to fruition.

Your support puts in place the final piece of our project budget and lifts us to the realm of theatrical production excellence. Through the collective imagery of layered movement, haunting sound scores, suggestive scenery, customized costumes, and dynamic lighting, viewers will know they have witnessed and experienced the epic stories of courageous women and dissent.

 

IMPACT

Every dollar that you contribute to our campaign helps manifest stories of women and dissent. You help to pay artists and cultural activists who are mining their memories and histories for this work. You help support the costs of scenic design as we draw from contemporary life issues and incorporate them into the work to tell the stories of our community. You help create a costume for a dancer.

Most of all, you help provide your fellow audience members with a top-notch theatrical experience!

Here’s what people have said say about the kind of work that you are supporting:

"I wept at the end of your show because it....reminded me of the power of art to change minds and feelings, to build community, to love, to believe in the possibilities of our dreams." –Soyini Madison, Professor, Northwestern University

“A revolution.…ends with the performers leading an exuberant celebration in the aisles.” –Caroline Palmer, Star Tribune

“The audience at the National Theater was fully engaged with this social justice-themed dance performance and was cheering after each section.” –Tibebeselassie Tigabu, The Reporter, Ethiopia

“Exceptional and pivotal in my personal and dance journey.…This company continues and strives to keep us ‘woke’ and conscious in our community and abroad.…Be ready for ADT to break you off in the most fierce way.” –Audience member

“Absolutely stunning and important.…Powerful work, discipline, story and hearts. Thanks for a wonderful evening, a Friday's rainy eve incredibly well spent.” –Audience member

“Creates a deep interaction with its audience, engaging them in a dialogue.…about the world in which we live and the barriers above which we can rise to taste the world with a bit more truth than how it is fed to us.” –Clarence White, Saint Paul Almanac

“Created and performed at a totally different level. The percussive dance perfectly accenting the music, the music took me on a complete journey and kept my head and body moving in my seat. The poems and spoken word pieces helped to guide me through this journey. The solos were nothing less than amazing, the lighting was perfect, and the beginning created a social/community atmosphere....Thank you for birthing this work and sharing it with the world.” –Audience member

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Large-scale theatrical works about issues and stories that are the stuff of lived experiences, but not necessarily light entertainment, carry elements of risk. Groups of artists committed to conveying compelling stories of our time proceed on faith.

This is not new for us. Our audiences have supported us over many years with vital support! We stand in gratitude and invite you to join them as we embark on this artistic journey.

story:
Short Summary

  • A reading is not a production but it is a very important step in developing a piece of work. The readings, happening on Friday October 13 and Saturday October 14 at Factory163 in Stratford, Ontario, will help in my development of the play over the next two years.
  • Controlled Damage is my personal project in that I want to share this story with everyone who ever stood up for themselves in spite of how it might affect them negatively.
  • With a small contribution you can help me pay the 7 actors a per diem while in Stratford and provide accommodations for one night.

What We Need & What You Get

  • My Call Me Scotty Productions business account still has funds to cover the car rentals, gas and rehearsal space for a couple of days. This campaign allows me to pay each actor a stipend for food and get them a place to sleep for the night
  • There will be four readings in two days in Stratford at Factory163 but this will not generate a substantial income to pay 7 actors. I'm hoping this campaign can assist in topping up a small honorarium for the cast.

The Impact

  • The events that the play covers happened in 1946 and lay buried for over 70 years. Help me bring the story to people who have never heard of Viola Desmond except in a Heritage minute. Your donation will allow a group of students and adults escape for one hour with some of the best actors in the business
  • I've produced three plays to great success in the last four years and this is just the beginning of my best piece. 
  • How could I not champion the story of a tiny black woman who stood up for herself at great personal cost 20 years before the Civil Rights movement? 
  • We are all daughters and sons of Viola

Risks & Challenges

  • This story lay dormant since 1947. 70 years later I believe I'm the right person to give it life. It has to start small, though, and that is why this is a simple reading in a small town in October
  • Four readings in Stratford won't make any of us rich; that's not the point. I am aiming for visibility and to garner interest in a story that is not just about gender, race, and class. This is the great Canadian story about how small acts can create engender great change in a democracy. Thanks to Viola Desmond standing up for herself we live in a much freer country than what existed post WW2.

Other Ways You Can Help

Social Media can always be useful!

  • I know money is tight so if you can just re-tweet, re-post, or just talk about Controlled Damage that will help with the campaign.
  • You've all been so supportive of my various theatre ventures and if you can't contribute then why don't you treat yourself to a road trip in October and visit Stratford? October 13 & 14 will be here before you know it and I hear Tom Rooney is amazing in Tartuffe!

story:
Our Story

We are raising money to improve our community Auditorium in Ajijic, a small village of 10,000 people in western Mexico. The Auditorium is 40 years old and the local government does not have any money to keep it in good repair. Our current project is to upgrade the air conditioning because it is old, very noisy, and doesn’t cool down the building.

The Impact

The auditorium meets a huge community need. School graduations are held here. In the evenings it is used for dramatic, musical, folkloric dance, and mariachi shows.

Most days the sun beats down on the roof all day and it gets pretty hot in there. The local audiences have been waiting many years for an improvement in the air conditioning system.


Evening intermission crowd outside the Auditorium

Who's Organizing this?

It’s organized by Pro Auditorio, a registered non-profit whose only purpose is to improve the Ajijic Auditorium. Three years ago we successfully obtained Mexican federal assistance for a program to significantly improve the interior acoustics. We are still working to improve the lighting, sound, and the seating (representing future budget needs for $25,000 USD). Our volunteer design consultant is retired architect Thom Weeks who has extensive performance-space remodeling experience.

Our technical advisors: Engineer Daniel Ruvalcaba (Quorum Acoustics) and Architect Thom Weeks.

Technical Details of this Project

To isolate the exterior noises from trucks and near-by band concerts we will build solid ducts for both air supply and the extraction lines, complete with sound-absorbing linings. We will recondition the cooling and extraction equipment and upgrade the noisy bearings.

These are the pieces of equipment that will be reconditioned, and the ducts that will be replaced as part of this project.

Project Cost

Construction of new ducts and reconditioning of the mechanical equipment will cost $18,000 USD. We have in the bank $8,000 USD from our annual fund-raising ‘Lip Sync’ show. We need to raise the outstanding balance of $10,000 USD in order to complete this project.


Our Annual Lip Sync Fundraiser

Every year in January, Michael McLaughlin produces and directs the Lip Sync show which has become the biggest and oldest Lip Sync anywhere. It is light-hearted and popular. All the proceeds go to benefit the Auditorium, but they are not enough to cover the projects we want to complete. That's the reason for this campaign.


Choose your perk now - or make a simple donation.


How Can I Pay?

Indiegogo accepts debit and credit cards issued in the U.S. or Canada.

If you live in Mexico and do not have such cards, you can make a simple bank transfer to the Pro Auditorio bank account. (Please convert the value of your perk to pesos.) You will need the following information:

  • Bank: Banco Actinver
  • Account Name: Pro Auditorio del Lago de Chapala A.C.
  • Account Number: 6679559
  • Clave:  133346000006679559

After you have ordered the transfer, you should send a scan or photo of the bank receipt with your name and desired perk to:   proauditorio@yahoo.com   Without this, we won't know who sent the bank transfer.

How Will I get my Perk Tickets?

At the end of this campaign (the week of November 27), or earlier, we will email you details of your ticket options. After you have selected your tickets, they will be set aside in an envelope with your name at the Auditorium desk.

Please help us spread the word about the Ajijic Auditorium project.  Share on your favorite social media; tell your friends; and be sure to attend the next Lip Sync Show in February 2016.

Thank you for your support.
story_txt:
Our StoryWe are raising money to improve our
community Auditorium in Ajijic, a small village of 10,000 people in western Mexico.
The Auditorium is 40 years old and the local government does not have any money
to keep it in good repair. Our current project is to upgrade the air conditioning
because it is old, very noisy, and doesn’t cool down the building.The Impact
The auditorium meets a huge community
need. School graduations are held here. In the evenings it is used for
dramatic, musical, folkloric dance, and mariachi shows.Most days the sun beats
down on the roof all day and it gets pretty hot in there. The local audiences
have been waiting many years for an improvement in the air conditioning system.Evening intermission crowd outside the AuditoriumWho's Organizing this?
It’s organized by Pro Auditorio, a
registered non-profit whose only purpose is to improve the Ajijic Auditorium.
Three years ago we successfully obtained Mexican federal assistance for a program to significantly improve the interior acoustics. We are still working to improve the lighting, sound, and the seating (representing future budget needs for $25,000 USD). Our volunteer design consultant is
retired architect Thom Weeks who has extensive performance-space remodeling
experience.Our technical advisors: Engineer Daniel Ruvalcaba (Quorum Acoustics) and Architect Thom Weeks.
Technical Details of this Project
To isolate the exterior noises from
trucks and near-by band concerts we will build solid ducts for both air supply and the extraction lines, complete with sound-absorbing linings. We will recondition the cooling and extraction equipment and
upgrade the noisy bearings. These are the pieces of equipment that will be reconditioned, and the ducts that will be replaced as part of this project.Project Cost
Construction of new ducts and
reconditioning of the mechanical equipment will cost $18,000 USD. We have in
the bank $8,000 USD from our annual fund-raising ‘Lip Sync’ show. We need to
raise the outstanding balance of $10,000 USD in order to complete this project.Our Annual Lip Sync FundraiserEvery year in January, 
Michael McLaughlin produces and directs the Lip Sync show which has become
 the biggest and oldest Lip Sync anywhere. It is light-hearted and 
popular. All the proceeds go to benefit the Auditorium, but they are not
 enough to cover the projects we want to complete. That's the reason for
 this campaign.
Choose your perk now - or make a simple donation.How Can I Pay?Indiegogo accepts debit and credit cards issued in the U.S. or Canada.If you live in Mexico and do not have such cards, you can make a simple bank transfer to the Pro Auditorio bank account. (Please convert the value of your perk to pesos.) You will need the following information:
Bank: Banco Actinver
Account Name: Pro Auditorio del Lago de Chapala A.C.
Account Number: 6679559
Clave:  133346000006679559
After you have ordered the transfer, you should send a scan or photo of the bank receipt with your name and desired perk to:   proauditorio@yahoo.com   Without this, we won't know who sent the bank transfer.How Will I get my Perk Tickets?At the end of this campaign (the week of November 27), or earlier, we will email you details of your ticket options. After you have selected your tickets, they will be set aside in an envelope with your name at the Auditorium desk.
Please help us spread the word
about the Ajijic Auditorium project. 
Share on your favorite social media; tell your friends; and be sure to attend the next Lip Sync Show in February 2016.
Thank you for your support.

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Third Eye Theatre Ensemble presents quality productions that inspire conversation. We want to get people talking about the issues we face in today's world and hope the power of music and theater can inspire those conversations at a community level. In order to achieve this, we hold talk-back discussions after several of our shows. We strive to champion rarely performed operatic works while advocating social change and providing Chicago's emerging artists with performance opportunities. We perform in intimate spaces so you can be up close to the action, and we have a come as you are policy - no need to dress up for the opera!

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

Many people don't realize that arts organizations cannot survive on ticket sales alone. In a typical arts organization, individual giving makes up 40% of funding. For newer companies, the number is much higher. This is because it is difficult to obtain grant money from foundations and government organizations without a proven track record and body of work. Therefore, we have to rely heavily on individual giving for a large part of our funding. We hope you will believe in what we want to achieve and will contribute as generously as you can. Every bit helps, so even if you can only give $5, that still helps us get closer to our goal.

WHAT YOU WILL GET:

Our perks are listed on the right hand side of the page. We think they are pretty cool! Everyone who donates to our campaign will be listed on our website as a supporter of Third Eye Theatre Ensemble. Those who donate prior to 10/2 will also be listed in our program. Additionally, you'll get our undying gratitude, which we hope counts for a lot, and a feeling that you are making a difference. Your contribution, however big or small, helps us tremendously! You're also helping to keep the performing arts alive. Who wouldn't feel good about that?

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

  • Artist Salaries (Singers, Actors, Directors, Designers)
  • Sets, Lighting, Props
  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Performance Space Rental
  • Truck Rental (for transporting set pieces and lighting equipment)
  • The Rights and Rental Fees to Perform Sumeida's Song
  • Insurance
  • Marketing
  • Unforeseen Expenses (we all know these happen!)

HOW DOES MY CONTRIBUTION HELP:

Here are some examples of what your specific contribution can do for us:

  • $10 buys 1/2 hour of rehearsal space rental
  • $25 buys 1/4 hour of truck rental
  • $50 buys 1 hour of performance space rental
  • $100 buys all of the props for our show!
  • $250 buys all of the costumes for our show!
  • $500 buys all of our set pieces and lighting equipment!
  • $1000 buys the rights to perform Sumeida's Song
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

  • Come and see the show, October 23 through November 8 (Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays)
  • Share this link with others 
  • Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thirdeyete
  • Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/ThirdEyeTE
  • Visit our website at www.thirdeyete.com and sign up for our emails
  • Sign up at iGive.com and shop online at over 1400 retailers who will donate a percentage of your purchase to us - http://www.igive.com/396NT6J
  • Help us spread the word

story:
The Opportunity

Computers that freeze up, cameras that malfunction, printers that jam – These are just a few of the problems faced when you run a charity with very limited resources.  But with some gum, spit and tape we don’t complain at HIV Experience Resources Organization, (HERO).  Our efforts to support people who are newly diagnosed and people living with HIV/AIDS is an act of love.  HERO supports the services and fundraising efforts of all HIV related charities and we don’t do much fundraising to help us keep doing what we do.  So why do we need your help?  We are putting on a show! On October 26, 2015 HERO will present the Second Annual Broadway and Ballet HERO Awards at Stage 48 in New York City.

This year’s event will feature 14 amazing performances from stars of Broadway and Ballet who have joined together to fight against HIV/AIDS.  In 2015 we will honor the work of GMHC (Gay Men’s Health Crisis.  The Broadway HERO award will be presented to Tony Award Winner and four-time Grammy nominated Legend, Melba Moore.  And, the John Adams Hero Award will go to Garen Price Scribner, starring in An American In Paris, for best Broadway Debut.  Melba Moore and Garen Price Scribner will perform at the event.  Last year's event was a big success.  We honored Tony Award Winner Jerry Mitchell, the work of The Actors Fund and Ballet Star, Stephen Hanna.  This year, with your help, we do better and knock it out of the park.  

Promotional video 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vla2Ilg26YY 

Info at  (www.hivhero.org  - YouTube channel heronews.org).

The Impact

We are the little charity that could.  Since 2009, HERO has been helping provide information and assistance for people newly diagnosed and people living with HIV/AIDS.  We need to get the word out about our resources.  The Broadway and Ballet HERO awards will generate much needed press about what we do and how we can help.

In addition, this event promotes the amazing talent of the Broadway and Ballet communities.  We have enlisted so much talent - singers, choreographers, dancers and comics.  We will be filming all of these on-of-a-kind performances and then sharing it with the world on our websites, YouTube channel, social Media, and our partners.

What We Need

As you may know, producing an event like this takes money.  No one gets paid at HERO and all the performers, stage crew, marketing services and video producers have graciously donated their time.  But there are expenses that we just can’t manage to get donated.  Your generous donation will also allow us to pay for venue rental, posters, flyers, donation cards and equipment rental, and equipment upgrades,  

The funds we raise from the Broadway and Ballet HERO Awards will allow us to finally do a redesign and upgrade of our website, and to attend and report from HIV/AIDS related conferences.  In addition, money raised will pay for expenses involved in covering HIV/related events and providing services free of charge to all partner organizations.  To date, HERO has produced over 500 videos to help stop the spread of HIV/AIDS.

A Little Background

HIV Experience Resources Organization (HERO) is a non-profit 501(3)(c) organization founded in 2009 by Michael Cavnaugh, former Vice President of Event Presentation at Madison Square Garden. HERO helps people navigate through the system that hinders timely assistance for people who need it. HERO’s Websites, HIVhero.org and HEROnews.org, provide local, national and international resources and interactive tools that provide assistance in finding doctors, getting medication, mental health, housing, financial assistance, insurance, returning to the work force and much more. We also serve as a portal site providing free content and promoting the services, activities and fundraising efforts of our partner organizations, which include Broadway Cares, Equity Fights AIDS, The Actors Fund, GMHC, The LBGT Center and many others. HIVhero.org also provides the latest in HIV/AIDS news.

HERO produces celebrity interviews and event coverage that support the services, activities and events of our partners. These videos are filmed and edited in house, and provided to partner organizations and the media open free of charge. Celebrity interviews discussing safe sex, and healthy living with HIV/AIDS, have been conducted with celebrities including Cyndi Lauper, Matthew Bomer, Angela Lansbury, Neil Patrick Harris, Bebe Neuwirth, Alley Sheedy, Kelly Ripa, Mary Louise Parker, Alan Cumming Chita Rivera and many others. 

More Ways You Can Help

So, if you want to help us and join the fight against HIV, you are a patron of the arts or you are just a really great person, please consider donated to this campaign. HERO is a 501 (3) (c) registered charity.  All donations are tax deductible to the full extent of the law.  We also welcome equipment donations and any other creative assistance.  We are always looking for volunteers who can offer their expertise and resources to help us make a difference.  And if you can, please tell people about www.hivhero.org and The Broadway and Ballet HERO Awards.  More information about the event can be found at www.broadwayandballet.org. 

Please subscribe to your YouTube channel - Heronews.org and follow us on Facebook - HIVhero and twitter @hivhero.

Thank you in advance for your consideration

story:
Haitian-born Gaspard Louis rose to prominence as a dancer and choreographer with the internationally renowned Pilobolus Dance Theater. His work has been praised for breathtaking combinations of Pilobolean shape building and fluid lyricism that resonate in the emotional core of human nature. In five seasons with Durham-based Gaspard&Dancers, Louis has built a distinct and deeply moving body of work.

With your generous support, Gaspard&Dancers’ upcoming sixth season will feature a new work, “Tota Pulchra Es–You All Are Beautiful.” Conceived as a companion piece to Louis’ Trilogy, based on the devastating 2010 earthquake and its aftermath. The Trilogy features exuberant and haunting music by composers Joshua Starmer, Randall Love, and Paul Leary. “Tota Pulchra Es” celebrates the universal bonds of humanity. World-renowned composer Bill Banfield has created the score and the Mallarmé Chamber Players recorded this exciting piece of music that is scored for piano, violin, viola, cello and percussion.

Gaspard&Dancers will have their New York premiere at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts on September 25th and 26th, 2015. They will present “Tota Pulchra Es – You All Are Beautiful” along with the Trilogy.

Please join us in making our New York performances an experience to be remembered! Your donation will help provide dancers salaries, costume and lighting design and transportation. 

All donations will receive our heartfelt thanks! Other great perks include a pair of tickets to the show in New York City and a G&D T-shirt for a donation of $200 or more, an invitation to an open rehearsal for a donation of $300 or more, and your name in the New York program as a sponsor of our new work for a donation of $500 or more!

We hope you can join us in New York and appreciate your support!

story:
What is Lipstick Theatre?

Lipstick Theatre is Northwestern University’s only theatre group dedicated to tackling women’s issues through performance and providing female theatre artists with opportunities for artistic growth and expression. The objectives of Lipstick Theatre are to produce dramatic works written by female playwrights, have strong female characters, have a largely female-based ensemble, or address women’s issues.

Tell me about 5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche!

5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche, written by Evan Linder and Andrew Hobgood, premiered in 2011 at The New Colony in Chicago, Illinois. Since then, it has enjoyed several successful productions in cities across the country. This March, Lipstick Theatre is bringing the show to Northwestern’s campus, with a semi-immersive production in the historic Shanley Pavilion. Every audience member will be an attendee of the 1956 Quiche Breakfast hosted by the Susan B. Anthony Society for the Sisters of Gertrude Stein. The meeting will be business as usual, until the ladies suddenly find themselves trapped in their community center indefinitely. Secrets start to come out and all the rules that bind these mid-20th century women together fly out the quadruple-paned window. It’s a sight to see.

Why should I support 5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche?

5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche will be a breath of fresh air on the Northwestern theatre scene. Its fast-paced antics and satire are of a genre rarely seen in student theatre. Also rarely seen are shows that feature a complete cast of fully-formed female characters. The play explores parts of the female experience and the queer experience in an honest and entertaining manner. The play also sheds new light on a dark part of American history: the fear that loomed underneath the idyllic image of the 1950s. Quiche will be Lipstick Theatre’s first production as an official member of the Northwestern Student Theatre Coalition, and we couldn’t be more excited to continue Lipstick’s mission with this exciting piece!

Where does the money go?

All donations go to major design elements that, put together, will bring the world of the show to life. Each piece of the puzzle is absolutely vital in making the show what it is.

Set and Space: We are immersing audience members in the world of the show by turning Shanley Pavilion into a 1950s community center.  We will be playing with interior decorating, creating different set pieces, and making sure the audience is as close to the action as possible.

Lights: The tone of the show shifts from scene to scene, and as it does, the lighting keeps up with the play’s fast-paced action. Subtlety is not the word we’re looking for.

Sound: There is a crazy world outside the community center and a crazy world inside it, and our sound team is working to create cues for impactful moments in the space.

Props: Because the show is so immersive, props are absolutely vital to the world of the play, from the use of quiche, to the passing of nametags, and everything in between.

Costumes: In order to recreate silhouettes and styles from the 1950s, our costume designer is both buying and sewing her own pieces. The production team will also be wearing 1950s-style accessories and outfits during each performance.

Hair and Makeup: Partnering with our costume designer is our hair and makeup team, who will help display the unique personality of each officer in the Society.

The Cast: Or, the Officers of the Society

Abby Doermann – Lulie Stanwyck, President

Maddy Kelly – Wren Robin, Events Chairwoman

Kali Skatchke – Ginny Cadbury, Secretary

Carrie Caffrey – Dale Prist, Historian

Ele Hagermoser – Veronica “Vern” Schultz, Buildings and Grounds Chairman


Production and Team

Rachel Holtzman  Producer

Sydney Thomas  Space and Set Designer

Connor MacMillen  Lighting Designer

Jim Alrutz  Sound Designer

Jon Mathias  Dramaturg, Assistant Sound Designer

Sophia Sinsheimer  Costume Designer

Stefani Amick  Co-Hair and Makeup Designer

Madisen Hursey  Co-Hair and Makeup Designer

Jason Yuan  Graphic Designer

TBA  Properties Designer

Nat Kier     Fundraising Director

Allison Towbes     Publicity Director

Joy Holden  Outreach Coordinator, Business Officer-at-Large

Rehearsal Team

Hale McSharry     Director

Taylor Stark     Assistant Director

Alina Carrel  Stage Manager

Showtimes:

Thursday, March 3rd

Friday, March 4th

Saturday, March 5th

Location:

5 Lesbians eating a Quiche will be performed in Shanley Pavilion located at 2031 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL.

Tickets:

Tickets are available at the door: $5 for Northwestern Students and $10 for General Public.

I want to support this, but I’m having trouble donating through Indiegogo?!

Send cash and checks made out to Northwestern University!

You can send checks to:

Rachel Holtzman

1870 Orrington Ave

Evanston, IL 60201

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can also help us out by sharing the link to this page! We appreciate your support!

The production team will also be wearing 1950s-style accessories and outfits during each performance.Hair and Makeup: Partnering with our costume designer is our hair and makeup team, who will help display the unique personality of each officer in the Society.The Cast: Or, the Officers of the SocietyAbby Doermann – Lulie Stanwyck, PresidentMaddy Kelly – Wren Robin, Events ChairwomanKali Skatchke – Ginny Cadbury, SecretaryCarrie Caffrey – Dale Prist, HistorianEle Hagermoser – Veronica “Vern” Schultz, Buildings and Grounds ChairmanProduction and TeamRachel Holtzman  ProducerSydney Thomas  Space and Set DesignerConnor MacMillen  Lighting DesignerJim Alrutz  Sound DesignerJon Mathias  Dramaturg, Assistant Sound DesignerSophia Sinsheimer  Costume DesignerStefani Amick  Co-Hair and Makeup DesignerMadisen Hursey  Co-Hair and Makeup DesignerJason Yuan  Graphic DesignerTBA  Properties DesignerNat Kier      Fundraising DirectorAllison Towbes      Publicity DirectorJoy Holden  Outreach Coordinator, Business Officer-at-LargeRehearsal TeamHale McSharry      DirectorTaylor Stark      Assistant DirectorAlina Carrel  Stage ManagerShowtimes:Thursday, March 3rdFriday, March 4thSaturday, March 5thLocation: 5 Lesbians eating a Quiche will be performed in Shanley Pavilion located at 2031 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL.Tickets:Tickets are available at the door: $5 for Northwestern Students and $10 for General Public.I want to support this, but I’m having trouble donating through Indiegogo?!Send cash and checks made out to Northwestern University!You can send checks to:Rachel Holtzman1870 Orrington AveEvanston, IL 60201If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can also help us out by sharing the link to this page! We appreciate your support!

story:
It's Real!

 Our community is in desperate need of a great awakening; crime, violence, murder, teen pregnancy, drug addiction and suicide have all been a rising number in our community for the past few year. Some of these problems are in part due to the lack of attention and detail we as adults pay to the warning signs these youth show before self destruction. “It’s Real!” will focus on the struggles of youth in today’s society, having youth re-enact real life issues will bring realism to the situation at hand and force parents, teachers and spiritual leaders to no longer turn a blind eye to these problems; and “out of sight out of mind” will no longer be a valid excuse. From this production we as spiritual leaders will understand the need to step up to the plate and offer Godly advice to parents and children struggling with these real life issues.


Where is the money going?

  • Equipment rentals
  • Location Fees
  • Awards banquet
  • Food
  • Travel
  • Lodging 
  • Marketing. (Flyers, Programs, tickets etc.)
  • Tech and Camera Crew
  • T-Shirts
*If our overall goal isn't reached the money that is raised will go back into the production and used to reward the children that are involved. 

The Impact

* By contributing you are planting a seed in a child's life. Giving them hope and assuring them that they can be somebody. The children that are cast has never performed on stage and some has never traveled outside of the county and therefore your contribution, whether it's $5 or $500 it is showing them that the sky is the limit. Sometimes, the boost we need is to see that others believe in our potential to be great.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • TAKE OUT YOUR PHONE and send the link to contribute to 10-20 people in your contacts.
  • SHARE on your social media and with your family and friends.
  • MOST IMPORTANTLY attend the show. Come witness the hard work that the kids are doing and help fill seats. It's nothing like performing to a full audience.

Be blessed but most importantly be a blessing!!

story:
Pourquoi ?

  •  Edimbourg pour les francophones ! Edinburgh pour les anglophones ! à la gaélique : prononcez Ed'nbourrrou (en faisant rouler les r) ! 
  • Tout cela pour vous dire que  j'aurai la joie de participer cette année à l'Edinburgh Fringe, le plus important festival artistique au niveau mondial. J'ai décidé de reprendre l’œuvre de ma vie "L'histoire de Sally McLaureen" dans son essentiel, cette fois, dans une version seule en scène de 50 mn, adaptée pour les enfants.
  • Ce sera dans une version anglaise (festival international oblige!) avec vidéoprojections que j'ai choisi de transmettre "l'esprit" Sally McLaureen : la notion des racines, l'éthique, la force de l'espoir, l'hommage à tous les migrants qui ont eu le courage d'abandonner leur terre en vue d'une vie meilleure... tout en gardant la magie du spectacle au fil des musiques que certains connaissant déjà ou que d'autres découvriront grâce aux contreparties des contributions ! ;-)
  •  La chanson L'Histoire de Sally Mac Laureen avait reçu en 2005 Le Prix Danjou-Boda au Festival de Cambrai et le Prix du Jury-Sacem à Savigny-sur-Orge. Puis, le musical celtique a aussi gagné, dans sa version française, le prix Découverte en 2007 suite aux présentations au Théâtre Mouffetard à Paris.
  • Cela fait 10 ans que le musical celtique dans sa toute première version courte, en janvier 2006, a obtenu une standing-ovation, au Festival Les Musicals. Aussi, pour célébrer ces dix ans, une terre celtique s'imposait. C'est pourquoi, je rêvais d'Edimbourg et de son Fringe Festival pour créer The McLaureen's Tale. Aussi dans ce monde où rien ne se fait sans argent ou sans solidarité, ;-) j'aurai grandement besoin de votre aide précieuse.
  •  Aujourd'hui, c'est au sein de Spotlite, 22-26 George Street, l’un des principaux lieux du Fringe, que je donnerai cette version toute spéciale chaque jour de 11h30 à 12h30, dans le cadre du festival qui aura lieu du 5 au 29 août. Previews les 4 & 5 août.  J’espère avoir le bonheur de vous y retrouver pour partager de beaux moments ensemble. Edimbourg est une cité magnifique qui mérite le détour avec ses parcs et ses collines, où domine son château. N’hésitez pas à venir y faire un tour, il n’y fait pas trop chaud l’été ! ;-)

 Comment ?

  • Participer à une festival de cette envergure, cela demande des fonds... D'abord il aura fallu payer l'inscription au Fringe pour s'inscrire au programme du Festival d'Edimbourg... (4OO £ soient 520 euros environ) + réserver la salle en prépayant une partie (1300 euros) + réserver le logement en avançant déjà un peu plus de 1000 euros... Soient déjà environ 3000 euros d'avancés. A cela s'ajouteront : l'assurance pour le mois de représentations + les frais de technicien + la location de matériel + les flyers et affiches à imprimer + l'achat d'espaces publicitaires + les frais de transports + les frais de décors, costumes et autres en rapport avec la création du spectacle... Soient encore au moins 3000 euros nécessaires pour que le spectacle puisse voir le jour à Edimbourg... C'est pourquoi ce serait une aide formidable que vous apportiez votre pierre à l'édifice...
  • En remerciement, vous serez crédités sur mon site web  et trouverez des contreparties en rapport avec le spectacle au gré des participations (mp3, affiches, pdf des partitions, places de spectacles, atelier d'écriture etc...). Pour avoir déjà plusieurs amis qui ont organisé des crowdfunding, je sais que ce sont souvent à travers les participations, en fonction des bourses de chacun, les gestes de soutien qui font chaud au cœur et qui donnent le courage d'avancer dans le processus de création. Car dans le spectacle vivant, comme à Edimbourg, chaque point réserve parfois des surprises et est souvent plus couteux que prévu, notamment ici parce qu'il faut aussi compter en £ et non en euros, ce qui augmente de 30 % la mise. Mais le jeu en vaut la chandelle. 
  • Et pour ceux qui souhaitent aussi participer activement, si le cœur vous en dit, merci de faire circuler l'information ! bouche à oreille, réseaux sociaux, déambulation en homme ou femme-sandwich avec les affiches du spectacle ou le nouveau costume du Fringe !... toutes les idées sont les bienvenues ! :-)
  •  Et n'hésitez pas à cliquer sur les outils de partage Indiegogo !
  • Merciiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii !!!!! et à bientôt j'espère! au coeur de l'aventure...

story:
1 in 5 women on college campuses report experiencing sexual violence. But how many of those names do we know?

The impulse for our play was born when our playwright and lead actress, Anna Baryshnikov, encountered a question at a women's empowerment fundraiser: just as we, in the present, find that the fact that women once did not have access to voting or higher education ludicrous, what in 2060 will women be shocked was once true in 2016?

The widely-known statistic that 1 in 5 women on college campuses report experiencing unwanted sexual contact jumped into Anna's head and never quite left. She approached her friends from college, Brandon Powers and Seonjae Kim, two theatre directors who once participated in creating a devised show about campus sexual assault for their school’s (Northwestern University) freshman orientation. The three of them remembered the honest conversations that play sparked, and felt an urgent desire to revisit it through a different story.

Sexual assault on college campuses has been a heated topic in the news in the past few years. America has had to confront how survivors of sexual assault often feel that both the legal system and their academic institution fail to bring justice to their cases. Many of these survivors have bravely spoken up in various public ways about their experiences, gaining national attention.

But what we don't see on the news is what happens after they do. Their voices bring awareness and discussion to a  difficult issue - but are their own lives changed for the better? What happens to a young woman’s life after she becomes a symbol?

Meet Ella Maythorne, your average spirited freshman. When her Halloween night at a frat party goes terribly wrong, and both the school and the police authorities refuse to fight for her, Ella decides to take matters into her own iPhone, launching a social media campaign against her rapist. She is now the face of a national feminist movement, a poster child for campus sexual assault, an activist for the Instagram era, and a celebrity in her own right - but where does she go from there?

It’s a heavy topic, for sure, but also expect to have some fun: throughout the play we are launched into concert-like moments with classic Britney Spears that allow us access to Ella’s fantasies and nightmares. Anticipate lip syncing, hip hop dancing, as well as boldly comedic dialogue and dynamic film sequences to guide us through our heroine's triumph and turmoil. With all these elements, The Essential Ella Maythorne explores just how far a young woman has to go to be heard in this world.

Our show was recently selected to perform on the mainstage of Dixon Place on February 19th, a venerable New York institution and supporter of new work. To make that happen, we need your help! 

Where's My Money Going?
  • Approx. $1,600 to pay our creative team and actors.

  • Approx. $1,900 for space rentals and other rehearsal expenses.*

  • Approx. $500 to cover props/costumes and marketing costs.

  • Approx. $500 to cover other administrative costs and videography/photography.*

  • If we raise up to $5,000, we will use the surplus funds to pay our cast and team more for their hard work. We believe that artists should be paid.

  • If we raise more than $5,500, we will donate the surplus funds to RAINN.

We are working hard to further reduce production costs, through the generosity of our friends in NYC (We've already received generous support from La Mama Experimental Theatre Club). If in lieu of a monetary donation, you would like to support us by hooking us up with some free/low-cost rehearsal space, printing, props and costume rentals, email us!
Your support will be instrumental to making this small but mighty production happen.
Why Us?

We get it. End of 2015 just happened, you donated to a bunch of charities, and this is yet another crowdfunding project. But hear us out:

Our show on February 19th will be the World Premiere, so the possibilities of where our little show could go is endless. We want to present a fresh and fantastic first draft of our show so it can have a future, and you will have been there from the beginning.

The cast and creative team will be comprised of entirely young, emerging artists, and this will be one of their first opportunities to present original work in New York. Think of this as a not only supporting a show but supporting the launch of many exciting careers in the arts.

Finally, we hope to both raise awareness and start conversations about an important, complicated issue, as well as make a really entertaining and moving piece of theater. We believe that those two things absolutely can, and should, go together. We want to utilize every moment of the process, including this Indiegogo page, to bring people together raise difficult questions.

If any of these reasons appeal to you, consider supporting us, even if it's just a few dollars. No donation is too small.

Even More Ways You Can Help!

Save the date for our performance on the Dixon Place mainstage, February 19th at 10pm! Tickets are inexpensive, especially if you buy ahead online. Bring your friends!

Spread the word on social media using #EssentialElla and following our Facebook event page. We would love to get a diverse (in every sense of the word) audience at our show, so please share away!

If you might be able to connect us with free/low cost rehearsal space, printing, or costumes/props rentals, please contact us at EssentialEllaMaythorne@gmail.com.

Finally, please take a moment to check out - and volunteer your time and money if you can - to some of these wonderful organizations doing the difficult and necessary work of supporting sexual assault survivors around the country:

  • RAINN - Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network  (https://rainn.org)

  • Safe Horizon - NYC area specific victim servies agency (http://www.safehorizon.org/)

  • Not Alone - information for students, educators, survivors and advoates (https://www.notalone.gov/)

  • 1 in 6 - Support for male survivors (https://1in6.org/)

Thank you so much for reading! Your support means the world to us.

Love,

The entire Ella Maythorne team

Playwright: Anna Baryshnikov

Directors: Seonjae Kim & Brandon Powers

Light Design: Jason Fok

Sound Design: Miles Polaski

Set Design:

Emmie Finckel

Projection and Video Design: Sang Min Chae

Featuring: Anna Baryshnikov, Betsey Brown, Bianca Crudo, Peter Falls, Isabella Mehiel, Dhari Noel

story:
Una bailarina rumbo a NY

Mi nombre es Marina y mi sueño de ser bailarina cada vez está más cerca.

 Mi abuela tiene una figura de Lladró de una bailarina, y cada vez que iba a su casa me quedaba embelesada mirándola. Empecé a bailar con 3 años, después de darle la tabarra a mis padres diciéndoles "¡Quiero bailar de 'puntillitas'!". Comencé tomando clases en una pequeña escuela de mi ciudad natal, y pronto destaqué por el interés, la concentración y la madurez que demostraba mientras bailaba. Cuando cumplí los 10 años, me decidí por completo a dedicar mi vida a bailar, y empecé a prepararme para entrar en el conservatorio.

Con 12 años entré en el Conservatorio Profesional de Danza de mi ciudad, Cádiz. Allí proseguí mis clases durante 5 años, aunque lo normal sea que dure 6 años,hasta acabar la carrera de Danza Clásica con una media de 10. Mientras tanto, proseguí con mis estudios de enseñanza obligatoria, los cuales acabé con buenisíma nota, y luego el Bachillerato, que acabé con Matrícula de honor. 

En este momento estoy en Sevilla, llevo aquí ya un año viviendo con mi tío, y soy alumna del Centro Andaluz de Danza, en el que sigo perfeccionándome para poder audicionar y conseguir algún puesto en alguna compañía. Además estudio la carrera de Bellas Artes en la Universidad de Sevilla.Como podéis ver "No Paro".


En mi tierra, la danza clásica (el ballet) no tiene "ni por asomo" el arraigo del flamenco. Para mis padres (los cuales nunca han dejado de apoyarme a conseguir cualquier cosa que me proponga) siempre ha supuesto un gran desembolso de dinero, esfuerzo y tiempo, todo por ayudarme a conseguir mi meta. Pero la situación es ahora complicada, ya que la crisis económica nos ha golpeado con dureza y nos está dificultando, en especial a mis padres, el poder seguir apoyándome en el tema económico. 

Aún así, han conseguido que vaya a cursos de perfeccionamiento, audiciones (como la del English National Ballet School, el Boston Ballet School , la School of American Ballet...) y concursos, en los que he participado e incluso conseguido algún premio o beca, (como el Certamen Ciudad de Barcelona, Concurso de Ribarroja del Turia...)

En diciembre, con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo (físico y económico), realicé la audición para el Joffrey Ballet School, y aún estando lesionada durante la prueba, he conseguido 2 BECAS COMPLETAS para cualquiera de los programas intensivos de verano en el ELITE LEVEL ( danza contemporánea y ballet clásico) en EEUU, aparte de ser aceptada en el programa TRAINEE del curso 2016/17.

Debido a la situación que vivimos, aún habiendo obtenido 2 becas completas, no puedo permitirme ni el viaje ni la estancia ni la manutención allí. 

¡¡¡¡¡Es por ello que recurro a vosotros y os pido ayuda para poder ir a NY, y de esta forma estar más cerca de mi sueño!!!!!

¿QUÉ NECESITO?

Para poder realizar mi viaje de 4 semanas en verano a NY, necesito:

  • VIAJE EN AVIÓN A NY (ida-vuelta) -------> 1000€
  • ALOJAMIENTO--------------------------------> 1900€
  • COMIDA----------------------------------------> 900€
  • VESTUARIO (obligatorio)-------------------> 400€
  • GASTOS---------------------------------------> 600€
  • CLASES---------------------------------------->4800€

                                                                     TOTAL= 9600€

¿QUÉ APORTO? 
  • IMPORTE DE LAS BECAS -------> 4800€
  • AHORROS--------------------------> 300€
                                                     TOTAL= 5100€
Por lo cual, gracias a las becas y a lo poquito que tengo ahorrado sólo me quedaría conseguir 4500€.
Aún así, estoy tratando de encontrar algún trabajo durante mi estancia en NY para reducir este importe.
SÉ QUE ES COMPLICADO, PERO LAS OPORTUNIDADES SON POCAS, Y SÉ QUE ESTA ES UNA DE ELLAS....

Por eso te pido que, aunque no me puedas ayudar, comparte mi campaña en tu muro de Facebook, con tus amigos, familia....

GRACIAS DE TODO CORAZÓN!!!!!!! <3 



Dancing road to NYC

My name is Marina and my dream of being a ballerina every time is more nearby.
My grandmother has Lladró's figure of a ballerina, and whenever I was going to her house I was giving fascinated looking at her.I started dancing with 3 years, after boring to my parents saying to them " I want to dance in pointe shoes! ". I started by taking classes in a small school of my natal city, and soon I stood out for the interest, the concentration and the maturity that I was demonstrating while I was dancing. When I turned 10 years, I decided to dedicate completely my life to dance, and I  started preparing to enter to the conservatoire.
With 12 years I entered the Professional Conservatoire of Dance of my city, Cadiz. There I continued my classes for 5 years, though the normal thing should be that lasts 6 years, up to ending the career of Classic Dance with an average of an A. Meanwhile, I continued with my studies of compulsory education, which I ended with a really good note, and then the Baccalaureate, which I finished with honors.
At this moment I am in Seville, go here already one year living with my uncle, and I am a dancer of the Andalusian Center of Dance, in which I am still perfecting me to be able to audition and  obtain some place in a company. In addition I study the career of Fine arts in the University of Seville. Since you can see " I Don´t stop ".
In my land, the classic dance (the ballet) does not have " not for glimpse " the rooting of the Flamenco dance. For my parents always it has supposed a great disbursement of money, effort and time, everything for helping myself to obtaining my goal. But the situation is now complicated, since the economic crisis has struck us with hardness and is impeding us, especially to my parents, the power to be still relying on the economic topic. 
Nonetheless, they have helped me to go to auditions (as that of the English National Ballet School, the School of American Ballet ...) and contests, in which I have taken part and even obtained some prize or scholarship, (as the Contest City of Barcelona, Ribarroja del Turia's Contest ...)
In December, with a lot of work and effort (physical and economic), I realized the hearing for the Joffrey Ballet School, and yet being injured during the audition, I have obtained 2 COMPLETE SCHOLARSHIPS  (jazz and ballet) for any of the intensive summer programs in the ELITE LEVEL in the USA, apart from being accepted in the program TRAINEE of the course 2016/17.
Due to the situation through that we live, still having obtained 2 complete scholarships, I can allow me neither the trip nor the stay nor the subsistence there. 

It's for it that I appeal to you and ask for you to help me to be able to go to NY, and of this form be more near my dream!!!!!
WHAT DO I NEED?
To be able to realize my trip of 4 WEEKS IN SUMMER to NY, I need:
  • TRIP IN PLANE TO NY (going - return)-------> 1000 €
  • HOUSING-----------------------------------------> 1900 €
  • FOOD-----------------------------------------------> 900 €
  • (Obligatory) UNIFORM---------------------------> 400 €
  • EXPENSES-----------------------------------------> 600 €
  • TUITION-------------------------------------------> 4800 €
                                                                   TOTAL = 9600 €

WHAT DO I CONTRIBUTE? 
  • AMOUNT OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS-------> 4800 €
  • SAVINGS----------------------------------------> 300 €
                                                               TOTAL = 5100 €
For which, thanks to the scholarships and the small thing that I have saved only me it would be able only to obtain 4500 €.
Nonetheless, I am trying to find a job during my stay in NY to reduce this amount.
I KNOW THAT IT IS COMPLICATED, BUT THE OPPORTUNITIES ARE SMALL, AND I KNOW THAT THIS ONE IS ONE OF THEM....

Because of it I ask you that, though you could not help me,  shares my campaign in your Facebook's wall, with your friends, family....
THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF MY HEART!!!!!!! <3
story_txt:
Una bailarina rumbo a NY Mi nombre es Marina y mi sueño de ser bailarina cada vez está más cerca.


 Mi abuela tiene una figura de Lladró de una bailarina, y cada vez que iba a su casa me quedaba embelesada mirándola. Empecé a bailar con 3 años, después de darle la tabarra a mis padres diciéndoles "¡Quiero bailar de 'puntillitas'!". Comencé tomando clases en una pequeña escuela de mi ciudad natal, y pronto destaqué por el interés, la concentración y la madurez que demostraba mientras bailaba. Cuando cumplí los 10 años, me decidí por completo a dedicar mi vida a bailar, y empecé a prepararme para entrar en el conservatorio.



Con 12
años entré en el Conservatorio Profesional de Danza de mi ciudad, Cádiz. Allí
proseguí mis clases durante 5 años, aunque lo normal sea que dure 6 años,hasta
acabar la carrera de Danza Clásica con una media de 10. Mientras tanto, proseguí con mis estudios de enseñanza
obligatoria, los cuales acabé con buenisíma nota, y luego el Bachillerato, que
acabé con Matrícula de honor. 



En este momento estoy en
Sevilla, llevo aquí ya un año viviendo con mi tío, y soy alumna del Centro
Andaluz de Danza, en el que sigo perfeccionándome para poder audicionar y
conseguir algún puesto en alguna compañía. Además estudio la carrera de Bellas Artes en la Universidad de Sevilla.Como podéis ver "No Paro".



En mi tierra, la danza clásica (el ballet) no tiene "ni por asomo" el arraigo del flamenco. Para mis padres (los cuales nunca han dejado de apoyarme a conseguir cualquier cosa que me proponga) siempre ha supuesto un gran desembolso de dinero, esfuerzo y tiempo, todo por ayudarme a conseguir mi meta. Debido a la situación que vivimos, aún habiendo obtenido 2 becas completas, no puedo permitirme ni el viaje ni la estancia ni la manutención allí. 
¡¡¡¡¡Es por ello que recurro a vosotros y os pido ayuda para poder ir a NY, y de esta forma estar más cerca de mi sueño!!!!!

Para poder realizar mi viaje de 4 semanas en verano a NY, necesito:


VIAJE EN AVIÓN A NY (ida-vuelta) -------> 1000€
ALOJAMIENTO--------------------------------> 1900€
COMIDA----------------------------------------> 900€
VESTUARIO (obligatorio)-------------------> 400€
GASTOS---------------------------------------> 600€
CLASES---------------------------------------->4800€

                                                                     TOTAL= 9600€

¿QUÉ APORTO? 


IMPORTE DE LAS BECAS -------> 4800€

AHORROS--------------------------> 300€

                                                     TOTAL= 5100€

Por lo cual, gracias a las becas y a lo poquito que tengo ahorrado sólo me quedaría conseguir 4500€.

SÉ QUE ES COMPLICADO, PERO LAS OPORTUNIDADES SON POCAS, Y SÉ QUE ESTA ES UNA DE ELLAS....




    Por eso te pido que, aunque no me puedas ayudar, comparte mi campaña en tu muro de Facebook, con tus amigos, familia....

story:
WHAT IS THE CAVE: A FOLK OPERA?

In an opium den at the turn of the 20th century, Willow sacrifices her life to pay off her father’s debt by working in an occult underground society called "The Cave." In this musical exploration of fairy tales, myths, and spiritualism, Willow fights to find light not only in the grim and strange shadow-world around her, but also within herself. 

The Cave: A Folk Opera, by Melanie Rose Thomas with direction by Christopher D. Betts and musical direction by Aaron Lindenberg, will have its New York City debut this March. With workshop productions at Sarah Lawrence College, Vassar College, and in London at The British American Drama Academy, The Cave: A Folk Opera has generated a following of emerging artists and received acclaim for its hypnotic form of storytelling and enchanting original music. The Cave is a new story inspired by the classic Beauty and the Beast fairy tale, and told entirely through original folk music. Using the format of an opera, along with folk music & highly poetic lyrical content, The Cave creates a mystical landscape of folklore and occultism. 



THE IMPACT

The Cave brings to light the relevance and depth of ancient stories, the muted female voices in the volatile history of women's sexuality, the search for redemption within addiction, and the struggle to find love within loss and sorrow. The funds raised here will support the development of this poignant piece. Your donation will support emerging artists with diverse voices and the creation of a new kind of musical theater. With your help, The Cave: A Folk Opera will be a success!

We are grateful to you from the bottom of our hearts for helping us to continue to bring this magical world to life. We will send you updates along the way so you can see the production you have helped to create! We hope to see you at The Cave: A Folk Opera opening March 31st at Access Theatre. 


WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

Between booking rehearsal and performance space, bringing our designers' ideas to life, marketing & logistics, and most importantly, making sure our artists are compensated for their time and dedication, a great deal of money is required to fund our production. 

The world of The Cave is an extravagant one, and our designers are doing the best they can to create low-budget designs, but in order to fully realize their visions, we will need financial support. Along with this, we have over 20 people working to bring this show to life. We need to show them how grateful we are for their dedication by compensating these incredible artists for their time. These are just some of the more specific places where money is being spent, but we pay for everything from printing scripts to marketing the show to renting out the theatre for the production. This production is not funded by any major investors, so your contribution, even if small, will make all the difference. Check out our budget breakdown to get an idea of how much money it takes to fund an off-off-broadway production in NYC.

Basic Budget Breakdown: 

  • Theater Rental: $5,000
  • Rehearsal Space: $3,000
  • Design Budget: $2,500
  • Marketing: $1,000
  • Insurance: $500
  • Payment for Cast, Crew, & Creative Team: $5,000

Take a look at the perks to see all the wonderful items we are offering in gratitude for your support! 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP 

If you can't support us monetarily, that's okay! Send this campaign along to your friends who you think will like The Cave: A Folk Opera. Then, bring your friends and come say hi at our concerts & our production! You can also sign up for our mailing list (HERE) & receive a free audio download of a Cave song. We would love to welcome you into The Cave.
