We would love to welcome you into The Cave.

story:
About The Play

It’s the end of the world.

A once-promising medication goes awry, mutating 51% of the world’s population into shells of human beings, with only the basic motor functions left to chase, bite, and kill. (Yep. They’re zombies.)

Three men, seemingly alone in the apocalypse, are honestly pretty all right with it. With all the women gone, they can finally kick back, relax, and get back to their men-only BBQ.

Until Alex—an intersex person who everyone assumes to be female—distorts the dichotomies in which these men view their black and white world. How is Alex alive? Is Alex’s life worth saving? And—ultimately—how can the men go about saving Alex when women are strictly against the BBQ rules?

In a quest for survival, adaptation is necessary. Will masculinity bend for a new world, or is the pull of routines of a lost time too strong to resist?

*This play was inspired by an actual list of BBQ rules that an actual man actually wrote. And yes, one of the rules is “no women.”

 

Meet Our Team

Paige Zubel - Playwright and Co-Producer

Paige Zubel is a Philadelphia-based playwright, dramaturg, and producer. Her plays have been performed internationally, with notable productions in her hometown of Houston, TX ($12.50/Hour, Sunday Flowers), New York City (Gel Us, In Full Bloom, The Pull of the Moon), and Scotland (Under Covers). Her plays and prose have been published through One Act Play Depot, Every Day Fiction, and Hashtag Queer. Most recently, her play A String Between Man and the World was awarded What If? Productions Best New Play Award and will receive its world premiere in 2018. She is a member of The Foundry, a Philadelphia emerging playwrights’ lab, and Artistic Associate of Philadelphia’s Shakespeare in Clark Park. For more: paigezubel.com. 

Max Friedman - Director and Co-Producer

Max is so happy to be making his NYC directorial debut with this fantastic piece. He is currently the Artistic Intern at Manhattan Theatre Club and has previously worked at the Public Theater, New York City Center Encores! Off-Center, Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, and Great River Shakespeare Festival, to name a few. Favorite select directing credits include: Rhinoceros, Trojan Women, Generation Z, and Things (un)Said. BA in Directing - Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University. mfdirector.com.

Natali Arco - Lighting Designer

A West Palm Beach, FL native, and a recent graduate of the Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University, Natali Arco is an emerging freelance lighting designer based in New York City. She is a collaborative artist with a passion for live performance, interactive art, and graphic design. She is the season designer for Winter Opera St. Louis, and tours nationally as the designer for Layon Grey's Black Angels Over Tuskeegee.  She has assisted for the Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, and was a lighting assistant for the Opera Theatre of Saint Louis' 40th Festival Season. Natali has also served as a Professional Lighting Design Intern with Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Creative Entertainment in Orlando, FL and as a Lighting Design Intern at The Williamstown Theatre Festival in Massachusetts. Additionally, Natali has varied experience in theatre, opera, dance, site-specific venues and concert venues as well as corporate events and exhibits. For a more comprehensive list of her design work, visit her site: nataliarco.com

Robert Accurst - Set Designer

Robert Ashurst is freelance scenic designer based in New York City and recent graduate of The Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University where he earned his BFA in Scenic Design. He currently is working on Broadway and Off-Broadway productions as an assistant for Derek McLane. Robert has designed scenery for both Macbeth and Dogfight at the Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University and The Mikado at Union Avenue Opera. His assistant credits include productions for The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Goodman Theatre, St. Louis Shakespeare Festival, The Albany Park Theatre Project, Variety Children’s Theatre, Max & Louie Productions, and Mustard Seed Theatre. ashurstdesign.com.

 

What We Need

The NY Winterfest provides a performance space and we have already secured our rehearsal space for this project. However, there are still a lot of expenses to make this project a reality.

  1. Participation fee: $250
  2. Cast and crew payment, designer fees, and photographer fees: $950
  3. Production costs: $700
  4. Marketing: $350
  5. Miscellaneous expenses, including a safety-net fund and complimentary tickets for industry professionals: $300
  6. Indiegogo fee: $125

Total: $2,625

We completely understand friends and supporters who may not be able to give monetarily. If you feel so inclined, please help us spread the word to make this project a reality!

 

Where Does The Money Go If We Exceed Our Goal Or Come in Under Budget?

Should we exceed our fundraising goal, our first priority will be to pay our performers and designers more.

After that, any extra income will be donated to the Harvey Relief Fund, as both the playwright and director of this project are proud to call Houston their hometown.

Additionally, the NY Winterfest offers many prizes which DEAD MEAT will be eligible for including Best Overall Play, Best Original Play, and Best Director. Should Dead Meat be awarded any of these, a portion of the prize money will also be donated to the Harvey Relief Fund.

She is the season designer for Winter Opera St. Louis, and tours nationally as the designer for Layon Grey's Black Angels Over Tuskeegee.  She has assisted for the Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, and was a lighting assistant for the Opera Theatre of Saint Louis' 40th Festival Season. Natali has also served as a Professional Lighting Design Intern with Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Creative Entertainment in Orlando, FL and as a Lighting Design Intern at The Williamstown Theatre Festival in Massachusetts. Additionally, Natali has varied experience in theatre, opera, dance, site-specific venues and concert venues as well as corporate events and exhibits. For a more comprehensive list of her design work, visit her site: nataliarco.com

Robert Accurst - Set Designer
Robert Ashurst is freelance scenic designer based in New York City and recent graduate of The Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University where he earned his BFA in Scenic Design. He currently is working on Broadway and Off-Broadway productions as an assistant for Derek McLane. Robert has designed scenery for both Macbeth and Dogfight at the Conservatory of Theatre Arts at Webster University and The Mikado at Union Avenue Opera. His assistant credits include productions for The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Goodman Theatre, St. Louis Shakespeare Festival, The Albany Park Theatre Project, Variety Children’s Theatre, Max & Louie Productions, and Mustard Seed Theatre. ashurstdesign.com.
 

What We Need
The NY Winterfest provides a performance space and we have already secured our rehearsal space for this project. However, there are still a lot of expenses to make this project a reality.

Participation fee: $250
Cast and crew payment, designer fees, and photographer fees: $950
Production costs: $700
Marketing: $350
Miscellaneous expenses, including a safety-net fund and complimentary tickets for industry professionals: $300
Indiegogo fee: $125

Total: $2,625
We completely understand friends and supporters who may not be able to give monetarily. If you feel so inclined, please help us spread the word to make this project a reality!
 

Where Does The Money Go If We Exceed Our Goal Or Come in Under Budget?
Should we exceed our fundraising goal, our first priority will be to pay our performers and designers more.
After that, any extra income will be donated to the Harvey Relief Fund, as both the playwright and director of this project are proud to call Houston their hometown.
Additionally, the NY Winterfest offers many prizes which DEAD MEAT will be eligible for including Best Overall Play, Best Original Play, and Best Director. Should Dead Meat be awarded any of these, a portion of the prize money will also be donated to the Harvey Relief Fund.

story:
Pale Fire Productions was created by Denver theatre artists Liz Nye and Seth Maisel as a means to explore what the boundaries of audience/performer relationships are and how we can break them down.  As part of our mission to bring visibility to the Colorado theatre scene and to create theatre experiences that change the way we view what it means to be on stage (or in the dark, watching), we are thrilled to be going on this journey to Scotland to expand the footprint of our theatre community to a global audience. 

Donors will receive prizes based on donation level, which we will be launching on our website over the week of January 15th to the 20th.  Prizes include sweet, sweet merch like bumper stickers, t-shirts, mugs, and more!  Watch for them on our Facebook page and our website.  And don't forget that even if you can't give, you can share!  Link our campaign on your social media, and remember to add how adorable we are!

Your donation dollars will help subsidize travel and housing costs, as well as performance royalties for our five Edinburgh performances.  

Financial breakdown:

Travel costs: $1200

Housing: $800

Performance rights: $400

story:
Keeping Live Theatre Alive - Just Online!

 

The Zenith Players & the Social Distancing Players have teamed up on a coproduction of The Importance of Being Earnest, performed online on Facebook and YouTube, and starring professional actors who would otherwise be unemployed due to theaters and renaissance festivals being closed during the ongoing COVID-19 crisis.

The Social Distancing Players started up after the onset of what we're now calling the QuaranTime as a way to help professional performers be semi-quasi-gainfully employed, with there being a minimum goal of $100 being made for each actor for each performance. For this particular show, we're upping that ante to $150, and also looking to raise money for the Zenith Players, a community theatre in New Jersey, to allow them to continue to purchase the performance rights for shows that are not in public domain, as well as to pay for the costs that are incurred by needing to have a robust online presence.

The overall financial goal of this campaign is $2,500 - netting each performer and person working on the show $150 and a further $500 for the Zenith Players as an organization (Indiegogo has its own costs that take some money off of the total $2,500).

The show will be on Wednesday, August 12th, at 7:05 pm EDT and aired LIVE on Facebook and YouTube.

If you donate at least $30, we invite you to join the cast for a post-show virtual tea party (complete with cucumber sandwiches!).

Thank you for helping us to keep live theatre alive!

- Claire, TJ, & Dan

story:
What We Do

For 15 years Twinhead Theatre has created adventurous programming to aid and abet self-producing artists. Our projects include:

  • an immersive guest artist program culminating in a full-length sketch comedy production,
  • a video contest for filmmakers of all experience levels,
  • collaborative community writing sessions, and
  • the annual Atlanta Fringe Festival

Our goal is to create an Atlanta arts scene that is accessible and welcoming to artists at any stage in their careers. Your donation will help pay for festival production equipment, artist stipends, props and scenery, as well as marketing tactics to reach more people in our community.

What We Need

Your donation will help pay for:

  • $3,000 - Production equipment and supplies for 20 shows in the Atlanta Fringe Festival
  • $3,800 - Marketing and audience development efforts for the Atlanta Fringe Festival
  • $6,400 - Props, costumes, scenery and artist stipends for 2 full-length Twinhead shows
  • $1,800 - Marketing efforts for Twinhead’s 2 full-length shows, 4 video contests, and 12 collaborative community writing sessions

Total $15,000

The Impact

Your support makes difference in the Atlanta arts community. Your donation makes the following possible:

  • New and emerging Atlanta artists can entertain, enlighten, and inspire our community with interesting perspectives and unique voices.
  • The Atlanta Fringe Festival can remove financial and logistical barriers and create professional opportunities for self-producing artists.
  • Twinhead Theatre can provide professional development, collaboration, and learning opportunities for anyone at any stage of their artistic development

Success Stories

These programs work, and they lead to lifelong arts collaboration and creation -- which, in turn, helps contribute to the cultural fabric of our community by creating a scene as exciting, challenging, and vibrant as the city itself. Here are some of our recent success stories:

  • A former Twinhead guest artist has become a regularly-booked comedian with her own sketch comedy show
  • Former Twinhead guest artists have created their own productions featured in the Atlanta Fringe Festival
  • Past festival performers have gone on to tour the circuit of other fringe festivals across the country
  • High school and college students have performed in the festival, gaining real-world knowledge to pair with their studies. Several have since graduated, are working in the industry and continue to perform in the festival.
  • Atlanta Fringe Festival has paid out more than $40,000 in ticket revenue to artists

Please donate today to help us make more artist success stories.

story:
Who We Are

Wanderlust: Theatre on Location is a Tallahassee-based site-specific musical theatre company with the mission of reimagining local spaces through musical theatre to illuminate and celebrate community identity. Because each of our shows is staged site-specifically where the story actually takes place, Wanderlust presents the unique opportunity of reinvigorating community spaces as they provide essential, authentic backdrops and bring musicals to life.


After last summer's sold-out run of our walking musical theatre experience Musicals on the Move in Midtown Tallahassee and a commissioned site-specific adaptation of A Christmas Carol for Thomasville's Victorian Christmas festival, Wanderlust unfortunately had to cancel our planned immersive summer 2020 production of Into the Woods due to COVID-19, which was meant to be staged on location in the woods at historic Lichgate conservancy in July.

As a 501(c)3 performing arts organization, we operate through live performance, and our entire season of programming has to be reimagined in the face of COVID limitations in terms of gathering cast, crew, and audience.

 

About the Project

Like many artists coming to terms with this ever-changing landscape, Wanderlust is looking to adapt to find new ways to bring a site-specific theatre experience to Tallahassee that can be safely enjoyed amidst COVID-related restrictions. Thus, we are creating a pre-recorded, auditory walking theatre experience in conversation with the Frenchtown Heritage Trail, a set of thirteen historical sites that chronicle the story of Tallahassee's historic Black neighborhood. In cooperation and conversation with the neighborhood’s Riley House Museum, this socially distant, site-specific audio musical theatre experience will be downloadable for guests to experience safely at their own pace. Once on the Trail, guests will listen along to songs and stories based on the history of the very place they're standing! Creative work will be based on oral histories and research conducted by the Riley House Museum.

Original music will be composed by Tallahassee-based artist and activist Royce Lovett, who appeared on the last season of NBC's The Voice. Lovett will also sample music from local musicians, such as the late Darryl Steele, a lifetime Frenchtown resident and iconic Blues Trail musician. Connective storytelling text will be created by local poetry collective Black on Black Rhyme.
 

The Impact

Wanderlust is committed to creating a space where diverse voices and experiences, courageous discourse, and community engagement are not only valued but essential to our shared success and growth.

Our project will celebrate the rich and fascinating history of Frenchtown, Tallahassee's historic Black neighborhood. We aim to raise awareness of the area's unique history through musical storytelling and promoting foot traffic to the area & its local businesses through our socially-distant auditory theatre experience.

The entire creative output of the project will be commissioned work by exclusively local Black artists. Mr. Lovett, who will be writing the music, will work closely with students from Griffin Middle School & Godby High School to include the talents and voices of young Frenchtown residents in the creative process of the project.

Amidst the changing realities brought by COVID-19, Wanderlust has been rethinking how we may continue to create site-specific theatre that celebrates our diverse community and illuminates local identity, all the while keeping our guests safe and socially-distanced. This bespoke project is designed FOR the community, BY the community.

 

Our Challenges

As a live performing arts organization, our entire mode of operation has virtually been rendered untenable by COVID-19. Presently, we cannot gather collaborative artists or host audiences at live productions, so we are creatively adapting to these new realities by creating cultural arts experiences that can be safely enjoyed by the community based on social distancing guidelines.

As noted in the project description, The Frenchtown Project will be pre-recorded and
accessible to the community to download for free and enjoy at their leisure while walking the
outdoor Frenchtown Heritage Trail.


As we await the future fate of live performances, Wanderlust is forging ahead with the creation of new works that keep audiences safe while still providing essential artistic engagement. We have no idea when theatre may return in its traditional form, and we seek to innovate new ways to bring the arts to the Tallahassee community.

 

How Funds Will Be Used

All donations will be put towards the commissioning of talented Black artists who will be creating this experience,  as well as providing local Frenchtown youth an opportunity to collaborate with professional artists.  Funds will also support production costs associated with recording and producing the music, paying local musicians, and marketing costs.

We are nearly halfway to our funding goal for this project, but we still need your help to bring this vital work to life! We appreciate donations large and small from both individuals and potential corporate sponsors.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that giving may not be possible for everyone during this time. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign with your network via email or social media
  • Identify any potential sponsors who may be interested in helping to fund this project
  • Follow us on social media @wanderlustonlocation on Facebook & Instagram.

 

We thank you for your ongoing support of our creative vision and mission to bring community-responsive theatre to Tallahassee!

Share this campaign with your network via email or social media

 We thank you for your ongoing support of our creative vision and mission to bring community-responsive theatre to Tallahassee!

story:
Short Summary

No More Toys is written and directed by me, Pierce Minor, a Los Angeles based writer, director and actor (Adopt a Highway, Book Club, How to Get Away With Murder). My professional background is mainly rooted in writing and acting for film, television, and commercials, but theater has always been my first love and foundation. I’ve also directed several festival recognized short films, including “Little Brown Baby” (2017), and my latest short, “Deity,” which will premiere later this year. Having been away from the stage since my 2014 roles in “The Dark Side of the Moon” and “Do Angels Sing the Blues” in Los Angeles, I am very eager to dig back into stagework with No More Toys - also my theatrical directing debut.

No More Toys began as a feature film script, taking place in mostly all one location. It has since evolved into a stage play, and has attracted a talented LA cast to help me bring it to life: Luis Garcia (Jesus and Moi, Homeward Los Angeles), Anthony D. Washington (S.W.A.T., Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.), Crystal Coreen (Broken Minds, Death Pool), Arlene Victoria Conrad (The Spectrum, Leo), Danice Cabanela (The Debt Collector, Forget Me Nots), Chidi Ohaeri (Six Degrees of Separation), and Jamal Henderson (Finding Home, Past and Presence).

Produced by myself and Michelle Roshanzamir, this ensemble drama is looking to add its mark to the already exciting and steady growing Hollywood Fringe Festival community. And we want YOU to be a part of it!

Synopsis of No More Toys

After a successful presentation, Todd, a local college recruiter, returns to a high school classroom to retrieve his forgotten baseball cap.  Upon arrival, he realizes that something is off - and that one of the students is out of place. Todd doesn’t take the hint to leave and suddenly finds himself held hostage by the disgruntled student in the room.

Why Fringe?

Started in 2010 by Founder Ben Hill and other organizers, “the Hollywood Fringe Festival is an annual, open-access, community-derived event celebrating freedom of expression and collaboration in the performing arts community.

Each June during the Hollywood Fringe, the arts infiltrate the Hollywood neighborhood: fully equipped theaters, parks, clubs, churches, restaurants and other unexpected places host hundreds of productions by local, national, and international arts companies and independent performers.” (https://www.hollywoodfringe.org)

In addition, the Fringe is a great place for artists to try out new material in front of an audience.

What We Need & What You Get

The total cost of the show is about $3,500.  It includes:

  • Venue rental for 5 shows
  • Insurance
  • Hollywood Fringe Registration
  • Rehearsal Space & Tech
  • Production Tech Expenses
  • Set/Prop Expenses
  • Marketing (poster, postcards, flyers, ads, playbills, etc.)
  • Wardrobe/Costumes
  • Photography

By supporting us with pre-sales, you’ll get a reserved ticket to the show of your choice plus optional extras!  Choose from the following packages:

Basic Reserved ($15) - Includes one reserved ticket, choice of show before general tickets sales starting May 1.

VIP Reserved ($25) - Includes Basic Reserved + VIP reserved seat in the front half of the house.

VIP Select ($50) - Includes VIP Reserved + drinks after the show with the Cast & Director, 1st drink on us!

Friend of the Show ($100) - Includes VIP Select + deluxe copy of the play script signed by the original cast & crew + a special thank you in our program.

Open Donations ($5-500) - You can, of course, donate however much you wish. This will go directly toward production costs.

**The money raised will go towards covering production fees - anything over basic production costs will go towards paying the hard working cast and crew of the show.**

The Impact

Stories have always had the capacity to bring people together, and theater is one way to do so.  While the Hollywood Fringe Festival has provided a space for creatives to present their work, it has also continued to provide a way for the Los Angeles community to have access to theater at an affordable price point.

Risks & Challenges

As always, as with much in the arts, theater can be a risky investment.  HOWEVER. It’s something that’s real and is happening right in front of you.  It provides connection and an experience in a world that’s continuing to be technologically driven.  Theater provides a great way to connect in real time with friends, family, colleagues and the world around us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute? That’s ok, there are still ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign on social media - send it to people you know might be into theatre, or who might just want to support the show.
  • Follow us on social media for updates on the show.

story:
What’s Happening:

At 6:00 PM on March 14th Karel and Josef Čapek’s Adam The Creator will be presented for the first time in Washington, DC, at the Embassy of the Czech Republic. Following the reading, audiences and artists will enjoy a reception and continue discussing the the play, its past development and future.

Originally written in 1928 and unproduced for almost a century, Adam The Creator and the Čapeks are long overdue a presence in the American theatre. 

 

Who is Adam The Creator?A Synopsis:

Adam, out of frustration with the corrupt state of humanity, takes to the public square where he negates all of existence and is then charged with the re-creation of the universe. Adam ventures to build a new, better world by attempting to create the ideal man, woman, and companion from a pile of clay and the breath of life. Grappling with the inherent struggles that come with implementing his ideals in reality, he creates his own Alter Ego, who in turn engages him in a challenge to create the ideal society. Soon after, Adam and Alter Ego lose control of their creations who are now at war with each other for ultimate power. Years later, Adam and Alter Ego return to the scene of their creation to learn that though they are being worshipped, they have not managed to improve the condition of the human race. Through his attempt to create a quintessential society from his own solitary existence, Adam glimpses the inherent value of life and the beauty of humanity despite all its flaws.

How’d We Get Here:

In 2015, Megan and I determined that Karel and Josef Čapek’s Adam The Creator is too important and too good to be ignored any longer. With only one english translation in 1931 London, we began creating a new adaptation. As theatre artists ourselves, we were able to streamline cast size and length to increase the play’s producibility in the contemporary theatre and sociopolitical landscape. 

Additionally, we realized the play's growing relevance to our current world. By adapting the text, we’ve renewed the spirit and themes of the Čapek’s original text in a uniquely American voice. In doing so, we’ve created an intercultural dialogue as relevant in 2019 America, as it was in 1928 Czechoslovakia.

Who We Are: Pete Danelski & Megan Diehl

Both graduates of DeSales University, Megan and I have been working in professional theatre on several fronts, while creating a creative partnership along the way. Together we have the skills to bring Adam The Creator to a new audience:

Megan Diehl is a playwright and director with a background in creating and developing new theatre. She is also the Advancement & Communications Manager with the Pennsylvania Shakespeare Festival. Megan holds a masters degree from Villanova University.

Pete Danelski is a DC based writer, director and theatre maker. He has worked throughout Pennsylvania and DC. Pete is a 2019 Director-in-Residence with the Drama League of New York City, where he will develop an original play. He is also Business and Operations Associate with CulturalDC, producing work across DC. Pete holds a masters from Trinity College Dublin.

What We Need & What We Promise:

We understand contributing is not always easy. Any donation is welcome, however we believe in the power of small individual contributions. If just over 30 supporters contribute $30 each, we'll easily make our goal. The progress we've seen so far has been made possible only by individuals in the US and Prague who share our commitment to this work. We are dedicated to growing our circle of supporters. 

Your support will ensure Adam The Creator receives the high-quality DC debut it deserves. $1000 of support will fund:

  • Payment for eight actors who will rehearse and perform the play
  • Expenses for artists.
  • Materials and supplies
  • Further project development.

By contributing to this campaign, you will also help us pay an equitable wage to local DC artists. Even if our goal isn't met, all funds raised will go toward supporting the artists making this reading possible.

We want to commit to those who have committed to us. As a contributor, you will be kept up to date on Adam The Creator news and development moving forward.

 

How to Support:

Every contribution, of any size, makes a difference and is appreciated! If you can’t donate, there are plenty of ways to help!

Spread the Word- Let people know about this project. Help connect us with people who should be involved!

Share this Link- Use the social media buttons on this page to share campaign with your friends! You can also share the link to this campaign.
story_txt:
What’s Happening:At 6:00 PM on March 14th Karel and Josef Čapek’s Adam The Creator will be presented for the first time in Washington, DC, at the Embassy of the Czech Republic. Following the reading, audiences and artists will enjoy a reception and continue discussing the the play, its past development and future.Originally written in 1928 and unproduced for almost a century, Adam The Creator and the Čapeks are long overdue a presence in the American theatre.  Who is Adam The Creator?A Synopsis:
Adam, out of frustration with the corrupt state of humanity, takes to the public square where he negates all of existence and is then charged with the re-creation of the universe. Adam ventures to build a new, better world by attempting to create the ideal man, woman, and companion from a pile of clay and the breath of life. Grappling with the inherent struggles that come with implementing his ideals in reality, he creates his own Alter Ego, who in turn engages him in a challenge to create the ideal society. Soon after, Adam and Alter Ego lose control of their creations who are now at war with each other for ultimate power. Years later, Adam and Alter Ego return to the scene of their creation to learn that though they are being worshipped, they have not managed to improve the condition of the human race. Through his attempt to create a quintessential society from his own solitary existence, Adam glimpses the inherent value of life and the beauty of humanity despite all its flaws.How’d We Get Here:In 2015, Megan and I determined that Karel and Josef Čapek’s Adam The Creator is too important and too good to be ignored any longer.
